Queries amount of triplets in scope or burst buffer Blocks until previously initiated measurement is complete and returns result finally Tests if there is measurement data to fetch Blocks defined time until previously initiated measurement is complete and returns result finally Starts a new single measurement for a previously configured unit Starts a new continuos measurement for a previously configured unit Measures a software triggered sequence of power W values in scope mode Measures a software triggered sequence of current A values in scope mode Measures a software triggered sequence of voltage V values in scope mode Measures the sensor averaged power in Watt or dBm for both channels simultaneously Measures the sensor averaged current for both channels simultaneously Measures the sensor averaged power density for both channels simultaneously Measures the sensor averaged voltage for both channels simultaneously Measures the sensor averaged power in Watt or dBm Measures a hardware triggered sequence of power W values in scope mode. string
PM5020 Powermeter SCPI Commands
None ACQ CAL CON DISP INP MEAS SENS SOUR STAT SYST
V 1.1.4.82 generated 28 Mar 2024, 10:16:43

This is the description of the Thorlabs PM5020 remote interface. This dual channel Power/Energy meter can be remotely controlled using the SCPI (Standard Commands for Programmable Instruments) interface.

In 1975, the IEEE standardized a bus developed by Hewlett-Packard originally called HPIB (Hewlett-Packard Interface Bus), later changed to GPIB (General Purpose Interface Bus). The standard was called IEEE 488 (IEEE 488.1) and it defined mechanical aspects of the bus. The later IEEE 488.2 defined its protocol properties. What was missing were set of rules between the manufacturers on commands to control the instruments. Sometimes these varied even between different models from the same manufacturer.

In 1990 SCPI Consortium released the first SCPI standard as an additional layer for the IEEE-488.2 standard.

SCPI commands are ASCII strings, which are sent to instrument over the physical communication layer. They can perform:

  • Set operations, for example the *RST command (resetting the instrument).
  • Query operations, for example the *IDN? query (querying the instrument’s identification string).

Some SCPI commands exist as both set commands and query commands. An example is an Powermeter's averaging command SENS:AVER. You can set it with the SCPI command SENS:AVER 2, and also query its current value with the SENS:AVER?.

The format mentioned in this manual e.g.: SENSe#:AVERage[:COUNt] <pres> is called canonical form. Here are the most important rules to remember:

  • The parts within square brackets are not mandatory and can be left out.
  • All # within the command represent a suffix positive integer number starting at 1. If there is only one suffix you may skip it because default is applied internally. If there are two or more suffix it is mandatory to specify all.
  • The capital letter parts are mandatory; the small letters can be omitted. This is called short form. An example of the above command in the short form is SENS1:AVER 3. You can use either the short form, or the long form SENSE1:AVERAGE 3, but nothing in between, e.g. SENS1:AVERA 3.
  • The SCPI commands are case-insensitive. You can also use the short form sens1:aver 3 or or the long form sense1:average 3
  • Combine multiple commands into one string using selmicolon ';'. For example, a combined string of SENS1:AVER 3 and SENS1:CORR:WAV 850 is SENS1:AVER 3;CORR:WAV 850. Notice that the second command does not have the SENS1: part. The reason is, that the command tree path does not change within one string. If you want to reset the command tree path to the root, use the colon character at the beginning of the second command: SENS1:AVER 3;:SENS2:CORR:WAV 850.
  • Create query forms by adding a question mark, mostly to the end: SENS1:AVER? Sometimes there is an additional parameter placed after the question mark. There must be a space character between the question mark and the additional parameter. For example: SENS1:CORR:WAV? MIN

The complete SCPI standard is available here: SCPI-99

Measurement Systems

The PM5020 supports three different general measurement modes. The following section provides a detail description of these modes. Not all modes are supported by all Sensors.

CW vs Peak mode

The PM5020 supports two different measure modes for different sensor types. In CW mode the discrete input signal is sampled fixed at 100 kHz. Every millisecond the device processes the last 100 sample results. In CW mode the device calculates outputs a constant measurement result stream regardless of input signal. This mode is supported for Photodiodes, Thermopiles and four Quadrant Thermopiles.

In peak mode the PM5020 internally samples the signal at 400 kHz and searches for peaks in the digitalized input data. Only peak values and their relative timestamp are forwarded to the calculation process. In peak mode the measure stream output rate depends on the input signal repetition rate. If there are no peaks in input signal or the power meter is not configured appropriately no peaks are detected and there are no results to query. This mode is supported for Photodiodes and Pyroelectric sensors.

The peak mode supports an overshoot filter signals. Use the command SENSe#:PEAKdetector:FILTer to enable/disable the overshoot filter. For sinus or triangle shaped signals disable the filter. It should be used for rectangular shaped signals where the flat top should be detected as peak and not the possible overshoot of the rising edge.

Slow Measurement System

The "Slow Measurement System" is available for all sensor types and measurement modes. It returns values up to a frequency of 1kHz. The command SENS:AVER can be used to scale down the update rate by formula MeasFreq = 1000/AVG in CW mode. In Peak mode the averaging is not used. Averaging is considered for the following units only:

  • POW: Photodiode, Thermopile, 4 Quadrant Thermopile: Sensor power in W or dBm (See command SENSe:POWer:UNIT)
  • ENER: Pyro: Sensor energy in Joule
  • CURR: Photodiode: Sensor current in Ampere
  • VOLT: Thermopile, 4 Quadrant Thermopile and Pyro: Sensor voltage in Volt
  • PDEN: Photodiode, Thermopile, 4 Quadrant Thermopile: Sensor power density in W/cm²
  • EDEN: Pyro: Sensor energy density in J/cm²

All other units have their own independent update rate.

In peak mode the output depends on the repetition rate of the input signal. For repetition rates larger than 1 kHz, all peaks within the recent millisecond will get averaged. Use the “Fast Measurement Stream” to access single pulses in that case.

Every measurement channel is configured independently. The SCPI commands for this measurement system are part of the MEAS group. This group contains some convenience commands. These commands internally call a predefined SCPI command sequence. Starting with the well-known MEAS? convenience command:

  1. ABOR
    Aborts any ongoing measurement
  2. CONF
    Configures measurement channel for power measurement
  3. INIT
    Starts a new measurement
  4. FETC?
    Blocks until measurement is complete and returns the result

If the same unit should be read multiple times in a row, reconfiguring the channel again and again is not necessary. Therefore, use the READ? convenience command instead:

  1. ABOR
    Aborts any ongoing measurement
  2. INIT
    Starts a new measurement
  3. FETC?
    Blocks until measurement is complete and returns the result

The following diagram shows two examples of SCPI command sequences for the Slow Measure System. There is no timing constraint between the single SCPI commands. Timeline is from left to right.

The first example shows a 1 kHz measurement scenario with an averaging of 1. INIT starts a new measurement. Once the measurement is complete, the result is stored internally until FETC? is called. If FETC? is called multiple times in a row the same result will be returned as no new measurement has been started.

The second example show a 500 Hz measurement scenario with an averaging of 2. INIT starts the new measurement. Before the measurement result is ready FETC? is already called. As the measurement is still ongoing in the background the FETC? blocks the entire remote interface until measurement has been taken.

Once you send a FETC?, MEAS? or READ? command, the interface is blocked until the measurement has been taken. For Photodiode in CW mode, Thermopile, 4 Quadrant Thermopile sensors these commands work reliable except for very high averaging. High averaging values result in a long block time when waiting for the measurement to terminate. Continue reading to get a solution for this special case.

For Pyroelectric sensors and Photodiode sensors in Peak mode the blocking of FETC?, MEAS? or READ? might be a problem. For constant pulse repetition rates > 0.5 Hz the commands work reliable. But when working with low pulse rates or even single pulse signals it is very likely to end up in a communication timeout of the USB, Ethernet or serial interface. The following time diagram shows the problem. Note: the timeout of 3 seconds is just an example here.

The PM5020 internally blocks 10 seconds before the internal FETC? function terminates. Within this time do not send an ABOR or any other SCPI command. Please do not enlarge the communication interface timeout to solve this problem but continue reading.

The lower part of the diagram shows the command sequence to use for one of the following cases:

  • Photodiode, Thermopile, 4Q Thermopile: AVG > 2000
  • Pyroelectric, Photodiode in Peak mode: Slow pulse repetition rates < 0.5 Hz
  • Pyroelectric, Photodiode in Peak mode: Single pulsed signals

Once a new measurement has been started by INIT, checking for completion can be done by the command FETC:STAT? If this command returns 1, FETC? can be called with providing an instant result. If the FETC:STAT? returns 0, continue to ask for completion or abort the measurement if not longer relevant by using the ABOR command. Do not use the convenience function in these cases.

Another configuration of the Slow Measurement system is the continuous measurement. For this mode there are no convenience functions. Use the following sequence for continuous mode:

  1. ABOR
    Aborts any previous ongoing measurement
  2. CONF:POW
    Configure a power measurement for example
  3. INIT:CONT
    Start continuous measurement
  4. FETC?
    Returns the last recent measurement result
  5. Delay()
    Delay between reading results
  6. FETC?
    Returns the last recent measurement result
  7. Delay()
    Delay between reading results
  8. ...

Keep in mind in continuous configuration there is no synchronization between the command and the measurements. If FETC? is called faster than the measurement update rate, the same result is read multiple times.

For measuring 4 Quadrant Thermopile voltages MEAS:Q4V? or beam position MEAS:POS?, the commands will return multiple results for the X and Y coordinate or the four voltages.

Fast Measurement Stream

The "Fast Measurement Stream" is available for Thermopiles, Photodiodes in CW and peak mode and Pyroelectric sensors. 4 Quadrant Thermopiles are not supported. The stream is accessed by the SCPI ACQ command group. The PM5020 samples the analogue frontend at 100 kHz. For CW mode this results in 100 000 Samples per Second. The Fast Measurement Stream allows to accessing this data stream. There is no averaging available here. The data is stored for every channel independently in a queue allowing to buffer data for 10 ms. If the queue is full, new data will be lost. To ensure no data is lost, the reading needs to be as fast as possible. The data transfer of the ACQuire:FAST SCPI commands are binary to minimize transfer time and data conversion. The response has the following little endian byte order:

Every millisecond the PM5020 adds a list of up to 100 tuples (time, measurement) to the queue as a non-dividable package. For Pyroelectric sensors or Photodiodes in Peak mode the Fast Measurement Stream is a list of all peak Energy or Power values found. The signal pulse repetition rate has to be smaller than 98 kHz.

All samples are tuples of relative time as 32-bit unsigned integer and measurement value as IEEE compliant float. The timestamp allows plotting the data, even if some data of stream is lost. Data loss is likely at some point because the PC is not always fast enough to query all data packages within 10 milliseconds. The wrapping 32-bit microsecond counter timestamp is relative and is not a wall time. This timestamp should be used to calculate the delta between the samples. For CW mode the delta is 10 us for sporadic pulse signals the delta is variable. To calculate the delta between the samples integer wrapping must be considered. The following example demonstrates the special case.

4294967282, 0.0001233
4294967292, 0.0001265
                  6, 0.0001274
                16, 0.0001254

Use the following pseudo code to calculate the delta:

if(sample[n+1] > sample[n])
  delta = sample[n+1] - sample[n]
else
  delta = 0xffffffff - sample[n] + sample[n+1]

The "Fast Measurement Stream" does not support measuring result unit dBm. Changing the measurement range will interrupt the stream for multiple milliseconds, allowing the hardware to settle. If queue does not contain any data, ACQ:FAST:FETC? result length is read as zero without any further payload. Changing the unit of the stream will discard any previously queued measurement results.

A typical fast measurement stream command sequence looks like this:

  1. ACQ1:FAST:POW
    Configure channel 1 fast measurement stream for power measurement
  2. ACQ1:FAST:RESET
    Reset the fast measurement stream of channel 1
  3. ACQ1:FAST:FETC?
    Poll data of stream. Response length is likely to be 0 because of previous reset.
  4. ACQ1:FAST:FETC?
    Poll data of stream
  5. ...

The following code gives an example to parse the fast mode binary data in Python:

inst.write('ACQ1:FAST:FETC?')
vals = inst.read_bytes(4)
length = struct.unpack('<I', bytearray(vals[0:0+4]))[0]
vals = inst.read_bytes(8 * length)
res = []
i = 0
while i < 8 * length:
   reltime = struct.unpack('<I', bytearray(vals[i:i+4]))[0]
   value   = struct.unpack('<f', bytearray(vals[i+4:i+8]))[0]
   res.append([reltime, value])
   i += 8;

Scope Mode

The "Scope Mode" implements an oscilloscope like measurement method in the PM5020. It is only available for the CW mode for photodiode and thermopile sensors. Pyroelectric and Four Quadrant Thermopile sensors are not supported by this measurement mode. An internal or external trigger starts a measurement to a fixed size internal buffer. Once the buffer is filled completely, the measurement stops automatically. Data remains valid in the buffer until the measurement gets started again. The buffer of the PM5020 stores always 10 000 samples in total. The maximal sample rate of the two measurement channels in scope mode is 100 kHz. With the 10 000 samples this results in a total time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For longer time intervals the averaging of scope must be used. If averaging is set to two the scope buffer is filled at 50 kHz resulting in a total time of 200 ms.

Before starting a scope measurement for optical power reading ensure:

  • Set manual range (Disables auto ranging of PM5020 automatically), command: SENSe#:POWer[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer]
  • Set full bandwidth for Photodiode sensors (no analog filter), command: INPut#[:PDIode]:FILTer[:LPASs][:STATe] 0
  • Choose CW mode for Photodiode sensors, command: SENSe#:FREQuency:MODE CW
  • Disable acceleration for thermopile sensors, command: INPut#:THERmopile:ACCelerator:AUTO 0
  • Set trigger threshold for internal hardware triggered signal, command: SENSe#:PEAKdetector (Not applicable for external triggering)

The scope mode is part of the MEAS SCPI command group. The basic command sequence looks like this:

  1. ABOR
    Abort any ongoing measurement
  2. CONF1:ARR:CHA
    Configure unit for channel 1. Skip if not connected or not needed
  3. CONF2:ARR:CHA
    Configure unit for channel 2. Skip if not connected or not needed

  4. CONF:ARR 1
    Configure software Scope mode with averaging 1 OR
    CONF:ARR:HWT 1,100
    Configure hardware Scope mode with averaging 1 and hpos 100

  5. INIT
    Starts a scope measurement
  6. FETC:STAT?
    Scope buffer filled? If not keep on asking. For timeout send ABOR finally
  7. FETC:STAT?
    Scope buffer filled? If not keep on asking. For timeout send ABOR finally
  8. ...
  9. FETC:STAT?
    Scope buffer filled returned true.
  10. FETC? 0
    Read scope buffer content at index 0
  11. FETC? 1
    Read scope buffer content at index 1
  12. ...
  13. FETC? 9999
    Read scope buffer content at index 9999

Once configured, a new scope measurement is taken with the following sequence:

  1. INIT
    Starts a scope measurement. Uses previous configuration
  2. FETC:STAT?
    Scope buffer filled?
  3. ...
  4. FETC:STAT?
    Scope buffer filled returned true.
  5. FETC? 0
    Read scope buffer content at index 0
  6. FETC? 1
    Read scope buffer content at index 1
  7. ...
  8. FETC? 9999
    Read scope buffer content at index 9999

The scope mode supports two trigger types. First the simpler software trigged Scope mode. Here the sample buffer gets filled directly after receiving the INIT SCPI command. If FETC? is called before the buffer has been filled, the command will block. An averaging pre-scaler allows to sample longer periods with less resolution. Any incoming HW triggers are ignored.
Second the more complex hardware triggered scope mode. The following diagram visualizes the mode. Time flows from left to right.

After receiving the first CONF:ARR:HWT the PM5020 directly starts storing measurement results in the pre-trigger buffer. The CONF:ARR:HWT sets the averaging pre-scaler to allow longer time periods and the trigger horizontal position (hPos) to allow the scope to show also part of the signal before the trigger condition. The diagram shows an example for averaging = 1 and hPos = 100. The measurement is not yet started, and the trigger is not armed. Any incoming trigger condition is ignored.

With the INIT command the trigger becomes armed. The next trigger condition will start the scope measurement if the pre-trigger buffer is filled already. If not, the condition is skipped as well. When the trigger is valid the scope continues storing the measurement results in the post-trigger buffer and unarms the trigger automatically until a future INIT invalidates the previous buffer and starts a new measurement. Any incoming FETC? or FETC:ARR? during an ongoing measurement blocks until the buffer is filled completely. If the post-trigger buffer is filled completely, the PM5020 continues measuring in the shadow pre-trigger buffer for the next measurement in background. The results of pre-trigger and post-trigger buffers stay valid and can be read with FETC? or FETC:ARR? at any time and speed.

The entire scope calculates in samples not time. The averaging allows to transfer samples to time at any time. The hPos is only allowed to be between 0 and 5000. The number of samples in post-trigger buffer always equals 10000 - hPos. The following example shows how to convert samples into time domain:

CONF:ARR:HWT 5,150

  • Scope sample period time: Avg = 5 -> 100 kHz / 5 = 20 kHz = 50 us
  • Time before trigger condition: hPos = 150 Samples -> 150 * 50 us = 7,5 ms
  • Total time in buffer: 10000 * 50 us = 500 ms
  • Time after trigger condition = 500 ms – 7.5 ms or (10000 – 150) * 50 us = 492.5 ms

Notes:

  • A trigger condition can be forced by command TRIGer:ARRay:FORCe in hardware triggered Scope mode
  • Scope mode is not available for Pyroelectric sensors or Photodiode sensors in Peak mode
  • Reading data in binary format by FETC:ARR? is much faster than the normal FETC? command
  • There are more flags in the STAT:OPER:COND? register showing the state of the scope buffer
  • For short scope measurements also the related convenience commands can be used: MEAS:ARR:HWT?, MEAS:ARR? or READ:ARR?

If you are using the faster binary FETC:ARR? command you will always receive up to 100 triplets at once. You can access the scope buffer in any order. Even if only a single channel is configured for scope you always read triplets. The unused channel is read as NAN. The binary triplet list response of FETC:ARR? has the following litle endian byte order:

The following code gives an example to parse the binary scope or burst data in Python:

inst.write('ACQ1:FAST:FETC?')
vals = inst.read_bytes(4)
length = struct.unpack('<I', bytearray(vals[0:0+4]))[0]
vals = inst.read_bytes(12 * length)
res = []
i = 0
while i < 12 * length:
   reltime = struct.unpack('<I', bytearray(vals[i:i+4]))[0]
   value1   = struct.unpack('<f', bytearray(vals[i+4:i+8]))[0]
   value2   = struct.unpack('<f', bytearray(vals[i+8:i+12]))[0]
   res.append([reltime, value1, value2])
   i += 12;

Burst Mode

The "Burst Mode" allows storing hardware triggerd measure results in an device internal buffer to be read out later. It uses the same memory than the "Scope Mode". It is only available for the CW mode for photodiode and thermopile. Pyroelectric and Four Quadrant Thermopile sensors are not supported by this measurement mode. Multiple internal or external trigger conditions start a measure burst sequence if not started already. The trigger repetition rate must be larger or equal 100 us. Normally either the front AUX or the rear trigger is used in input direction. The device memory allows storing up to 15000 samples. Every sequence is defined like this:

  • Optional initial delay ("Init Delay") before starting measurement burst
  • Averaged burst measurement 1
  • Optional averaged burst measurement 2
  • Optional averaged burst measurement 3
  • ...

The optional initial delay allows to postpone the burst sequence after the trigger condition in a 10 us time grid. If not required set to 0 to start sequence immediately. The sequence itself always contains at least one but less than 5000 averaged measurements. If the burst sequence stops the next trigger will issue an identical next burst sequence. If there is no more free memory in the device, data is discarded. An optional averaging enables the burst sequence to measure longer time periods with the same amount of stored samples. To store a single measure result with highest resolution for every trigger use Init Delay 0, Averaging 1 and a Burst Length of 1.

Before starting a burst measurement for optical power reading ensure:

  • Set manual range (Disables auto ranging of PM5020 automatically), command: SENSe#:POWer[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer]
  • When measuring pulsed or alternating signals, set full bandwidth for Photodiode sensors (no analog filter), command: INPut#[:PDIode]:FILTer[:LPASs][:STATe] 0
  • Choose CW mode for Photodiode sensors, command: SENSe#:FREQuency:MODE CW
  • Disable acceleration for thermopile sensors, command: INPut#:THERmopile:ACCelerator:AUTO 0
  • Set trigger threshold for internal hardware triggered signal, command: SENSe#:PEAKdetector (Not applicable for external triggering)

The burst mode is part of the MEAS SCPI command group. The basic command sequence looks like this:

  1. ABOR
    Abort any ongoing measurement
  2. CONF1:ARR:CHA
    Configure unit for channel 1. Skip if not connected or not needed
  3. CONF2:ARR:CHA
    Configure unit for channel 2. Skip if not connected or not needed
  4. CONF3:ARR:BUR 1,2,3
    Configure hardware front AUX triggered burst mode with initDelay = 1, BustCount = 2 and Averaging = 3.
  5. INIT
    Starts a burst measurement
  6. Trigger is active and burst sequences are stored in device buffer
  7. ABOR
    Stops burst measurement. Triggers are not longer observed
  8. FETC:ARR:LEN?
    Reads amount of samples in buffer
  9. FETC? 0
    Reads first sample of burst sequence
  10. FETC? 1
    Reads second sample of burst sequence
  11. ...

Once configured, a new burst measurement is taken with the following sequence:

  1. INIT
    Starts a burst measurement. Uses previous configuration
  2. Trigger is active and burst sequences are stored in device buffer
  3. ABOR
    Stops burst measurement. Triggers are not longer observed
  4. FETC:ARR:LEN?
    Reads amount of samples in buffer
  5. FETC? 0
    Reads first sample of burst sequence
  6. FETC? 1
    Reads second sample of burst sequence
  7. ...

The following diagram visualizes the mode in more detail. Time flows from left to right.

During configuration of Burst Mode all trigger conditions are ignored. After configuring the unit for the signle channels using for example CONF:ARR:CHAN you configure the Burst mode in general. The CONF3:ARR:BUR command suffix selects the trigger input. By default the frequency count threshold of channel 1 is used as internal trigger condition. In most cases it makes sense to use front AUX (3) or rear trigger (4) as trigger input. All external 3.3V triggers react on rising edges. The internal trigger of channel 1 or 2 fires when the signal becomes larger than the configured threshold (See command SENSe:PEAK). The CONF3:ARR:BUR parameters define the burst sequence to store after trigger condition. If you call INIT afterwards the trigger is armed and start a new burst measure sequence. The burst results are stored without any separator in the burst memory. Every burst measurement point is a triplet of relative sample time, value for channel 1 followed by value for channel 2. If no unit for channel is selected or sensor is not present the value will always read back as NAN. The example shows a burst configuration with an Init Delay of 2 (20 us) and a Burst Count of 3 with an Averaging of 2 (20 us).

In the given example the device will idle for 20 us once the trigger fired before starting to store 3 samples in a row with an averaging of 20 us. Any trigger during this time will be postponed to the end of the burst. In that case the next burst to starts directly after the previous. Ensure the trigger repetition rate is >= 100 us (10 kHz). As long there are rising edge trigger conditions and there are less than 15000 samples already stored the burst sequence the burst sequence gets restarted. Once the measurement is complete call ABOR to deactivate the burst mode. The previous results stay valid until next INIT. Use FETC:ARR:LEN? to get the amount of samples stored. Then query the results using FETC? or the faster but binary FETC:ARR? command multiple times. Calling any of these commands during ongoing measurement result in an error. You may call FETC:ARR:LEN? during measurement to see how many results are already stored.

The entire burst calculates in samples not time. The averaging allows to transfer samples to time at any time. The following example shows how to convert a parameter set of CONF:ARR:BUR 5, 2, 3 into time domain:

  • Init Delay time: InitDelay = 5, 10 us * 5 = 50 us
  • Averaging time: Averaging = 3, 10 us * 3 = 30 us
  • Burst sequence time: (InitDelay + SequcenceCount * Averaging) * 10 us = 110 us

Notes:

  • A trigger condition can be forced by command TRIGer:ARRay:FORCe in Burst mode
  • Burst mode is not available for Pyroelectric sensors or Photodiode sensors in Peak mode
  • Reading data in binary format by FETC:ARR? is much faster than the normal FETC? command

JSON Format

The powermeter allows to export and import all measurement related parameters in JSON format. To simplify JSON transport via SCPI, the JSON response does not contain any line breaks or other formats characters. The JSON strings are not designed to change the measurement parameters. The intention is to provide a simple store and load parameters functionality. It is possible to change the sensors within the sensor type family. For example a photodiode might be replaced by another photodidode. Importing the photodiode parameters for a thermopile sensor will cause an error. If the sensor is changed during export and import it might be necessary to adapt some parameters to fit the new sensor. For exammple the wavelength needs to be adjusted. This adaption is optional on request. For the import the JSON string needs to be split into multiple SCPI command calls as the maximal request length is limited. The JSON parts are buffered in the device. Once the entire string has been transmitted the power meter will parse the JSON and update the parameters. To clear the device internal buffer in any case use the magic char #.

To export measurement parameters as a single line JSON string use SYSTem:PARAmeter:EXPOrt:JSON?. The following example response has been manually formated to show the content.


         
      
To import JSON parameters the large JSON string needs to be split into multiple frames as the maximal SCPI request 
        length is limited to 200 characters. Use the magic char # to discard any previous content of the device internal 
        JSON input buffer. The powermeter counts the curly brackets to decide when the entire JSON string  has been written.
        It is best practice to check for errors after import to see if operation was successful. Use SYST:ERR? to query error queue.
        The following example shows how to import parameters in multiple SCPI command calls. To keep this demo simple the request
        length is even shorter than the allowed 200 characters what is also valid but less efficent. 
      

      
    
        
  1. SYSTem:PARAmeter:IMPOrt:JSON 1,  'randomContent'
    Generate some invalid JSON to show clear feature. Don't do this.
    2. 
        
  2. SYSTem:PARAmeter:IMPOrt:JSON 1, '#{“pm“:{“name“:“PM5020“,“serial“:“P00000001“,'
    Use magic char to clear nonsense and start writing JSON
    3. 
        
  3. SYSTem:PARAmeter:IMPOrt:JSON 1, '“calDate“:“Uncalibrated“,“adap0“:1,“adap1“:1},'
    Continue writing next JSON part
    4. 
        
  4. SYSTem:PARAmeter:IMPOrt:JSON 1, '“ntc0“:{“r0“:10000.00,“b“:3988.00},'
    Continue writing next JSON part
    5. 
        
  5. SYSTem:PARAmeter:IMPOrt:JSON 1, '“ntc1“:{“r0“:10000.00,“b“:3988.00},'
    Continue writing next JSON part
    6. 
        
  6. ...
    7. 
      

        
Details and Limitations

        
    
          
  1. Parameter adaption is performed for sensor parameters only. Powermeter parameters like NTC for example are not adapted.
    2. 
          
  2. It is allowed to import parameters of another PM5020. Is is not possible to import JSON parameters of another power meter.
    3. 
          
  3. If no sensor is currently connected no sensor parameters are imported. The sensor parameter json part will be ignored.
    4. 
          
  4. It is possible to import only single JSON objects like pm, ntc or sensor parameters by adapt the JSON. Within the given objects
              all parameters needs to be present.
    5. 
          
  5. As JSON does not define infinity or nan (Not a Number) as valid reals, these values are retruned as string.
    6. 
        

        
The following code gives an example to export and later inport the parameters using Python:

        

          #export the data

          importData = d.query(“SYST:PARA:EXPO:JSON?“)

          

          #Clear any pending data in buffer

          d.write(“SYST:PARA:IMPO:JSON 1, '#'“)

          #Program JSON string chucks

          for i in range(0, len(importData), 200):

            d.write(f“SYST:PARA:IMPO:JSON 1, '{importData[i : i + 200]}'“)

          

          #check for import error

          print(d.auto_query(“SYST:ERR?“))

        

      


    

    
SCPI Registers

      
The SCPI system defines a status reporting system based on status register sets. Every state or event is mapped to a single bit in the values of the register sets. 
      The PM5020 defines the following register sets: 

      
    
        
  • AUXilary: Auxiliary system monitoring like shutter or fan.
    • 
        
  • OPERation: Measurement state monitoring.
    • 
        
  • QUESTionalbe: Measure result reliability status monitoring.
    • 
        
  • STDandard Byte: SCPI global system status byte.
    • 
      


      
Every register set contains 5 registers.

      
    
        
  • CONDition: The Condition register monitors the actual state. For example if a sensor is currently connected or not.
    • 
        
  • PTRansition: The Positive Transition register masks bit changes from 0 to 1 of the Condition register to the Event register.
    • 
        
  • NTRansition: The Negative Transition register masks bit changes from 1 to 0 of the Condition register to the Event register.
    • 
        
  • EVENT: The Event register shows changes of the Condition register. Some conditions only last for a short moment and are otherwise hard to detect.
    • 
        
  • ENABle: The Enable register masks if changes of the Event registers (TODO JS registers plural?) are forwarded to a higher level hierarchy Condition register.
    • 
      

      
The following image visualizes the logical relation between the registers.

      
      
The Condition register always reflects the current state. For example if a sensor is connected or not. The Positive Transition register masks if a
      certain condition becomes true (bit changes from 0 to 1) to set the bit at the same position in the Event register. For example to set the Event register 
      bit to 1 if the sensor got connected. 
The Negative Transition register tests if condition becomes false to update the Event register. For example to 
      set event register bit to 1 if the sensor got disconnected. The Enable register masks if changes of the Event register should be reported to the 
      higher level hierarchy Condition register. The register sets are logically chained. The following section will provide further details about the chaining.

      
All registers except the STB register group are 16 bit wide. The following paragraph gives a short description of bit mask in general. Bit mask use the binary
      representation of numbers to store boolean states (true, false) or (active, inactive). This is a memory saving way to store multiple conditions at once.
      If you look on a decimal number 9 for example the binary representation is 1001 = 1 * 2 ^ 4 + 1 * 2 ^ 0. This bit mask means condition at bit position 1 and 4 are true. 
      All other conditions are false as all other bits are set to 0.

      To test if a certain bit is set to 1 you can either use bit logic operations or use generic mathematic operations. Bit logic operations are available in almost every 
      programming language. In Python you would write something like condition = bitmask & (1 << position).

      If you want to use standard math you can use the following formula: condition = round_down(bitmask / (2 ^ bitPos)) modulus 2.

      
The PM5020 features two light sensor measure channels. These are internally managed as two independent measurement devices. Every with a own QUEST and OPER register 
      set. To minimize the register amount there is only one AUX register even if there are for example two external NTC or fan channels.
 
      
The following section shows how the 3 OPEReration registers are chained and summarized.


      
      
The measure channel 1 reports to the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1 register set. The measure channel 
        2 uses the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM2 register set. Both channels do also set the status in the shared STAT:OPER
        register set. The ISUM1 and ISUM2 register might report events to the STAT:OPER:COND register if the 
        OPER:INST:ISUM1:ENAB or OPER:INST:ISUM2:ENAB registers are set and the masked events occur. The
        OPER:INST register set reports to the OPER:COND Condition register. The STAT:OPER register set might report
        to the SCPI Standard Byte register. This hierarchy enables you to check for a summarized condition
        only. If the highlevel condition becomes true you can than go down the hierarchy to query the details 
        causing the event. This enables you for example to check if both sensor heads are not overheated by
        reading OPER:INST:COND register. In case of an error you can than read the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM register
        to test what channel caused the error.


      
The three QUESTionable register sets use the identical hierarchy like the previous OPERation register sets.

      


      
The two AUXilary register sets hierarchy looks the following

      

    


    
Unfold all SCPI Commands

    

    
Unfold all None Commands

    

      

        CLSClears all SCPI event status registers
      

      

        
*CLS

        
Use this command to clear all event bits in the SCPI event status registers. After calling this command all event registers are read as 0 as long no new event changes bits back to 1. For closer details about event registers read for example description of command STAT:OPER?.

        
>> *CLS


      

    

    

      

        ESEPrograms the 8 bit wide Standard Event Enable Register
      

      

        
*ESE 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint standard even enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
>> ESE 2


      

    

    

      

        ESE?Reads the 8 bit wide Standard Event Enable Register
      

      

        
*ESE?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint standard even enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
>> ESE?
<< 0


      

    

    

      

        ESR?Reads and clears the Standard Event Register
      

      

        
*ESR?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint standard byte event register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
>> ESR?
<< 2


      

    

    

      

        IDN?Reads the device identification string
      

      

        
*IDN?

        
Response
    
          
  • manufstring Device manufacturer name.
    • 
          
  • devNamestring Device name.
    • 
          
  • serialstring Device serial number.
    • 
          
  • versionstring Firmware software number.
    • 
        


        
Call to query device identification string. 

        
>> *IDN?
<< Thorlabs,PM5020,T00000002,0.0.7.1


      

    

    

      

        LST?Lists supported SCPI commands
      

      

        
*LST? 
<subsyst>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • subsyst'',string nothing to list all cmds. SCPI subsystem string to filter results
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • liststring List of SCPI cmds. One command per line
    • 
        


        
 The command lists all SCPI commands matching the given filter condition. The filter condition can be any SCPI subsystem like for example "SYST". If no filter condition is set the command returns all supported commands. As the result list may be longer than the maximal SCPI response, the same command has to be called multiple times with the same parameter to retrieve all  commands. 

        
>> *LST?
<< "*IDN?"\\n"*RST"\\n

        
Result length is limited. So call multiple times with same parameters to retrieve all results.


      

    

    

      

        OPCSets the Operation Complete bit in the Standard Event Register
      

      

        
*OPC

        
>> OPC 2


      

    

    

      

        OPC?Operation complete query
      

      

        
*OPC?

        
Response
    
          
  • constantuint Always 1
    • 
        


        
Places a "1" into the output queue when all device operations have been completed No real functionality on this implementation. Result is always 1. 

        
>> OPC?
<< 1


      

    

    

      

        RSTResets all SCPI and sensor parameters to default
      

      

        
*RST

        
 The command resets all SCPI parameters like serial baudrate and sensor parameters  like wavelength to defaults. Both sensor channels are reset to defaults. To reset  a single measure channel use SENS#:RST. To reset the SCPI registers use  CLS. 

        
>> RST


      

    

    

      

        SREService request enable command
      

      

        
*SRE 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint new service request enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Programs the Service Request Enable Register

        
>> SRE 2


      

    

    

      

        SRE?Service request enable query
      

      

        
*SRE?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint service request enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Reads the Service Request Enable Register

        
>> SRE?
<< 0


      

    

    

      

        STB?Status byte query
      

      

        
*STB?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint status byte condition register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Reads the Status Byte Register

        
>> STB?
<< 20


      

    

    

      

        TST?Self-test query
      

      

        
*TST?

        
Response
    
          
  • constuint Always 0.
    • 
        


        
No function always returns 0.

        
>> TST?
<< 0


      

    

    

      

        WAIWait-to-continue command
      

      

        
*WAI

        
Wait until all previous commands are executed. Empty implementation.

        
>> WAI


      

    

    

    
Unfold all ACQ Commands

    

      

        ACQ:FAST:MAXS?Returns fast measure sample rate in Hz
      

      

        
ACQuire:FAST[:ARRay]:MAXSamplerate?

        
Response
    
          
  • samplereateuint32 maximal sample rate in Hz of Powermeter fast measure system. Always 100kHz
    • 
        


        
>> ACQ:FAST:MAXS?
<< 100000


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FASTConfigures the measurement stream for power measure in Watt
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST[:ARRay][:POWer]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
 Call this command to configure the fast measurement stream for power measurement in W for photodiodes and thermopile sensors. Measurements in dBm are not supported. If the sensor does not support power measurement, the command enqueues an error. Changing the fast measure unit resets the measurement stream automatically see ACQ#:FAST:RESET as the buffer would contain measure results for another unit. The maximal sample rate here is 100kHz see ACQ:FAST:MAXS?.
 For thermopile or photodiode in CW mode the fast measurement stream gets updated by Powermeter at 1kHz with 100 measure results of recent ms. The acceleration feature INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO is not available for fast measurement stream. Four quadrant thermopile sensors are not supporting fast measurement stream. Normally it makes sense to use fast measurement stream with high bandwidth INP#:FILT.
 If photodiode is configured for PEAK mode, the stream output depends on the repetition rate of the modulated input signal but must not reach 95 kHz. If the modulation frequency is higher you will lose peak measure results. 
 For closer details about this measurement mode read Stream section.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:POW

        
Photodiode and thermopile only! After sending this command it is quite likely that calling ACQ#:FAST:FETC? ends up in a empty result as no data has been enqueued yet.


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FAST:CURRConfigures the measurement stream for current measurement
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST[:ARRay]:CURRent[:DC]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
 Call this command to configure the fast measurement stream for current measurement in Ampere for photodiode sensors. If the sensor does not support current measurement, the command enqueues an error. Changing the fast measure unit resets the measurement stream automatically see ACQ#:FAST:RESET as the buffer would contain measure results for another unit. The maximal sample rate here is 100kHz see ACQ:FAST:MAXS?. If photodiode is configured in CW mode the fast measurement stream will constantly stream output. Normally it makes sense to use fast measurement stream with high bandwidth INP#:FILT. If it is configured for PEAK mode the stream output depends on the repetition rate of the modulated input signal but must not reach 95 kHz. If the modulation frequency is higher you will lose peak measure results. The stream gets updated by Powermeter at 1kHz with up to 100 measure results of recent ms.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read Stream section.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:CURR

        
Photodiode only! After sending this command it is quite likely that calling ACQ#:FAST:FETC? ends up in a empty result as no data has been enqueued yet.


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FAST:EDENConfigures the measurement stream for energy density measurement in Joule per square cm
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST[:ARRay]:EDENsity

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
 Call this command to configure the fast measurement stream for energy density measurement in J/cm^2 for pyro sensors. Ensure you select the correct beam size by using command SENS#:CORR:BEAM.If the sensor does not support energy density measurement, the command enqueues an error. Changing the fast measure unit resets the measurement stream automatically see ACQ#:FAST:RESET as the buffer would contain measure results for another unit. Pyro sensors are measured in PEAK mode. The result stream will only contain time and level of the Pyro peaks. The amount of peaks depend on the input pulsed light signal. The stream gets updated by Powermeter at 1kHz with up to 100 measure results of recent ms.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read Stream section.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:EDEN

        
Pyro only! After sending this command it is quite likely that calling ACQ#:FAST:FETC? ends up in a empty result as no data has been enqueued yet.


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FAST:ENERConfigures the measurement stream for energy measurement in Joule
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST[:ARRay]:ENERgy

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
 Call this command to configure the fast measurement stream for energy measurement in J for pyro sensors. If the sensor does not support energy measurement, the command enqueues an error. Changing the fast measure unit resets the measurement stream automatically see ACQ#:FAST:RESET as the buffer would contain measure results for another unit. Pyro sensors are measured in PEAK mode. The result stream will only contain time and level of the pyro peaks. The amount of peaks depend on the input pulsed light signal. The Powermeter supports a rep rate up to 95 kHz. If the modulation frequency is higher you will lose peak measure results. The stream gets updated by Powermeter at 1kHz with up to 100 measure results of recent ms.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read Stream section.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:ENER

        
Pyro only! After sending this command it is quite likely that calling ACQ#:FAST:FETC? ends up in a empty result as no data has been enqueued yet.


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FAST:FETC?Polls the oldest fast measurement stream results
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST[:ARRay]:FETCh?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary Four bytes binary amount of binary tuples following.
    • 
          
  • tuplesbinary list of binary tuples. Four bytes relative time in microseconds. Four bytes IEEE float with value.
    • 
        


        
 The command polls the oldest measure results out of the fast measurement stream. The device internally buffers all recent 10 ms samples in a queue. The unit depends on the previously selected unit. See ACQ#:FAST for example. If there are currently no measure results the response length will be 0 without any binary data following.  The Powermeter updates the queue at 1kHz. For Pyro and Photodiode in Peak mode the update rate of the stream depends on the modulated input frequency. The modulation frequency must not reach 95kHz. In general ensure to  call the method as fast as possible to prevent data loss. Any delay longer than 10 ms will result in a loss of stream samples. Because of this always check the relative timestamp in the result list and use an XY plot to ensure gaps in data are considered. Setting a prescaler SENS#:AVER does not affect the fast measurement stream update rate. When calculating the time delta between the samples ensure to  handle wrapp around of relative microsecond counter.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:FETC?
<< uint32_t count uint32_t relTime0 float measure0 uint32_t relTime1 float measure1 ... int32_t relTime99 float measure99

        
Binary data can contain all values including 0 and \n. Poll as fast as possible. Check timestamp to see if samples are lost.


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FAST:PDENConfigures the measurement stream for power density measurement in Watt per square cm
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST[:ARRay]:PDENsity

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
 Call this command to configure the fast measurement stream for power measurement in in W/cm^2 for photodiodes and thermopile sensors. Ensure you select the correct beam size by using command SENS#:CORR:BEAM. If the sensor does not support power density measurement, the command enqueues an error. Changing the fast measure unit resets the measurement stream automatically see ACQ#:FAST:RESET as the buffer would contain measure results for another unit. The maximal sample rate here is 100kHz see ACQ:FAST:MAXS?.
  For thermopile or photodiode in CW mode the fast measurement stream gets updated by Powermeter at 1kHz with 100 measure results of recent ms. The acceleration feature INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO is not available for fast measurement stream. Four quadrant thermopile sensors are not supporting fast measurement stream. Normally it makes sense to use fast measurement stream with high bandwidth INP#:FILT.
 If photodiode is configured for PEAK mode, the stream output depends on the repetition rate of the modulated input signal but must not reach 95 kHz. If the modulation frequency is higher you will lose peak measure results.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read Stream section.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:PDEN

        
Photodiode and thermopile only! After sending this command it is quite likely that calling ACQ#:FAST:FETC? ends up in a empty result as no data has been enqueued yet.


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FAST:RESETDisposes the content of the buffered fast measurement stream
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST:RESET

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
 Call this command initially once before starting a new measurement stream for the currently configured unit to ensure to measure only data following the start condition. When unit gets changed reset is performed internally already.  For closer details about this measurement mode read Stream section.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:RESET

        
After sending this command it is quite likely that calling ACQ#:FAST:FETC? ends up in a empty result as no data has been enqueued yet.


      

    

    

      

        ACQ#:FAST:VOLTConfigures the measurement stream for voltage measurement
      

      

        
ACQuire
#
:FAST[:ARRay]:VOLTage

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
 Call this command to configure the fast measurement stream for voltage measurement in Volt for pyro and thermopile sensors. If the sensor does not support voltage measurement, the command enqueues an error. Changing the fast measure unit resets the measurement stream automatically see ACQ#:FAST:RESET as the buffer would contain measure results for another unit.
 Pyro sensors are measured in PEAK mode. The result stream will only contain time and level of the pyro peaks. The amount of peaks depend on the input pulsed light signal. The Powermeter supports a rep rate up to 95 kHz. If the modulation frequency is higher you will lose peak measure results.
 Thermopile sensors are measured in CW mode. In this mode the stream gets updated by Powermeter at 1kHz with 100 measure results of recent ms. The acceleration feature INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO is not available for fast measurement stream. Four quadrant thermopile sensors are not supporting fast measurement stream.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read Stream section.

        
>> ACQ:FAST:VOLT

        
Pyro and thermopile only! After sending this command it is quite likely that calling ACQ#:FAST:FETC? ends up in a empty result as no data has been enqueued yet.


      

    

    

    
Unfold all CAL Commands

    

      

        CAL#:STR?Queries factory calibration string
      

      

        
CALibration
#
:STRing?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • datestring Cal string with format dd-MonthStr-YYYY or 'Uncalibrated' when not calibrated.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the factory calibration date string of the sensor measure frontend.

        
>> CAL:STR?
<< "18-Feb-2022"


      

    

    

    
Unfold all CON Commands

    

      

        CON:FAN#:ENAB?Tests if fan should spinning or not
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:ENABle?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool true if fan should be spinning. False if fan should be off.
    • 
        


        
 This query tests if the fan should be spinning or not. It does not check if the fan is spinning in reality. If no fan is connected or fan is blocked the result might be wrong. To test if fan is running you might want to check the Auxiliary register STAT:AUX:COND? fan running flag bit 6 and 7.

        
>> CON:FAN2:ENAB?
<< 0


      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:MODESets fan controller operating mode
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:MODE 
<mode>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • modespecial fan controller mode. See list in detail section.
    • 
        


        
 This command will change the operating mode of the fan controller. Changing the operating mode will automatically use the previously defined parameters for the selected mode. Only the CTRL mode is stored persistently. If another mode is selected, the default after reboot will be mode OFF. The following modes are defined 
     
  • OFF fan will be switched off regardless of previous mode
    •  
  • FULL fan will running at full speed 12V output.
    •  
  • OPEN open loop mode for fans with or without tacho signal. Use CON:FAN#:VOLT to change the output voltage.
    •  
  • CLOSED closed loop mode for fans with tacho signal. Use CON:FAN#:RPM to change the fan speed.
    •  
  • TEMPER temperature control mode. Fan speed is controlled by measured temperature automatically. Use CON:FAN#:TEMP:VOLT:ADJ and CON:FAN#:TEMP:SOUR? to change parameters for this mode.
    •  

        
>> CON:FAN2:MODE CLOSED


      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:MODE?Queries fan controller operating mode
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:MODE?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • modespecial fan controller operating mode.
    • 
        


        
This query returns the current operating mode of fan controller. For closer details about the modes read CON:FAN#:MODE.

        
>> CON:FAN2:MODE?
<< OPEN


      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:RPMSets fan controller round per minute set points for closed loop mode
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:RPM 
<maxRPM>
, 
<RPM>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • maxRPMuint maximal supported RPM of fan
    • 
              
  • RPMuint control fan speed set point in RPM
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to update the fan closed loop speed parameters. If fan controller is currently configured for another mode this function simply updates the parameters. If the fan controller is configured for closed loop mode the function updates the parameters and changes the fan speed set point simultaneously. To change the operating mode use CON:FAN#:MODE. This mode is only possible to operate 12V fans. To calculate the internal RPM count registers it is mandatory to set the maximal  expected speed out of fan. The implemented fan speed control is  reacting slowly.

        
>> CON:FAN:RPM 10000, 2000

        
Only available for 12V fans with 3 wire tacho signal.

        
Control of fan speed is slow and can take several seconds.

      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:RPM?Queries fan controller closed loop mode parameters
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:RPM?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • maxRPMuint maximal expected RPM of fan.
    • 
          
  • RPMuint control set point of fan in RPM.
    • 
        


        
 Use this query to read the closed loop fan speed set parameters.  To read the actual measured RPM use command CON:FAN#:RPM:DATA?. For closer details about closed loop mode read CON:FAN#:RPM.

        
>> CON:FAN2:RPM?
<< 8000, 1000

        
Only available for 12V fans with 3 wire tacho signal.

        
Control of fan speed is slow and can take several seconds.

      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:RPM:DATA?Queries currently measured rounds per minute in closed loop mode
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:RPM:DATA?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • RPMuint currently measured RPM
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to get the measured actual fan speed in round per minute. This commands is only valid if PM5020 fan controller has been configured in closed loop mode previously by calling command CON:FAN#:MODE.

        
>> CON:FAN:RPM:DATA?
<< 5340

        
Only available for 12V fans with 3 wire tacho signal.

        
Control of fan speed is slow and can take several seconds.

      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:TEMP:SOURSets fan temperature control source
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:TEMP:SOURce 
<source>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • sourcespecial HEAD for sensor head temperature or NTC for external NTC
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to change the temperature measure source for fan speed control. Temperature source is stored persistently and automatically recovered after reboot. Changing temperature source is valid at any time. For closer details about automatic fan speed control of Powermeter read CON:FAN#:TEMP:VOLT:ADJ. To change the fan operating mode use CON:FAN#:MODE.

        
>> CON:FAN1:TEMP:SOUR NTC


      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:TEMP:SOUR?Gets fan temperature control source
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:TEMP:SOURce?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • sourcespecial HEAD for sensor head temperature or NTC for external NTC
    • 
        


        
 Queries currently used temperature measure source for fan speed control. For closer details about automatic fan speed control of Powermeter  read CON:FAN#:TEMP:VOLT:ADJ. To change the fan operating mode use CON:FAN#:MODE.

        
>> CON:FAN1:TEMP:SOUR NTC


      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:TEMP:VOLT:ADJSets temperature based fan speed control adjustment points
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:TEMP:VOLT:ADJust 
<minV>
,
<maxV>
,
<minTemp>
,
<maxTemp>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • minVfloat minimal voltage where fan starts spinning
    • 
              
  • maxVfloat maximal voltage where fan runs at full speed
    • 
              
  • minTempfloat temperature in degree Celsius where fan should start spinning
    • 
              
  • maxTempfloat temperature in degree Celsius where fan should reach full speed
    • 
        


        
 This command sets the temperature fan voltage adjustment points used by Powermeter to control the fan speed based on temperature measurement. This function will simply update the adjustment points.  If fan controller operates in control mode the new parameters are used immediately. Use command CON:FAN#:MODE to change the operating mode and  CON:FAN#:TEMP:SOUR? to select the temperature measure source.  The fan speed control is updated at 2 Hz and implements a 3% hysteresis when head or external NTC is chilling. Between the given points a logarithmic  curve is fitted to calculate fan speed at measured temperature. The control parameters are stored persistently and are used at restart automatically.

        
>> CON:FAN2:TEMP:VOLT:ADJ 2.2,12,35,50

        
The control uses 3 Kelvin hysteresis before disabling fan again.


      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:TEMP:VOLT:ADJ?Queries temperature based fan speed control adjustment points
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:TEMP:VOLT:ADJust?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • minVfloat minimal voltage where fan starts spinning
    • 
          
  • maxVfloat maximal voltage where fan runs at full speed
    • 
          
  • minTempfloat temperature in degree Celsius where fan should start spinning
    • 
          
  • maxTempfloat temperature in degree Celsius where fan should reach full speed
    • 
        


        
 This command reads back the automatically fan speed control adjustment parameters.  For closer details read command CON:FAN#:TEMP:VOLT:ADJ documentation. 

        
>> CON:FAN2:TEMP:VOLT:ADJ?
<< 2.2,12,35,50


      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:VOLTSets fix voltage to fan for open loop mode
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:VOLTage 
<voltage>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • voltagefloat output voltage for fan
    • 
        


        
 Calling this command sets the fix voltage parameter for fan open loop operating mode. In open mode the fan speed is not controlled. The fan controller simply outputs a  fixed voltage. This modus allows to operate 12V or 5V fans. If another operating mode is selected this function simply sets  voltage parameter. If open loop mode is currently selected the function will set  the parameter and update the fan controller output voltage simultaneously. To change  operating mode use CON:FAN#:MODE.

        
>> CON:FAN:VOLT 4.3

        
Outputing more than 5V for a 5V fan can cause damage.

        
If the given voltage is to low the fan might not start spinning.

      

    

    

      

        CON:FAN#:VOLT?Queries voltage output of fan
      

      

        
CONtrol:FAN
#
:VOLTage?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Fan channel number 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • voltagefloat fan output voltage
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to read back the output voltage of fan. For closer details about open loop mode read CON:FAN#:VOLT.

        
>> CON:FAN:VOLT?
<< 5.3


      

    

    

      

        CON:I2C:MODESelects I2C operating speed and mode
      

      

        
CONtrol:I2C:MODE 
<mode>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • modeINTER,SLOW,FAST new I2C operating mode and speed. See list in detail section.
    • 
        


        
 This setter changes the I2C speed and operating mode. By dafault I2C is controlled by the powermeter and SCPI I2C commands are disabled. It is mandatory to select a manual mode before SCPI  I2C commands are enabled. The configuraiton is not stored for next boot. Be aware in manual mode the optional external environmental sensor will not longer be queried by the powermeter. The following modes are supported 
     
  • INTER: I2C controlled by powermeter. SCPI I2C disabled.  
  • SLOW: I2C controlled by SCPI commands in 100k standard speed. Powermeter does not access bus. 
  • FAST: I2C controlled by SCPI commands in 400k fast speed. Powermeter does not access bus. 
      

        
>> CON:I2C:MODE SLOW


      

    

    

      

        CON:I2C:MODE?Queries I2C operating speed and mode
      

      

        
CONtrol:I2C:MODE?

        
Response
    
          
  • modeINTER,SLOW,FAST I2C operating mode and speed
    • 
        


        
 The command queries the I2C speed and operating mode.  For closer details read CON:I2C:MODE.

        
>> CON:I2C:MODE?
<< SLOW


      

    

    

      

        CON:I2C#:READ?Reads data on I2C bus from given slave address
      

      

        
CONtrol:I2C
#
:READ? 
<count>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint I2C slave address. Address are bit 7 to bit 1. Bit 0 is ignored.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • countuint amount of bytes to read from address. Needs to be less than 128.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • hexStrstring received data as hexadecimal string without byte separator. Length always multiple of 2.
    • 
        


        
 The command receives data from slave with given address. The function requires CON:I2C:MODE to be called once previously. The command returns data as hexadecimal string without quotes. The length is always a multiple of two as two hex digits encode a single byte. The maximal length are 128 Bytes. Data is read synchronously with the SCPI command. To prevent long read timeouts when reading data from an non responding slave the command does not enqueue a SCPI error. Instead it will return a magic response NO DATA.

        
>> CON:I2C128:READ? 2
<< 024B

        
Special error handling! Read detail section carefully.


      

    

    

      

        CON:I2C#:WRITSends data on I2C bus to given slave address
      

      

        
CONtrol:I2C
#
:WRITe 
<hexStr>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint I2C slave address. Address are bit 7 to bit 1. Bit 0 is ignored.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • hexStrstring transmission data as hexadecimal string without byte separator. Length always multiple of 2.
    • 
        


        
 The command transmits given data to slave with given address. The function requires CON:I2C:MODE to be called once previously. The transmission data is given as hexadecimal string parameter. The length needs to be a multiple of two as two hex digits encode a single byte. Leading zeros are mandatory. So to transfer byte 2 and 75 use string 024B. Hex digits are support upper or lowercase letters. The maximal length are 128 Bytes. Data is transferred synchronously with the SCPI command. If there is no slave responding for given address the command will terminate and a SCPI error is enqueued. If you want to read after writing some data you may use the command CON:I2C#:WRRE?.

        
>> CON:I2C128:WRIT 02


      

    

    

      

        CON:I2C#:WRRE?Transmits and reads data sequentially on I2C bus from given slave address
      

      

        
CONtrol:I2C
#
:WRRE? 
<hexStr>
,
<count>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint I2C slave address. Address are bit 7 to bit 1. Bit 0 is ignored.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • hexStrstring transmission data as hexadecimal string without byte separator. Length always multiple of 2.
    • 
              
  • countuint amount of bytes to read from address.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • hexStrstring received data as hexadecimal string without byte separator. Length always multiple of 2.
    • 
        


        
 The command transmits given data to slave with given address following a bus reception from same device if transmission was successful. This command is a convenience function for a CON:I2C#:WRIT followed by a CON:I2C#:READ? command sequence. If transmission failed an SCPI error is enqueued and no data is read. To prevent long read timeouts when reading data from an non responding slave the command does not enqueue a SCPI error. Instead it will return a magic response NO DATA. The maximal transmission and reception byte count is 128. For closer details of hexString format read CON:I2C#:WRIT command description.

        
>> CON:I2C128:WRRE? 02,2
<< 1000

        
Special error handling! Read detail section carefully.


      

    

    

      

        CON:SHUTOpen or closes shutter position
      

      

        
CONtrol:SHUTer 
<state>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • statebool 1 to open shutter. 0 to close.
    • 
        


        
 This command sets the shutter set state. If the interlock is closed this command results in an change of the shutter state. If the interlock is open the command only changes the set value without a mechanically effect. If the interlock is plugged in later the shutter will open then. It is not possible to read back the set value. To read the actual state call CON:SHUT? to check if the interlock is set call  CON:SHUT:INT?.

        
>> CON:SHUT 1

        
Ensure interlock is closed by using CON:SHUT:INT?


      

    

    

      

        CON:SHUT?Returns actual shutter position
      

      

        
CONtrol:SHUTer?

        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if open, 0 if closed
    • 
        


        
 This command checks if the shutter is currently open or closed. The shutter state is monitored by a internal light barrier. So even if it is mechanically blocked this command returns the  real state. The actual shutter state is also masked in the SCPI Auxiliary Detail register bit 11. For closer details read STAT:AUX:DET:COND?.

        
>> CON:SHUT?
<< 0

        
Interlock and shutter set state are logically combined by an AND gate

      

    

    

      

        CON:SHUT:CON?Tests if shutter is connected or not.
      

      

        
CONtrol:SHUTer:CONnected?

        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if connected, 0 otherwise
    • 
        


        
 This command checks if shutter is connected or not. The interlock state is also masked in the SCPI Auxiliary Detail register bit 12. For closer details read STAT:AUX:DET:COND?.

        
>> CON:SHUT:CON?
<< 1

        
Interlock and shutter set state are logically combined by an AND gate

      

    

    

      

        CON:SHUT:INT?Returns shutter interlock state
      

      

        
CONtrol:SHUTer:INTerlock?

        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if closed, 0 if open
    • 
        


        
 This command checks if the interlock is closed or not. Only with an plugged in interlock the shutter can be opened. If the interlock is removed the shutter will close immediately. The interlock state is also masked in the SCPI Auxiliary Detail register bit 10. For closer details read STAT:AUX:DET:COND?.

        
>> CON:SHUT:INT?
<< 1

        
Interlock and shutter set state are logically combined by an AND gate

      

    

    

    
Unfold all DISP Commands

    

      

        DISP:BRIGSets display brightness in percent
      

      

        
DISPlay:BRIGhtness 
<brightness>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • brightnessfloat brightness in percent between 0 and 1
    • 
        


        
>> DISP:BRIG 0.5

        
Only 31 different brightness levels are supported.

      

    

    

      

        DISP:BRIG?Queries display brightness in percent
      

      

        
DISPlay:BRIGhtness?

        
Response
    
          
  • brightnessfloat Brightness in percent between 0 and 1
    • 
        


        
>> DISP:BRIG?
<< 0.91

        
Only 31 different brightness levels are supported.

      

    

    

    
Unfold all INP Commands

    

      

        INP#:ADAPSets the default adapter sensor type
      

      

        
INPut
#
:ADAPter[:TYPE] 
<type>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • typespecial Configure adapter type. See list in description.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the default adapter sensor type. Adapters are sensors without a head EEPROM. if currently no sensor is connected this function will change the default adapter sensor type.  If an adapter is currently connected the function will re-enumerate the new adapter type on the Powermeter. Adapter type is stored persistently and will be reused after reboot automatically. The following adapter types are defined: 
     
  • PHOTodiode Photodiode sensor adapter
    •  
  • THERmal Thermopile sensor adapter
    •  
  • PYRo Pyroelectric sensor adapter
    •  
  • PDA Preamplified photodiode adapter
    •  
  • Q4 Four Quadrant Thermopile sensor adapter
    •  
  • LUMinance Photometric sensor adapter
    •  

        
>> INP2:ADAP PYR


      

    

    

      

        INP#:ADAP?Queries the default adapter sensor type
      

      

        
INPut
#
:ADAPter[:TYPE]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • typespecial Currently configured adapter type. For list read INP#:ADAP.
    • 
        


        
Use this command read the adapter sensor type. Adapters are sensors without a head EEPROM. You can use this command also if no adapter is currently connected. For closer details about adapter type read INP#:ADAP.

        
>> INP2:ADAP?
<< PYR


      

    

    

      

        INP#:FILTEnables/Disables bandwidth limitation
      

      

        
INPut
#
[:PDIode]:FILTer[:LPASs][:STATe] 
<enable>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool True to limit bandwidth. False for full bandwidth.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable or disable the bandwidth limitation of the sensor signal amplifier. This command is useful for CW signals to suppress noise.  For modulated signals ensure bandwidth is set to high. 

        
>> INP1:FILT 0

        
When active bandwidth is limited to approximately 3 Hz.

      

    

    

      

        INP#:FILT?Queries the default adapter sensor type
      

      

        
INPut
#
[:PDIode]:FILTer[:LPASs][:STATe]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool True if bandwidth limited. False when full bandwidth.
    • 
        


        
Use this command read the adapter sensor type. Adapters are sensors without a head EEPROM. You can use this command also if no adapter is currently connected. For closer details about adapter type read INP#:ADAP.

        
>> INP2:FILT?
<< 1


      

    

    

      

        INP#:THER:ACC:AUTOEnables/Disables thermopile prediction
      

      

        
INPut
#
:THERmopile:ACCelerator:AUTO 
<enable>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool true to enable thermopile prediction. False to disable.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable or disable the thermopile sensor value prediction algorithm. Thermopile sensors are relatively slow when light intensity changes fast. The prediction algorithm automatically calculates the resulting power during the sensor signal follows a logarithmic function during positive jump and a 1/e function during negative jump. The sensor behaves like a capacitor. In both cases after the time period of 5 Tau the signal reached 99% of the final level and prediction is stopped automatically. Tau is a sensor specific constant and is stored in the head EEPROM. For adapter sensors Tau can be changed using the function INP#:THER:ACC:TAU. To test if prediction is currently active check for the for accelerator flag bit 10 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND?. 

        
>> INP2:THER:ACC:AUTO 1

        
Thermopile only!


      

    

    

      

        INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO?Queries if thermopile prediction is enabled or disabled
      

      

        
INPut
#
:THERmopile:ACCelerator:AUTO?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool true if thermopile prediction is enabled. False when disabled.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if thermopile sensor value prediction algorithm is enabled or disabled. It does not test if the algorithm is active at the moment. To test if prediction is currently active check for the for accelerator flag bit 10 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND?. For closer details about thermopile prediction in general read INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO description. \~cmdResult: 1

        
>> INP2:THER:ACC:AUTO?

        
Thermopile only!


      

    

    

      

        INP#:THER:ACC:TAUSets thermopile sensor adapter specific time constant Tau
      

      

        
INPut
#
:THERmopile:ACCelerator:TAU 
<tau>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • taufloat,MIN,MAX,DEF new time constant Tau in Seconds. Or predefined special value.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the time constant Tau for thermopile adapter sensors. For sensors with EEPROM this function is forbidden. The time constant is stored in the EEPROM already. use INP#:THER:ACC:TAU? to read the value. When working with adapters ensure the correct adapter type is selected by using INP#:ADAP.

        
>> INP1:THER:ACC:TAU 1.2

        
Thermopile adapters only!


      

    

    

      

        INP#:THER:ACC:TAU?Queries thermopile sensor specific time constant Tau
      

      

        
INPut
#
:THERmopile:ACCelerator:TAU? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! nothing to query actual value. Special to query predefined value.
    • 
        


        
Response
