  • taufloat sensor time constant tau in Seconds.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the thermopile specific time constant Tau. For sensor heads without EEPROM alias adapters you can change the constant by using INP#:THER:ACC:TAU. For all other sensors this function returns the time constant out of the head EEPROM.

        
>> INP1:THER:ACC:TAU?
<< 1.2

        
Thermopile only!


      

    

    

      

        INP#:THER:INTE:ENABEnables/Disables thermopile pulse energy measurement mode
      

      

        
INPut
#
:THERmopile:INTEgrator:ENABle 
<enable>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool true to enable thermopile integration. False to disable.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable or disable the thermopile  pulse energy measurment. This mode may be used for single thermopile pulses with a slow rep rate to measure the resulting energy in Joule. The algorithm integrates the power measurement for 8 * Tau. Tau is a sensor specific time constant and is stored in the head EEPROM. For adapter sensors Tau can be changed using the function INP#:THER:ACC:TAU. To test if integration is currently active, check for the for integrator flag bit 12 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND?. Enabling the Thermopile integration will automatically disable Thermopile prediction INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO. Do not use autoranging for this measure mode. Select a fitting measure range manually first. \info Ensure you selected a proper measure range to cover complete peak previously. Do not use autoranging.

        
>> INP2:THER:INTE:ENAB 1

        
Thermopile only! Ensure pulse rep rate is smaller 10 * Sensor Tau Seconds.


      

    

    

      

        INP#:THER:INTE:ENAB?Queries if thermopile pulse energy measurement mode is enabled or disabled
      

      

        
INPut
#
:THERmopile:INTEgrator:ENABle?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool true if thermopile integration is enabled. False when disabled.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if thermopile sensor pulse energy measurement is enabled or disabled. It does not test if the algorithm is active at the moment. To test if integration is currently active check for the for integration flag bit 12 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND?. For closer details about thermopile integration in general read INP#:THER:INTE:ENAB description. \~cmdResult: 1

        
>> INP2:THER:INTE:ENAB?

        
Thermopile only!


      

    

    

    
Unfold all MEAS Commands

    

      

        ABOR#Aborts any previously started measurement
      

      

        
ABORt
#

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to abort any previously started measurement.

        
>> ABOR

        
Do not send ABOR in case of READ#? or MEAS#? timeout within 10 seconds. Otherwise Communication will crash totally.

        
Abort is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR, CONF#, INIT#, FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        CONF:ARRConfigures software trigger scope mode.
      

      

        
CONFigure:ARRay[:SWTrig] 
<avg>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
        


        
Use this command after configuring the single channels by command CONF#:ARR:CHA, CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURR or CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT to configure the measure system for scope software triggered measurement. The configuration is only required once. Afterwards you control the measure system by using ABOR#, INIT# and FETC:ARR? finally. 
 There is also the READ:ARR? convenience command for these three SCPI commands. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. It is also possible to configure a hardware triggered scope measurement by using CONF#:ARR:HWT. For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> CONF:ARR 2


      

    

    

      

        CONF:SIMUConfigures SCPI measure system for simulantious two channel power measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure:SIMUltaneous[:POWer]

        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for photodiode, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile simulantious two channel power measurement in Watt or dBm for. The unit depends on the power unit configuration set by SENS#:POW:UNIT command. This command only prepares the measurement and requires two connected current sensors in CW measurement mode.  Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF:SIMU, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The averaging of the configured measurement  might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1.
 You can also configure a single channel power measurement using the command CONF#.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:SIMU

        
Photodiode, Thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only! Only CW measure mode supported. Requires two connected power sensors.

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF:SIMU:CURRConfigures SCPI measure system for simulantious two channel current measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure:SIMUltaneous:CURRent[:DC]

        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for photodiode two channel simulantious current measurement in Ampere. This command prepares the measurement only and requires two connected current sensors in CW measurement mode.  Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF:SIMU:CURR, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The averaging of the configured measurement might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1.
 You can also configure a single channel current measurement using the command CONF#:CURR.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:SIMU:CURR

        
Photodiode only! Only CW measure mode supported. Only CW measure mode supported. Requires two connected current sensors.

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF:SIMU:PDENConfigures SCPI measure system for simulantious two channel power density measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure:SIMUltaneous:PDENsity

        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for photodiode, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile simulantious two channel simulantious power density measurement in W / cm^2.  This command prepares the simulantious measurement only and requires two connected power sensors in CW mode. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF:SIMU:PDEN, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.  The averaging of the configured measurement might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1.
  To change the density reference beam size use SENS#:CORR:BEAM command. For four quadrant thermopile sensors this command configures measurement system for total power density.
 You can also configure a single channel power density measurement  using the command CONF#:PDEN.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:SIMU:PDEN

        
Photodiode, Thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only! Only CW measure mode supported. Requires two connected power sensors.

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF:SIMU:VOLTConfigures SCPI measure system for simulantious two channel voltage measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure:SIMUltaneous:VOLTage[:DC]

        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for thermopile or four quadrant two channel simulantious voltage measurement in Volt. This command prepares the measurement only and requires two connected voltage sensors.  Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, configSim. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF:SIMU:VOLT, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The averaging of the configured measurement might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1.
  For thermopile sensors and four quadrant thermopile sensors auto ranging is supported by command SENS#:VOLT:RANG:AUTO. For thermopile sensors only you might also enable the thermopile prediction previously by using INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO.
 For four quadrant thermopile sensors this command configures measurement system for total voltage. For the single channel quadrant voltages use CONF#:Q4V instead.
 You can also configure a single channel voltage measurement using the command CONF#:VOLT.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:SIMU:VOLT

        
Thermopile or four quadrant thermopile only! Requires two connected voltage sensors.

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#Configures SCPI measure system for power measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar][:POWer]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for photodiode, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile power measurement in Watt or dBm for. The unit depends on the power unit configuration set by SENS#:POW:UNIT command. This command only prepares the measurement. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.
 You can also configure a simultaneous power measurement for both channels using CONF:SIMU.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF

        
Photodiode, Thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#?Returns the actual configured unit for measurement system
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • confstring abbreviation of configuration in upper case letters
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the actual configuration of the SCPI measure system. The following configurations are returned: 
     
  • POW for power measurements. See CONF#
    •  
  • CURR for current measurements. See CONF#:CURR
    •  
  • VOLT for power measurements. See CONF#:VOLT
    •  
  • ENER for energy measurements. See CONF#:ENER
    •  
  • POWDENS for power density measurements. See CONF#:PDEN
    •  
  • ENERDENS for energy density measurements. See CONF#:EDEN
    •  
  • FREQ for frequency measurements. See CONF#:FREQ
    •  
  • TEMP for head NTC temperature measurements. See CONF#:TEMP
    •  
  • RES for head NTC resistance measurements. See CONF#:RES
    •  
  • NEG_PULSE_WIDTH for negative pulse width measurements. See CONF#:NWID
    •  
  • POS_PULSE_WIDTH for positive pulse width measurements. See CONF#:PWID
    •  
  • NEG_DUTY_CYCLE for negative duty cycle measurements. See CONF#:NDUT
    •  
  • POS_DUTY_CYCLE for positive duty cycle measurements. See CONF#:PDUT
    •  
  • 4Q_VOLT for four quadrant voltage measurements. See CONF#:Q4V
    •  
  • POW_ARR for power array measurement. See CONF#:ARR:CHA
    •  
  • CURR_ARR for current array measurement. See CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURR
    •  
  • VOLT_ARR for voltage array measurement. See CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT
    •  
  • BURST for burst measurement. See CONF#:ARR:BUR
    •  
  • SIMU_POWER for simultaneous power measurement. See CONF:SIMU
    •  
  • SIMU_CURR for simultaneous current measurement. See CONF:SIMU:CURR
    •  
  • SIMU_VOLT for simultaneous voltage measurement. See CONF:SIMU:VOLT
    •  
  • SIMU_POWDENS for simultaneous power density measurement. See CONF:SIMU:PDEN
    •  
 

        
>> CONF?
<< VOLT


      

    

    

      

        CONF#:ARR:BURConfigures hardware trigger burst mode
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
:ARRay:BURst 
<initDelay>
,
<burstCount>
,
<avg>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint trigger source. 1(default) signal of channel 1, 2 signal of channel 2, 3 signal of front AUX, 4 signal of rear trigger
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • initDelayuint amount of 10us to wait after trigger before starting burst measurement. Might be 0.
    • 
              
  • burstCountuint Amount of measuruments beeing part of the burst. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
              
  • avguint burst capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
        


        
Use this command after configuring the single channels by command CONF#:ARR:CHA, CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURR or CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT to configure the measure system for burst hardware triggered measurement. The configuration is only required once. To disable a burst measure channel once configured use CONF#:ARR:CHA:DISA. Afterwards you control the measure system by using ABOR#, INIT# and FETC:ARR? finally. 
 There is also the READ:ARR? convenience command for these three SCPI commands. The burst mode stores 15k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. In Burst mode the device stores a defined sequence of measurements for every rising edge trigger condition. Once triggered the sequence might be initially delayed before starting taking a fixed amount of measurements with given averaging. The next trigger will restart the sequence. Use TRIG:ARR:FORC to trigger a burst sequence by software. 
 For closer details about this measurement mode read Scope section.

        
>> CONF1:ARR:BUR 5, 10, 2


      

    

    

      

        CONF#:ARR:CHAConfigures scope channel for power measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
:ARRay:CHAnnel[:POWer]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command during scope mode configuration to configure channel of scope for power measurement. After configuring single or both channels call CONF#:ARR:HWT or CONF:ARR to complete the scope configuration phase. If the sensor at given channel does not support power measurement you will issue an error.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> CONF1:ARR:CHA


      

    

    

      

        CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURRConfigures scope channel for current measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
:ARRay:CHAnnel:CURRent

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command during scope mode configuration to configure channel of scope for current measurement. After configuring single or both channels call CONF#:ARR:HWT or CONF:ARR to complete the scope configuration phase. If the sensor at given channel does not support current measurement you will issue an error.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> CONF1:ARR:CHA:CURR


      

    

    

      

        CONF#:ARR:CHA:DISADisables scope measurement channel
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
:ARRay:CHAnnel:DISAble

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command during scope mode configuration to disable measurement of channel of scope or burst mode. If no sensor is connected disabling channel is not  possible. Use CONF#:ARR:CHA, CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURR or  CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT to enable scope channel.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> CONF2:ARR:CHA:DISA

        
After reboot both scope channels are disabled by default.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLTConfigures scope channel for voltage measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
:ARRay:CHAnnel:VOLTage

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command during scope mode configuration to configure channel of scope for voltage measurement. After configuring single or both channels call CONF#:ARR:HWT or CONF:ARR to complete the scope configuration phase. If the sensor at given channel does not support voltage measurement you will issue an error.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> CONF1:ARR:CHA:VOLT


      

    

    

      

        CONF#:ARR:HWTConfigures hardware trigger scope mode
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
:ARRay:HWTrig  
<avg>
, 
<hpos>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint trigger source. 1(default) signal of channel 1, 2 signal of channel 2, 3 signal of front AUX, 4 signal of rear trigger
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
              
  • hposuint horizontal position of trigger in sample count. Needs be between 0 and 2500.
    • 
        


        
Use this command after configuring the single channels by command CONF#:ARR:CHA, CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURR or CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT to configure the measure system for scope hardware triggered measurement. The configuration is only required once. Afterwards you control the measure system by using ABOR#, INIT# and FETC:ARR? finally. 
 There is also the READ:ARR? convenience command for these three SCPI commands. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. The hpos allows to move the trigger point on the time x axis. The value is given in samples; to convert to us or ms the averaging needs to be considered. For example, at averaging 1, the samples in the scope buffer have a distance of 10 us. Setting hpos to 100 will get 100 @ 10 us samples before the trigger condition so 1 ms. There are different hardware trigger sources addressable by SCPI command suffix. The external triggers releases on rising edges. If the trigger releases, it gets automatically unarmed before it is armed again by INIT#. Using the internal channels an appropriate trigger level by using command SENS#:PEAK needs to be set. If the measured signal becomes larger than the configured threshold the trigger will release. It is also possible to configure a software triggered scope measurement by using CONF:ARR.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> CONF3:ARR:HWT 2,200


      

    

    

      

        CONF#:CURRConfigures SCPI measure system for current measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:CURRent[:DC]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for photodiode current measurement in Ampere. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:CURR, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.
 You can also configure a simultaneous current measurement for both channels using CONF:SIMU:CURR.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:CURR

        
Photodiode only!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:EDENConfigures SCPI measure system for energy density measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:EDENsity

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for pyro energy measurement in J / cm^2. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:EDEN, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. To change the density reference beam size use SENS#:CORR:BEAM command.
 The Powermeter uses an internal threshold signal for pyro peak detection. Ensure the threshold level has been set by SENS#:PEAK previously. When measuring energy density for pyro auto ranging is not supported at all. The user has to select a range manually for example using SENS#:ENER:RANG command. If you have a repetitive pulse signal you can also start the peak finder background operation to let the Powermeter set range and threshold parameters automatically by sending command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:EDEN

        
Pyro only!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:ENERConfigures SCPI measure system for energy measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:ENERgy

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for pyro energy measurement in Joule. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:ENER, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.
 The Powermeter uses an internal threshold signal for pyro peak detection. Ensure the threshold level has been set by SENS#:PEAK previously. When measuring energy auto ranging is not supported at all. The user has to select a range manually for example using SENS#:ENER:RANG command. If you have a repetitive pulse signal you can also start the peak finder background operation to let the Powermeter set range and threshold parameters automatically by sending command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:ENER

        
Pyro only!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:FREQConfigures SCPI measure system for energy frequency measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:FREQuency

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for power frequency measurement in Hz. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:FREQ, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The Powermeter updates the frequency with 2 Hz or less if the input frequency is less. For the frequency measurement the analogue sensor signal is compared to the threshold level see SENS#:PEAK. If the input signal is above the threshold it is detected as high. Otherwise the Powermeter detects a low level. The frequency measurement accuracy depends on the input signal frequency. The Powermeter uses edge counting for input signals larger than approximately 500Hz and period measure for input signals for slower signal frequencies. Edge counting always results in a whole number frequency. If you input a CW signal frequency is read back as 0. Averaging SENS#:AVER is not applied for frequency measurements!

        
>> CONF:FREQ

        
Check different bandwidth of amplification stages for high frequencies.

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:NDUTConfigures measurement system for negative duty cycle
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:NDUTycycle

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for negative duty cycle measurement in percent for photodiodes in peak mode. See SENS#:FREQ:MODE. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:NDUT, INIT#, FETC#?. The negative duty cycle describes the ratio between the pulse low time and the entire pulse period. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. If the analogue signal of the sensor falls below the threshold, time measurement starts until the signal reaches the threshold again. To configure measurement of the absolute peak low time use CONF#:NWID. Measuring duty cycle is not supported for single pulse measurements! Measuring duty cycle makes sense for TTL input signals only. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.

        
>> CONF:NDUT?

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW or single pulse signals!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:NWIDConfigures SCPI measurement system for negative pulse width
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:NWIDth

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for negative or low pulse width measurement in Seconds for photodiodes in peak mode. See SENS#:FREQ:MODE. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:NWID, INIT#, FETC#?. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. If the analogue signal of the sensor falls below the threshold, time measurement starts until the signal reaches the threshold again. You can use CONF#:PWID to configure the measurement of the high time. To configure the relative measurement of the negative pulse use CONF#:NDUT. Measuring pulse width makes sense for TTL input signals only. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.

        
>> CONF:NWID

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW or single pulse signals!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:PDENConfigures SCPI measure system for power density measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:PDENsity

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for photodiode, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile power density measurement in W / cm^2. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:PDEN, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. To change the density reference beam size use SENS#:CORR:BEAM command. For four quadrant thermopile sensors this command configures measurement system for total power density.
 You can also configure a simultaneous power density measurement for both channels using CONF:SIMU:PDEN.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:PDEN

        
Photodiode, Thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:PDUTConfigures measurement system for positive duty cycle
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:PDUTycycle

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for positive duty cycle measurement in percent for photodiodes in peak mode. See SENS#:FREQ:MODE. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:PDUT, INIT#, FETC#?. The positive duty cycle describes the ratio between the pulse high time and the entire pulse period. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. If the analogue signal of the sensor reaches the threshold, time measurement starts until the signal falls below the threshold again. To configure measurement of the absolute peak high time use CONF#:PWID. Measuring duty cycle is not supported for single pulse measurements! Measuring duty cycle makes sense for TTL input signals only. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.

        
>> CONF:PDUT?

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW or single pulse signals!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:POSConfigures SCPI measurement system for beam position measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:POSition

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for beam position coorinate measurement in um. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR,CONF,INIT,FETC?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The beam position is absolute to the center of the sensor.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:POS

        
Only 4 Quadrant Thermopile sensor heads support this measure method

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:PWIDConfigures SCPI measurement system for positive pulse width
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:PWIDth

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for positive or high pulse width measurement in Seconds for photodiodes in peak mode. See SENS#:FREQ:MODE. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:PWID, INIT#, FETC#?. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. If the analogue signal of the sensor reaches the threshold, time measurement starts until the signal falls below the threshold again. You can use CONF#:NWID to configure the measurement of the pulse low time. To configure the relative measurement of the positive pulse use CONF#:PDUT. Measuring pulse width makes sense for TTL input signals only. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.

        
>> CONF:PWID

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW or single pulse signals!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:Q4VConfigures SCPI measurement system for 4 quadrant voltages measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:Q4Voltage

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for 4 quadrant voltages measurement in V. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR,CONF,INIT,FETC?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The beam position is absolute to the centre of the sensor. To configure measurement system for total voltage measurement use command CONF#:VOLT
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:Q4V

        
Only 4 Quadrant Thermopile sensor heads support this measure method

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:RESConfigures SCPI measure system for head resistance measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:RESistance

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for sensor head NTC resistance measurement in Ohm. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:RES, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The sensor head temperature is updated at 2 Hz. Averaging SENS#:AVER is not applied for frequency measurements! To configure the NTC temperature measurement use CONF#:TEMP.

        
>> CONF:RES

        
Not all sensor heads feature temperature measurement via NTC.

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:TEMPConfigures SCPI measurement system for head temperature measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:TEMPerature

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for sensor head NTC temperature measurement in °C. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:TEMP, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements. The sensor head temperature is updated at 2 Hz. Averaging SENS#:AVER is not applied for frequency measurements! To configure the sensor head NTC resistance measurement use CONF#:RES.

        
>> CONF:TEMP

        
Not all sensor heads feature temperature measurement via NTC.

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        CONF#:VOLTConfigures SCPI measure system for voltage measurement
      

      

        
CONFigure
#
[:SCALar]:VOLTage[:DC]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to configure the Powermeter for thermopile, four quadrant or pyro voltage measurement in Volt. This command prepares the measurement only. Configure is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#:VOLT, INIT#, FETC#?. If the measurement has been configured you can either call INIT# and FETC#? or use the shorter READ#? to start the measurements.
  The Powermeter uses an internal threshold signal for pyro peak detection. Ensure the threshold level has been set by SENS#:PEAK previously. When measuring pyro voltage auto ranging is not supported at all. The user has to select a range manually for example using SENS#:VOLT:RANG command. If you have a repetitive pulse signal you can also start the peak finder background operation to let the Powermeter set range and threshold parameters automatically by sending command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR.
 For thermopile sensors and four quadrant thermopile sensors auto ranging is supported by command SENS#:VOLT:RANG:AUTO. For thermopile sensors only you might also enable the thermopile prediction previously by using INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO.
 For four quadrant thermopile sensors this command configures measurement system for total voltage. For the single quadrant voltages use CONF#:Q4V instead.
 You can also configure a simultaneous voltage measurement for both channels using CONF:SIMU:VOLT.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read  Slow measurement section.

        
>> CONF:VOLT

        
Pyro, Thermopile or four quadrant thermopile only!

        
After configuring the measurement call READ#? or INIT# and FETC#? to start and query measurement results finally.

      

    

    

      

        FETC:ARR?Returns binary data block of scope mode result buffer.
      

      

        
FETCh:ARRay? 
<offset>
, 
<length>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • offsetuint start reading array measurements at this offset
    • 
              
  • lengthuint amount of measurements to read at index. Max is 100.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary amount of binary triples in result as uint32_t
    • 
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
Use this command to fetch the scope measure results in multiple binary encoded data blocks. To retrieve the entire 10 kSamples of scope mode the function has to be called with different offsets at least 100 times. In burst mode you should call FETC:ARR:LEN?  to query how many results to query. The scope buffer stays valid until the scope gets armed by INIT# again. You can fetch the data at any speed and order. The result starts with the number of triples in the result as binary 4 byte uint32. If the result length is larger than 0, binary triplet data follows the 4 bytes. Every triplet has this format. Four bytes for uint32 of time followed by four bytes for float of channel 1 and again four bytes for float of channel 2. The floats are IEEE compliant. All uint32 and the floats are transferred with the following little endian byte order: 
  
 The following pseudo code should give you an example how to  parse the result. The variable could have float or uint32 type. 
 val = triplet[0]
 val = val | (triplet[1] << 8)
 val = val | (triplet[2] << 16)
 val = val | (triplet[3] << 24)
 
 You will always get triples even if a single has been configured for scope mode only. The other channel will have a constant value of NAN (Not a Number). The time is a relative time in us. The time might be used to calculate an delta between the samples. The wrap round of time has to be considered. The  following pseudo code shows how to handle wrap around. 
 if(curr_t > prev_t)
   delta_t = curr_t - prev_t
 else
   delta_t = 0xffffffff - prev_t + curr_t
 
 This array fetch SCPI command call will wait for the trigger to fire and then for the internal scope buffer to be filled completely before it will return. It is very likely that there will occur a timeout error. In case of a timeout error, please wait more than 10 Seconds before sending the next SCPI command. Otherwise, the remote interface connection can be crashed. For single pulses or sporadic signals it is better to use the single SCPI commands ABOR#, CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT, CONF#:ARR:HWT, INIT# and call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling fetch finally. If the HW trigger is not firing within expected time you might want to force a trigger condition by using TRIG:ARR:FORC. If you have problems with the binary format you can use the normal FETC#? command with the optional offset parameter. This queries the same data but ways slower. For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> FETC:ARR?
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
If you have problems parsing the binary format. You can also user FETC#? to query the same data in text representation. This method is simply slower.

      

    

    

      

        FETC:ARR:LEN?Queries amount of triplets in scope or burst buffer
      

      

        
FETCh:ARRay:LENgth?

        
Response
    
          
  • countuint total amount of tripplets in scope or burst buffer
    • 
        


        
Use this command in burst mode after ABOR# to query the amount of triplets in burst buffer. Once you know the amount of triplets you use FETC#? or FETC:ARR? to query the results. For scope mode the command is valid but useless. 

        
>> FETC:ARR:LEN?
<< 10000

        
For scope this function will always return 10000. Should be used for burst mode.

      

    

    

      

        FETC#?Blocks until previously initiated measurement is complete and returns result finally
      

      

        
FETCh
#
? 
<offset>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • offsetuint Optional! Optional data fetch offset. Used for scope mode only.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • measurementfloat measurement result. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range.
    • 
        


        
Fetch is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#, INIT#, FETC#?. Use this command block remote interface until previously initiated measurement is complete and return the result finally. The maximal query frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. Call SENS#:AVER to change averaging. Averaging is only applied for  CW mode. All peak, temperature, resistance pulse width units are measured independently of the averaging. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state. For closer details read for example SENS#:CURR:REF and SENS#:CURR:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled.
 Be careful when measuring Pyro sensors or Photodiodes in PEAK mode. If the input signal does not constantly generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command can block for multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. For modulated signals it is better to call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC? finally. You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 Be aware result of fetch depends on measured unit. When configured for thermopile 4 quadrant voltage the result will be a quadrupel of the four voltages separated by comma.
 For all simultaneous measurement results you will receive a tuple with the two measurement results.
 You can also use this command to fetch the result of scope or burst mode in a normal text representation instead of binary format of command FETC:ARR?. Querying the results in text representation is a lot slower than the binary transfers. When used for scope mode the result is the relative capture time, channel 0 followed by channel 1. Regardless of mode this command may return inf or nan instead of floating point number. In burst mode you should  call FETC:ARR:LEN? to query how many results to query.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> FETC?
<< 1.34324e-5 (or)
<<5.34534e-3,3.2433e-4(Simultaneous measurement)
<<123, -234(Beam position)
<<5.34534e-3,3.2433e-4,1.8432e-3,5.2312e-8 (For four quadrant voltages)
<<38759030,nan,5.76388e-06 (For scope mode)

        
Do not send ABOR in case of read timeout within 10 seconds.

        
Fetch is part of the SCPI measurement system command sequence: ABOR#, CONF#, INIT#, FETC?.

      

    

    

      

        FETC#:STAT?Tests if there is measurement data to fetch
      

      

        
FETCh
#
:STATe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if data is ready to fetch. 0 if not.
    • 
        


        
Call this function to test if there is data to fetch. If the function returns 1 you can call FETC#? or FETC:ARR? depending on measure mode. If the function returns 0 measurement system is still waiting for  measure result. 

        
>> FETC:STAT?
<< 1

        
You might also call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND?.

      

    

    

      

        FETC#:TIM?Blocks defined time until previously initiated measurement is complete and returns result finally
      

      

        
FETCh
#
:TIMeout? 
<timeout>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • timeoutuint time in ms to wait for data to be fetched.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • measurementfloat measurement result. May be 0 for timeout, INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range.
    • 
        


        
Same as FETC#? but waits for result only defined of time. In case of timeout the function return 0. Otherwise recent measurement result is returned. In case of timeout you might want to call ABOR# to discard the measurement. 

        
>> FETC:TIM?
<< 1


      

    

    

      

        INIT#Starts a new single measurement for a previously configured unit
      

      

        
INITiate
#
[:IMMediate]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to start a new single measurement for a previously configured unit. Fetch is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#, INIT#:CONT, FETC#?. The command requires any of the configure commands has been called previously. If the Powermeter receives an INIT# command it will start a single new measurement. The maximal measurement frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. Call SENS#:AVER to change averaging. Averaging is only applied for Photodiode in CW mode. All peak, temperature, resistance pulse width units are measured independently of the averaging.
 Use FETC#? to wait until the measurement has been taken and the result is ready. If you want to check if the measurement has been taken without blocking the remote interface call STAT:OPER:COND? and call FETC#:STAT? or check the DataReadyToFetch flag before calling fetch.

        
>> INIT

        
Init is part of the SCPI measurement system command sequence: ABOR#, CONF#, INIT, FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        INIT#:CONTStarts a new continuos measurement for a previously configured unit
      

      

        
INITiate
#
:CONTinuous

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to start a new continuos measurement for a previously configured unit. Fetch is part of the SCPI measurement system ABOR#, CONF#, INIT#:CONT, FETC#?. The command requires any of the configure commands has been called previously. If the Powermeter receives a INIT#:CONT command it will start a new continuos measurement. A continuos measurement always updates the measurement value of the remote interface. So once started you can call FETC#? as often as you want to get consecutive measure results. The results are not queued within the Powermeter! To stop a continuos measurement use the ABOR# command.

        
>> INIT:CONT

        
Init is part of the SCPI measurement system command sequence: ABOR#, CONF#, INIT:COND, FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS:ARR?Measures a software triggered sequence of power W values in scope mode
      

      

        
MEASure:ARRay[:SWTrig][:POWer]? 
<avg>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary amount of binary triples in result as uint32_t
    • 
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
This software triggered scope mode is only available for thermal and photodiode power sensors in CW mode. For checking measure mode of photodiode use command SENS#:FREQ:MODE?. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. The function will configure all channels that are connected and in a valid mode for power scope measurement. If none of the channels support this mode an error will be issued. Once the buffer is full the command will return the first 100 samples as binary triples. To query the rest of samples call FETC:ARR? multiple times afterwards. Please read this FETC:ARR? for data format description. This SCPI command is a convenience function that includes the SCPI command sequence ABOR#, CONF#:ARR:CHA, CONF:ARR, INIT# and finally FETC:ARR?. If you want to use a hardware trigger to horizontal lock the signal use MEAS#:ARR:HWT?.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> MEAS:ARR? 2
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
Depending on averaging this command may take several seconds to complete.

        
The command finally return first 100 triples. Call FETC:ARR? to get all data afterwards.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS:ARR:CURR?Measures a software triggered sequence of current A values in scope mode
      

      

        
MEASure:ARRay[:SWTrig]:CURRent? 
<avg>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary amount of binary triples in result as uint32_t
    • 
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
This software triggered current scope mode is only available for photodiode sensors in CW mode. For checking measure mode use command SENS#:FREQ:MODE?. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. The function will configure all channels that are connected and in a valid mode for current scope measurement. If none of the channels support this mode an error will be issued. Once the buffer is full the command will return the first 100 samples as binary triples. To query the rest of samples call FETC:ARR? multiple times afterwards. Please read this FETC:ARR? for data format description. This SCPI command is a convenience function that includes the SCPI command sequence ABOR#, CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURR, CONF:ARR, INIT# and finally FETC:ARR?. If you want to use a hardware trigger to horizontal lock the signal use MEAS#:ARR:HWT:CURR?. For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> MEAS:ARR:CURR? 1
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
Depending on averaging this command may take several seconds to complete.

        
The command finally return first 100 triples. Call FETC:ARR? to get all data afterwards.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS:ARR:VOLT?Measures a software triggered sequence of voltage V values in scope mode
      

      

        
MEASure:ARRay[:SWTrig]:VOLTage? 
<avg>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary amount of binary triples in result as uint32_t
    • 
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
This software triggered voltage scope mode is only available for thermopile sensors in CW mode. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. The function will configure all channels that are connected and in a valid mode for voltage scope measurement. If none of the channels support this mode an error will be issued. Once the buffer is full the command will return the first 100 samples as binary triples. To query the rest of samples call FETC:ARR? multiple times afterwards. Please read this FETC:ARR? for data format description. This SCPI command is a convenience function that includes the SCPI command sequence ABOR#, CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT, CONF:ARR, INIT# and finally FETC:ARR?. If you want to use a hardware trigger to horizontal lock the signal use MEAS#:ARR:HWT:VOLT?. For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> MEAS:ARR:VOLT? 1
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
Depending on averaging this command may take several seconds to complete.

        
The command finally return first 100 triples. Call FETC:ARR? to get all data afterwards.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS:SIMU?Measures the sensor averaged power in Watt or dBm for both channels simultaneously
      

      

        
MEASure:SIMUltaneous[:POWer]?

        
Response
    
          
  • power1float power in Watt or dBm of channel 1. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
          
  • power2float power in Watt or dBm of channel 2. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged power in Watt or dBm for photodiode, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile  sensors on both channel simultaneously.  The unit depends on the power unit configuration SENS#:POW:UNIT of channel 1. If the Powermeter receives a  MEAS:SIMU? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results of a single channel query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1. This command requires two connected power sensors measuring in CW mode. Parallel peak measurements or single channel measurements  are not supported by this command.  During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state of channel 1. For closer details read SENS#:POW:REF and SENS#:POW:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled. For thermopile sensors the accelerator might be enabled by INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO. When enabled and electrical sensor signal changeed significantly, the measure command will return software calculated values for a short time. Acceleration feature does not apply for four quadrant thermopile sensors. For the four quadarnt thermopile  sensors the command will return the total power.
 You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 You can also run a single channel power measurement with  the command MEAS#?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:SIMU?
<< 5.99893e-07,6.95153e-05

        
Photodiode and thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only. Only CW measure mode supported. Requires two connected power sensors.

        
MEAS is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF:SIMU; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS:SIMU:CURR?Measures the sensor averaged current for both channels simultaneously
      

      

        
MEASure:SIMUltaneous:CURRent[:DC]?

        
Response
    
          
  • current1float current in Ampere of channel 1. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
          
  • current2float current in Ampere of channel 2. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged current in Ampere for photodiode sensors on both channel simultaneously.  If the Powermeter receives a MEAS:SIMU:CURR? command, it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results of a single channel query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1. This command requires two connected power sensors measuring in CW mode. Parallel peak measurements or single channel measurements  are not supported by this command. During the measurement  the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state for channel 1. For closer details read SENS#:CURR:REF and SENS#:CURR:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled.
 You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 You can also run a single channel current measurement with  the command MEAS#:CURR?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:SIMU:CURR?
<< 5.99893e-07,6.95153e-05

        
Photodiode only. Only CW measure mode supported. Requires two connected power sensors.

        
MEAS:SIMU:CURR? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF:SIMU:CURR; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS:SIMU:PDEN?Measures the sensor averaged power density for both channels simultaneously
      

      

        
MEASure:SIMUltaneous:PDENsity?

        
Response
    
          
  • density1float energy density in Watt per square cm of channel 1. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
          
  • density2float energy density in Watt per square cm of channel 2. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged power density in Watt per square cm for photodiodes, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile sensors on both channels simultaneously. If the  Powermeter receives a MEAS:SIMU:PDEN? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results for a s single channel query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. To change the density reference beam size use SENS#:CORR:BEAM command. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1. This command requires two connected power sensors measuring in CW mode. Parallel peak measurements or single channel measurements  are not supported by this command. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state for channel 1.  For closer details read SENS#:POW:REF and SENS#:POW:REF:STAT.  By default delta is disabled. For thermopile sensors the  accelerator might be enabled by INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO.  When enabled and electrical sensor signal changed significantly, the measure command will return software calculated values  for a short time. Acceleration feature does not apply for  four quadrant thermopile sensors. For the four quadrant thermopile sensors the command will return the total power density.
 You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 You can also run a single channel power density measurement with  the command MEAS#:PDEN?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:SIMU:PDEN?
<< 5.99893e-07,6.95153e-05

        
Photodiode and thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only. Only CW measure mode supported. Requires two connected power sensors.

        
MEAS:SIMU:PDEN? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF:SIMU:PDEN; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS:SIMU:VOLT?Measures the sensor averaged voltage for both channels simultaneously
      

      

        
MEASure:SIMUltaneous:VOLTage[:DC]?

        
Response
    
          
  • voltagefloat voltage in Volt of channel 1. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
          
  • voltagefloat voltage in Volt of channel 2. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged voltage in Volt for  thermopile or 4 quadrant thermopile sensors on both channels  simultaneously. The execution of this measure command depends on the connected sensor type.
 For thermopile and four quadrant thermopile sensors the command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz. (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command for channel 1. This command requires two connected voltage sensors. Parallel peak measurements or single channel measurements  are not supported by this command. For thermopile sensors the accelerator might be enabled by INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO. When enabled and electrical sensor signal changed significantly, the measure command will return software calculated values for a short time. Acceleration feature does not apply for four quadrant thermopile sensors. For the four quadarnt thermopile sensors the command will return the total voltage. Use  MEAS#:Q4V? to query the single channel quadrant voltages.
 You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND?  so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 The following applies to thermopile sensors. To retrieve all measurement results of a single channel query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. During the simultaneous measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state  of channel 1. For closer details read SENS#:VOLT:REF  and SENS#:VOLT:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled.
 You can also run a single channel voltage measurement with  the command MEAS#:VOLT?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:SIMU:VOLT?
<< 5.99893e-07,6.95153e-05

        
Thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only. Requires two connected voltage sensors.

        
MEAS:VOLT? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF:SIMU:VOLT; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#?Measures the sensor averaged power in Watt or dBm
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar][:POWer]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • powerfloat power in Watt or dBm. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged power in Watt or dBm for photodiode, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile sensors. The unit depends on the power unit configuration SENS#:POW:UNIT. If the Powermeter receives a MEAS#? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command. It is only applied for Photodiode CW mode. For peak measurements the averaging is skipped. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state. For closer details read SENS#:POW:REF and SENS#:POW:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled. For thermopile sensors the accelerator might be enabled by INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO. When enabled and electrical sensor signal changeed significantly, the measure command will return software calculated values for a short time. Acceleration feature does not apply for four quadrant thermopile sensors. For the four quadarnt thermopile  sensors the command will return the total power.
 Be careful when measuring Photodiodes in PEAK mode. If the input signal does not constantly generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command will block for multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. In this special case it is better not to call this command. It is saver to INIT# a new measurement, call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC#? finally. You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 You can also run a simultaneous two channel power measurement with  the command MEAS:SIMU?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS?
<< 3.34e-5

        
Photodiode and thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only. Be careful when measuring single pulse events. Read details carefully.

        
MEAS is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:ARR:HWT?Measures a hardware triggered sequence of power W values in scope mode.
      

      

        
MEASure
#
:ARRay:HWTrig[:POWer]? 
<avg>
, 
<hpos>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint trigger source. 1(default) signal of channel 1, 2 signal of channel 2, 3 signal of front AUX, 4 signal of rear trigger
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
              
  • hposuint horizontal position of trigger in sample count. Needs be between 0 and 2500.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary amount of binary triples in result as uint32_t
    • 
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
 This hardware triggered scope mode is only available for thermal and photodiode power sensors in CW mode. For checking measure mode of photodiode use command SENS#:FREQ:MODE?. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. The function will configure all channels that are connected and in a valid mode for power scope measurement. If none of the channels support this mode an error will be issued. Once the buffer is full the command will return the first 100 samples as binary triples. To query the rest of samples call FETC:ARR? multiple times afterwards. Please read this FETC:ARR? for data format description. This SCPI command is a convenience function that includes the SCPI command sequence ABOR#, CONF#:ARR:CHA, CONF#:ARR:HWT, INIT# and finally FETC:ARR?.The hpos allows to move the trigger point on the time x axis. The value is given in samples; to convert to us or ms the averaging needs to be considered. For example, at averaging 1, the samples in the scope buffer have a distance of 10 us. Setting hpos to 100 will get 100 @ 10 us samples before the trigger condition so 1 ms. 
Be aware that this command is implemented for convenience and should not be used for single pulse measurements. The internal FETC:ARR? call will wait for the trigger to fire and then for the internal scope buffer to be filled completely before it will return. It is very likely that there will occur a timeout error. In case of a timeout error, please wait more than 10 Seconds before sending the next SCPI command. Otherwise, the remote interface connection can be crashed. For single pulses or sporadic signals it is better to use the single SCPI commands and call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC:ARR? finally. 
 There are different hardware trigger sources addressable by SCPI command suffix. The external triggers releases on rising edges. If the trigger releases, it gets automatically unarmed before it is armed again by INIT#.Using the internal channels an appropriate trigger level by using command SENS#:PEAK needs to be set. If the measured signal becomes larger than the configured threshold the trigger will release. It is also possible to start a software triggered scope measurement by using MEAS:ARR?. Do not use TRIG:ARR:FORC if you used this scope mode measure command.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> MEAS2:ARR:HWT? 4, 400
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
Depending on signal this command may take several seconds to complete. For sporadic single pulse signals read details carefully.

        
The command finally return first 100 triples. Call FETC:ARR? to get all data afterwards.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:ARR:HWT:CURR?Measures a hardware triggered sequence of current A values in scope mode.
      

      

        
MEASure
#
:ARRay:HWTrig:CURRent? 
<avg>
, 
<hpos>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint trigger source. 1(default) signal of channel 1, 2 signal of channel 2, 3 signal of front AUX, 4 signal of rear trigger
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
              
  • hposuint horizontal position of trigger in sample count. Needs be between 0 and 2500.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary amount of binary triples in result as uint32_t
    • 
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
 This hardware triggered scope mode is only available photodiode sensors in CW mode. For checking measure mode of photodiode use command SENS#:FREQ:MODE?. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. The function will configure all channels that are connected and in a valid mode for current scope measurement. If none of the channels support this mode an error will be issued. Once the buffer is full the command will return the first 100 samples as binary triples. To query the rest of samples call FETC:ARR? multiple times afterwards. Please read this FETC:ARR? for data format description. This SCPI command is a convenience function that includes the SCPI command sequence ABOR#, CONF#:ARR:CHA:CURR, CONF#:ARR:HWT, INIT# and finally FETC:ARR?.The hpos allows to move the trigger point on the time x axis. The value is given in samples; to convert to us or ms the averaging needs to be considered. For example, at averaging 1, the samples in the scope buffer have a distance of 10 us. Setting hpos to 100 will get 100 @ 10 us samples before the trigger condition so 1 ms. 
Be aware that this command is implemented for convenience and should not be used for single pulse measurements. The internal FETC:ARR? call will wait for the trigger to fire and then for the internal scope buffer to be filled completely before it will return. It is very likely that there will occur a timeout error. In case of a timeout error, please wait more than 10 Seconds before sending the next SCPI command. Otherwise, the remote interface connection can be crashed. For single pulses or sporadic signals it is better to use the single SCPI commands and call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC:ARR? finally. 
 There are different hardware trigger sources addressable by SCPI command suffix. The external triggers releases on rising edges. If the trigger releases, it gets automatically unarmed before it is armed again by INIT#.Using the internal channels an appropriate trigger level by using command SENS#:PEAK needs to be set. If the measured signal becomes larger than the configured threshold the trigger will release. It is also possible to start a software triggered scope measurement by using MEAS:ARR?. Do not use TRIG:ARR:FORC if you used this scope mode measure command.  For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> MEAS2:ARR:HWT:CURR? 4, 400
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
Depending on signal this command may take several seconds to complete. For sporadic single pulse signals read details carefully.

        
The command finally return first 100 triples. Call FETC:ARR? to get all data afterwards.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:ARR:HWT:VOLT?Measures a hardware triggered sequence of voltage V values in scope mode.
      

      

        
MEASure
#
:ARRay:HWTrig:VOLTage? 
<avg>
, 
<hpos>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint trigger source. 1(default) signal of channel 1, 2 signal of channel 2, 3 signal of front AUX, 4 signal of rear trigger
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • avguint scope capture devisor for 100 kHz sample rate of scope mode. 0 is not allowed.
    • 
              
  • hposuint horizontal position of trigger in sample count. Needs be between 0 and 2500.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • countbinary amount of binary triples in result as uint32_t
    • 
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
 This hardware triggered scope mode is only available for thermal sensors. The scope mode stores 10k samples with given averaging at max 100 kHz in an internal buffer. So max time resolution between the samples is 10 us. With the internal sample buffer of 10000 will end up in a capture time of 100 ms with highest resolution. For example, setting an averaging of 2 will give 200 ms capture time. The function will configure all channels that are connected and in a valid mode for voltage scope measurement. If none of the channels support this mode an error will be issued. Once the buffer is full the command will return the first 100 samples as binary triples. To query the rest of samples call FETC:ARR? multiple times afterwards. Please read this FETC:ARR? for data format description. This SCPI command is a convenience function that includes the SCPI command sequence ABOR#, CONF#:ARR:CHA:VOLT, CONF#:ARR:HWT, INIT# and finally FETC:ARR?.The hpos allows to move the trigger point on the time x axis. The value is given in samples; to convert to us or ms the averaging needs to be considered. For example, at averaging 1, the samples in the scope buffer have a distance of 10 us. Setting hpos to 100 will get 100 @ 10 us samples before the trigger condition so 1 ms. 
Be aware that this command is implemented for convenience and should not be used for single pulse measurements. The internal FETC:ARR? call will wait for the trigger to fire and then for the internal scope buffer to be filled completely before it will return. It is very likely that there will occur a timeout error. In case of a timeout error, please wait more than 10 Seconds before sending the next SCPI command. Otherwise, the remote interface connection can be crashed. For single pulses or sporadic signals it is better to use the single SCPI commands and call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC:ARR? finally. 
 There are different hardware trigger sources addressable by SCPI command suffix. The external triggers releases on rising edges. If the trigger releases, it gets automatically unarmed before it is armed again by INIT#.Using the internal channels an appropriate trigger level by using command SENS#:PEAK needs to be set. If the measured signal becomes larger than the configured threshold the trigger will release. It is also possible to start a software triggered scope measurement by using MEAS:ARR:VOLT?.
