Do not use TRIG:ARR:FORC if you used this scope mode measure command. For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> MEAS3:ARR:HWT:VOLT? 4, 400
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
Depending on signal this command may take several seconds to complete. For sporadic single pulse signals read details carefully.

        
The command finally return first 100 triples. Call FETC:ARR? to get all data afterwards.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:CURR?Measures the sensor averaged current
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:CURRent[:DC]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • currentfloat current in Ampere. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged current in Ampere for photodiode sensors. If the Powermeter receives a MEAS#:CURR? command, it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command. It is only applied for Photodiode CW mode. For peak measurements the averaging is skipped. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state. For closer details read SENS#:CURR:REF and SENS#:CURR:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled. Be careful when measuring Photodiodes in PEAK mode. If the input signal does not constantly generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command will block for multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. In this special case it is better not to call this command. It is saver to INIT# a new measurement, call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC#? finally. You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 You can also run a simultaneous two channel current measurement with  the command MEAS:SIMU:CURR?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:CURR?
<< 3.34e-5

        
Photodiode only. Be careful when measuring single pulse events. Read details carefully.

        
MEAS:CURR? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:CURR; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:EDEN?Measures the sensor averaged energy density
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:EDENsity?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • densityfloat energy density in Joule / cm^2. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged energy density in Joule per square cm for pyro sensors. If the Powermeter receives a  MEAS#:EDEN? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. To change the  density reference beam size use SENS#:CORR:BEAM command. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests.
 The Powermeter uses an internal threshold signal for peak detection. Ensure the threshold level has been set by SENS#:PEAK previously. When measuring energy density auto ranging is not supported at all. The user has to select a range manually using SENS#:ENER:RANG. If you have a repetitive pulse signal you can also start the peak finder background operation to let the Powermeter set range and threshold parameters automatically by sending command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR.
 If the input signal does not repetitively generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command can block multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. In this special case it is better not to call this command. It is saver to INIT# a new measurement, call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC#? finally. You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:EDEN?
<< 2.78e-4

        
Pyro only. Be careful when measuring single pulse events. Read details carefully.

        
MEAS:EDEN? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:EDEN; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:ENER?Measures the sensor averaged energy in J
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:ENERgy?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • energyfloat energy in Joule. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged energy in Joule for pyro sensors. If the Powermeter receives a MEAS#:ENER? command it will start a new measurement and return result when next peak has been detected. The maximal frequency is 1 kHz. All peaks within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all peak measure results, query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state. For closer details read SENS#:ENER:REF and SENS#:ENER:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled. Averaging is not applied for this measurement!
 The Powermeter uses an internal threshold signal for peak detection. Ensure the threshold level has been set by SENS#:PEAK previously. When measuring energy auto ranging is not supported at all. The user has to select a range manually using SENS#:ENER:RANG. If you have a repetitive pulse signal you can also start the peak finder background operation to let the Powermeter set range and threshold parameters automatically by sending command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR.
 If the input signal does not repetitively generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command can block multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. In this special case it is better not to call this command. It is saver to INIT# a new measurement, call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC#? finally. You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:ENER?
<< 1.34e-6

        
Pyro only. Be careful when measuring single pulse events. Read details carefully.

        
MEAS:ENER? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:ENER; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:FREQ?Measures the modulated sensor signal frequency in Hz
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:FREQuency?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • frequfloat frquency in Hz. Might be 0 Hz for CW signals
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure the modulation frequency of the input signal in Hz. The Powermeter updates the frequency with 2 Hz or less if the input frequency is less. For the frequency measurement the input signal is compared to the threshold level see SENS#:PEAK. If the input signal is above the  threshold it is detected as high. Otherwise the Powermeter detects a low level. The frequency measurement accuracy depends on the input signal frequency. The Powermeter uses edge counting for input signals larger  than approximately 500Hz and period measure for input signals for slower signal frequencies. Edge counting always results in a whole number frequency.  If you input a CW signal frequency is read back as 0. Averaging SENS#:AVER is not applied for frequency measurements!

        
>> MEAS:FREQ?
<< 423.32

        
Check different bandwidth of amplification stages for high frequencies.

        
MEAS:FREQ? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:FREQ; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:NDUT?Measures the negative pulse duty cycle
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:NDUTycycle?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • resfloat relation between signal below and above threshold in percent
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure the negative pulse duty cycle in percent. The negative duty cycle describes the ratio between the pulse low time and the entire pulse period. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. To measure the absolute negative pulse time use MEAS#:NWID?. Measuring duty cycle is not supported for single pulse measurements! This measurement makes sense for TTL input signals only.

        
>> MEAS:NDUT?
<< 23.34

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW signals!

        
MEAS:NDUT? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:NDUT; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:NWID?Measures the negative pulse width
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:NWIDth?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • resfloat time analogue signal stays below threshold between pulses in Seconds
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure the negative or low pulse width in Seconds. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. If the analogue signal of the sensor falls below the threshold, time measurement starts until the signal reaches the threshold again. You can use MEAS#:PWID? to measure the high time of the pulse.For relative negative duty cycle measurements call MEAS#:NDUT?. Measuring negative pulse width is not supported for single pulse measurements! This measurement makes sense for TTL input signals only.

        
>> MEAS:NWID?
<< 0.0125

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW signals!

        
MEAS:NWID? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:NWID; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:PDEN?Measures the sensor averaged power density
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:PDENsity?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • densityfloat energy density in Watt per square cm. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged power density in Watt per square cm for photodiodes, thermopile or four quadrant thermopile sensors. If the Powermeter receives a MEAS#:PDEN? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. To change the density reference beam size use SENS#:CORR:BEAM command. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command. It is only applied for Photodiode CW mode. For peak measurements the averaging is skipped. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state. For closer details read SENS#:POW:REF and SENS#:POW:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled. For thermopile sensors the accelerator might be enabled by INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO. When enabled and electrical sensor signal changed significantly, the measure command will return software calculated values for a short time. Acceleration feature does not apply for four quadrant thermopile sensors. For the four quadrant thermopile sensors the command will return the total power density.
 Be careful when measuring Photodiodes in PEAK mode. If the input signal does not constantly generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command will block for multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. In this special case it is better not to call this command. It is saver to INIT# a new measurement, call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC#? finally. You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 You can also run a simultaneous two channel power density measurement with  the command MEAS:SIMU:PDEN?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:PDEN?
<< 3.34e-5

        
Photodiode and thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only. Be careful when measuring single pulse events. Read details carefully.

        
MEAS:PDEN? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:PDEN; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:PDUT?Measures the positive pulse duty cycle
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:PDUTycycle?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • resfloat relation between signal above and below threshold in percent
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure the positive pulse duty cycle in percent. The positive duty cycle describes the ratio between the pulse high time and the entire pulse period. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. To measure the absolute positive pulse time use MEAS#:PWID?. Measuring duty cycle is not supported for single pulse measurements! This measurement makes sense for TTL input signals only.

        
>> MEAS:PDUT?
<< 23.34

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW signals!

        
MEAS:PDUT? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:PDUT; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:POS?Measures the absolute beam position on sensor in um
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:POSition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • temperatureuint beam X coordinate in um
    • 
          
  • temperatureuint beam Y coordinate in um
    • 
        


        
Use this command for 4 qudrant thermopile sensors to measure  the beam position coordinate on the sensor in um. The coordinate is absolute to the center of the sensor area.  If the Powermeter receives a MEAS:POS? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). The averaging might be adapted by  SENS#:AVER command.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:FREQ?
<< 120,-234

        
Only 4 Quadrant Thermopile sensor heads support this measure method

        
MEAS:POS? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:POS; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:PWID?Measures the positive pulse width
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:PWIDth?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • resfloat time analogue signal stays above threshold in Seconds
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure the positive or high pulse width in Seconds. Low and high are defined by the peak detection threshold. See SENS#:PEAK. If the analogue signal of the sensor reaches the threshold, time measurement starts until the signal falls below the threshold again. You can use MEAS#:NWID? to measure the low time of the pulse. For relative positive duty cycle measurements call MEAS#:PDUT?. This measurement makes sense for TTL input signals only.

        
>> MEAS:PWID?
<< 0.0125

        
Only supported for Photodiodes in peak measure mode. Not available for CW signals!

        
MEAS:NWID? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:PWID; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:Q4V?Measures the single voltages of four qudrant thermopile sensors in V
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:Q4Voltage?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • voltage q1float voltage on first quadrant of thermopile in V
    • 
          
  • voltage q2float voltage on second quadrant of thermopile in V
    • 
          
  • voltage q3float voltage on third quadrant of thermopile in V
    • 
          
  • voltage q4float voltage on fourth quadrant of thermopile in V
    • 
        


        
Use this command for 4 qudrant thermopile sensors to measure  the signle qudrant voltages of the sensor in Volt. If the Powermeter receives a MEAS:Q4V? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). The averaging might be adapted by  SENS#:AVER command.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:Q4V?
<< 9.28127e-05,9.80894e-05,9.92041e-05,9.62379e-05

        
Only 4 Quadrant Thermopile sensor heads support this measure method

        
MEAS:Q4V? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:Q4V; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:RES?Measures sensor head NTC resistance
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:RESistance?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • resfloat NTC resistance in Ohm
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure the sensor head NTC resistance in Ohm. The value is updated at 2 Hz. Averaging SENS#:AVER is not applied for resistance measurements! To measure the NTC temperature directly use MEAS#:TEMP?. If you want to measure the external NTC resistance you have to use the command SENS#:RES:DATA?.

        
>> MEAS:RES?
<< 3434.33

        
Not all sensor heads feature temperature measurement via NTC.

        
MEAS:RES? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:RES; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:TEMP?Measures sensor head temperature in °C
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:TEMPerature?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • temperaturefloat temperature in °C
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure the sensor head temperature in °C. The sensor head temperature is updated at 2 Hz. Averaging SENS#:AVER is not applied for head temperature measurements! To measure the NTC resistance use MEAS#:RES?. If you want to measure the external NTC temperature you have to use the command SENS#:TEMP:DATA?.

        
>> MEAS:FREQ?
<< 34.55

        
Not all sensor heads feature temperature measurement.

        
MEAS:TEMP? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:TEMP; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        MEAS#:VOLT?Measures the sensor averaged voltage
      

      

        
MEASure
#
[:SCALar]:VOLTage[:DC]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • voltagefloat voltage in Volt. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to measure an averaged voltage in Volt for pyro,  thermopile or 4 quadrant thermopile sensors. The execution of this measure command depends on the connected sensor type.
 For thermopile and four quadrant thermopile sensors the command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz. (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. The averaging might be adapted by SENS#:AVER command. For thermopile sensors the accelerator might be enabled by INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO. When enabled and electrical sensor signal changed significantly, the measure command will return software calculated values for a short time. Acceleration feature does not apply for four quadrant thermopile sensors. For the four quadarnt thermopile sensors the command will return the total voltage. Use  MEAS#:Q4V? to query the single quadrant voltages.
 For pyro sensors the command will return result when next peak has been detected. The maximal command call frequency is 1 kHz. All peaks within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. Averaging is not applied for this sensor type! The Powermeter uses an internal threshold signal for peak detection of pyro sensors. Ensure the threshold level has been set by SENS#:PEAK previously. When measuring voltage for pyro sensors auto ranging is not supported at all. The user has to select a range manually using SENS#:VOLT:RANG. If you have a repetitive pulse signal you can also start the peak finder background operation to let the Powermeter set range and threshold parameters automatically by sending command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR.
 If the input pyro signal does not repetitively generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command can block multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. In this special case it is better not to call this command. It is saver to INIT# a new measurement, call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC#? finally. You may query the Questionable Status register STAT:QUES:COND? so see if measurement results are valid and not infinity.
 The following applies to thermopile and pyro sensors. To retrieve all measurement results query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state. For closer details read SENS#:VOLT:REF and SENS#:VOLT:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled.
 You can also run a simultaneous two channel voltage measurement with  the command MEAS:SIMU:VOLT?.
 For closer details about this measurement mode read   Slow measurement section.

        
>> MEAS:VOLT?
<< 3.34e-5

        
Pyro, thermopile and four quadrant thermopile only. Be careful when measuring single pulse events. Read details carefully.

        
MEAS:VOLT? is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; CONF#:VOLT; INIT#; FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        READ:ARR?Reads result of a previously configured scope mode
      

      

        
READ:ARRay?

        
Response
    
          
  • databinary list of binary triples. Four bytes relative uint time between samples. 2 times four bytes IEEE float
    • 
        


        
Use this connivance command to read the previously configured scope results. This command is independent of the software CONF:ARR or CONF#:ARR:HWT hardware scope mode. The command internally uses the SCPI command sequence ABOR# INIT# and FETC:ARR?. The READ:ARR? command will return the first 100 samples as binary triples. To query the rest of samples call FETC:ARR? multiple times afterwards. Be aware that this command is implemented for convenience and should not be used for single pulse measurements. The internal FETC:ARR? call will wait for the trigger to fire and then for the internal scope buffer to be filled completely before it will return. It is very likely that there will occur a timeout error. In case of a timeout error, please wait more than 10 Seconds before sending the next SCPI command. Otherwise, the remote interface connection can be crashed. For single pulses or sporadic signals it is better to use the single SCPI commands and call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC:ARR? finally. For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> READ:ARR?
<< <4 Bytes length>

        
Depending on signal this command may take several seconds to complete. For sporadic single pulse signals read details carefully.

        
The command finally return first 100 tuples. Call FETC:ARR? to get all data afterwards.

      

    

    

      

        READ#?Starts and queries measurement result for a previously configured unit
      

      

        
READ
#
?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • measurementfloat measurement result. May be INFINITY or -INFINITY if signal out of measurement range
    • 
        


        
Use this command to start and query measure results of the previously configured unit. The command requires any of the configure commands have been called previously. If the Powermeter receives a READ#? command it will start a new measurement and return result when enough data has been averaged. The maximal frequency is 1 kHz (averaging 1). All measurement results within the 1 millisecond period are averaged. To retrieve all measurement results of some units query the fast measurement stream ACQ#:FAST:FETC?. During the measurement the remote interface will block and can not process any further SCPI requests. The result of this command may be absolute or relative depending on delta mode offset and enable state. For closer details read for example SENS#:CURR:REF and SENS#:CURR:REF:STAT. By default delta is disabled.
 Be careful when measuring Pyro sensors or Photodiodes in PEAK mode. If the input signal does not repetitively generate pulses (single pulse measurements or low repetition rates) the command can block for multiple seconds and end up in a timeout after 10 seconds without a pulse. For modulated signals it is better to call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC#? finally.

        
>> READ?
<< 1.34324e-5

        
Read is a convenience command for the SCPI command sequence: ABOR#; INIT# and FETC#?.

      

    

    

      

        TRIG:ARR:FORCForces a trigger condition for scope mode if not triggered already
      

      

        
TRIGer:ARRay:FORCe

        
Use this command in HW trigger mode to force a trigger condition by software. If you called INIT# previously the PM waits for a trigger condition. This commands fires the trigger manually regardless of the signal level. After calling this command you have to wait for the scope buffer to be completely filled. Call FETC#:STAT? or check for the DataReadyToFetch flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? before calling FETC:ARR? or FETC#? finally. For closer details about this measurement mode read  Scope section.

        
>> TRIG:ARR:FORC

        
Must not be used with any of the convenience array measure commands like MEAS#:ARR:HWT?.

        
Has no effect if trigger previously already.

      

    

    

    
Unfold all SENS Commands

    

      

        SENS#:AVERSets the averaging for slow measurements
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:AVERage[:COUNt] 
<pres>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • presuint whole number prescaler value starting with 1.
    • 
        


        
This command sets the averaging prescaler for slow light signal related measurements like MEAS#?, MEAS#:CURR?, MEAS#:PDEN?. The whole number allows slowing down the measurement rate from max 1kHz with prescaler set to 1. When prescaler is set to 2, the Powermeter will always average 2 slow measurements and end in a 500Hz update rate. Other units of the MEAS system like MEAS#:FREQ?, MEAS#:TEMP? are not averaged with the given prescaler.              There is no prescaler for the fast measurement stream! Prescaler is only available for Photodiode in CW  measure mode.  

        
>> SENS:AVER 10

        
Photodiode in CW mode only.

        
Averaging is only applied to light measurements like Watt, Ampere, dBm.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:AVER?Gets the averaging for slow measurements
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:AVERage[:COUNt]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • presuint whole number prescaler value starting with 1.
    • 
        


        
This command gets the averaging prescaler for slow light signal related measurements. For closer details  read SENS#:AVER.

        
>> SENS:AVER?
<< 10

        
Photodiode in CW mode only.

        
Averaging is only applied to light measurements like Watt, Ampere.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:COND?Tests if sensor signal is within defined window
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CONDition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if signals is within the defined window. 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if the actual sensor signal stays within a previously defined value range. Use the command SENS#:POW:COND:LEV or SENS#:ENER:COND:LEV to change the window. You can also link a GPIO pin to reflect this flag using command SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC. You can also check for the Auxiliary register STAT:AUX:COND? window flag bit 2 and 3.

        
>> SENS:COND?
<< 0


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORRSets the light attenuation
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection[:LOSS[:INPut[:MAGNitude]]] 
<attenuation>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • attenuationfloat,MIN,DEF,MAX attenuation in dBm. MIN, DEF or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set attenuation of light in dBm. If your setup uses a filter in front of the sensor this attenuation ensures Powermeter displays corrected values.  Attenuation parameter is stored persistently and restored after reboot. If connected sensor is changed the parameter  is reset to 0.

        
>> SENS:CORR 0.1


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR?Gets the light attenuation
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection[:LOSS[:INPut[:MAGNitude]]]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN or MAX to query special attenuation values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • attenuationfloat attenuation in dBm
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query attenuation of light in dBm. If your setup uses a filter in front of the sensor this attenuation ensures Powermeter displays corrected values.  Attenuation parameter is stored persistently and restored after reboot.  If connected sensor is changed the parameter is reset to 0. 

        
>> SENS:CORR?
<< 0.1


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:BEAMSets the beam diameter
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:BEAMdiameter 
<diam>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • diamfloat,MIN,DEF,MAX circular beam diameter in mm. MIN, DEF or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the circular beam diameter in mm. The beam diameter is used to  calculate power and energy density values. If you have other beam shapes you have to calculate the matching diameter for a circle with the same area manually. Beam diameter is stored persistently  and restored after reboot. If connected sensor type gets changed, defaults are applied. If the  sensor type stays same the parameter gets coerced automatically. 

        
>> SENS:BEAM 1.5

        
In your setup ensure the beam hits the entire sensor area. Parameter range depend on connected sensor aperture.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:BEAM?Gets the beam diameter
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:BEAMdiameter? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN,DEF or MAX to query special beam diameter values
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • beamdiameterfloat circular beam diameter in mm.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to get the circular beam diameter in mm. The beam diameter is used to  calculate power and energy density values.  If you have other beam shapes you have to calculate the matching diameter for a circle with the same area manually. Beam diameter is stored persistently and restored after reboot.

        
>> SENS:BEAM?
<< 1.5

        
In your setup ensure the beam hits the entire sensor area. Parameter range depend on connected sensor aperture.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COEF:BETASets external thermistor equation Beta parameter
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COEFficient:BETA 
<beta>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint external NTC channel number 5 for NTC1 or 6 for NTC2. Default is 5.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • betafloat,MIN,MAX,AUTO Beta value. MIN, DEF or MAX for special parameters.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the Beta parameter being part of the external NTC temperature calculation. To parameter value depends on the used thermistor. A wrong parameter value results in a wrong temperature measurement. To get the temperature measurement result use SENS#:TEMP:DATA?. 

        
>> SENS:CORR:COEF:BETA 3988


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COEF:BETA?Sets external thermistor equation Beta parameter
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COEFficient:BETA?  
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint external NTC channel number 5 for NTC1 or 6 for NTC2. Default is 5.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! Nothing to query actual value. MIN, MAX or DEF for special values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • betafloat thermistor beat parameter.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the Beta parameter being part of the external NTC temperature calculation. The parameter value depends on the used thermistor. A wrong parameter value results in a wrong temperature measurement. To get the temperature measurement result use SENS#:TEMP:DATA?. 

        
>> SENS:CORR:COEF:BETA?
<< 3988


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COEF:RESSets external thermistor equation R0 parameter
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COEFficient:RESistance 
<resist>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint external NTC channel number 5 for NTC1 or 6 for NTC2. Default is 5.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • resistfloat,MIN,MAX,AUTO R0 Resistance in Ohm. MIN, DEF or MAX for special parameters.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the R0 parameter in Ohm being part of the external NTC temperature calculation. To parameter value depends on the used thermistor. A wrong parameter value results in a wrong temperature measurement. To get the temperature measurement result use SENS#:TEMP:DATA?. 

        
>> SENS:CORR:COEF:RES 10000


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COEF:RES?Gets external thermistor equation R0 parameter
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COEFficient:RESistance? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint external NTC channel number 5 for NTC1 or 6 for NTC2. Default is 5.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! Nothing to query actual value in Ohm. MIN, MAX or DEF for special values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • R0float thermistor R0 parameter in Ohm.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the R0 parameter in Ohm being part of the external NTC temperature calculation. To parameter value depends on the used thermistor. A wrong parameter value results in a wrong temperature measurement. To get the temperature measurement result use SENS#:TEMP:DATA?. 

        
>> SENS:CORR:COEF:RES?
<< 10000


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZEROStarts a zeroing of the sensor
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COLLect:ZERO[:INITiate]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to start a dark current or voltage correction of sensor. Before starting the correction ensure light source is not hitting the sensor area and the sensor is completely covered. This command only starts the zeroing procedure running in background. During zero procedure, measuring is not possible. To test if zeroing is still running use SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:STAT? or poll for Zeroing flag in STAT:OPER:COND?. If sensor is not completely covered zeroing procedure may time out automatically with an error code. If you want to abort previously started procedure use the SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:ABOR command. If zeroing is complete (by error or success) you may want to test for error using SYST:ERR? command. To make relative measurements compared to ambient light use delta mode commands like SENS#:POW:REF because maximal zero correction parameter is limited to a small current. If you want to set a custom zero value use SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:MAGN command. You may check for zeroing flag bit 7 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see zeroing is ongoing.

        
>> SENS:CORR:COLL:ZERO

        
Do not use zeroing to make relative measurements compared to ambient light. Zeroing is only available for Photodiode in CW mode.

        
Best practice is to cover the entire sensor aperture during zero procedure.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:ABORAborts previously started zeroing procedure
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COLLect:ZERO:ABORt

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to abort a previously started zeroing. The zeroing of sensor is running as asynchronous background operation. Aborting the sequence will end the background operation and enables measuring with the old zero value. To start a new zeroing use SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO command.

        
>> SENS:CORR:COLL:ABOR

        
Zeroing is only available for Photodiode in CW mode.

        
Aborting if zeroing is already complete or has never been started has no effect.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:MAGNSets zero correction to a given value
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COLLect:ZERO:MAGNitude 
<zero>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • zerofloat,MIN,MAX,DEF zero current in Ampere. MIN, DEF or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the zero correction value in Ampere. Setting zero directly will not  start the asynchronous zeroing procedure. In most cases you want the Powermeter to measure zero itself  using SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO command. To make relative measurements compared to ambient light use delta mode commands  like SENS#:POW:REF because maximal zero correction parameter is limited to a small current. Zero parameter is not stored persistently. It will be lost after reboot!

        
>> SENS:CORR:COLL:ZERO:MAGN 0

        
Zero parameter is only accessible for Photodiode in CW mode.

        
Set to 0 to disable zero correction.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:MAGN?Queries the zero correction value
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COLLect:ZERO:MAGNitude? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN, MAX or DEF to query special zero values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • zerofloat zero current in Ampere.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to get the zero correction value in Ampere. To update the zero value you can either call SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO or the SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:MAGN command. Zero parameter is not stored persistently.  It will be lost after reboot!

        
>> SENS:CORR:COLL:ZERO:MAGN?
<< 1.234e-4

        
Zero parameter is only accessible for Photodiode in CW mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:STAT?Tests if zeroing procedure is running
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:COLLect:ZERO:STATe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 0 if no zeroing is running, 1 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if previously started zeroing procedure is running in background. The zeroing of sensor is running as asynchronous background operation. The zeroing will terminate automatically in case of error or success. Once terminated this command will return 0. If no zeroing has been started the command will also return 0. Another way to test if zeroing is complete is to poll for zeroing flag bit 7 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND?.

        
>> SENS:CORR:COLL:STATe
<< 1

        
Zeroing is only available for Photodiode in CW mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:CSET:POINSets customer calibration set point tuples
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:CSET:POINts 
<wavelength1>
,
<factor1>
,
<wavelength2>
,
<factor2>
,
<wavelength3>
,
<factor3>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • wavelength1uint wavelength in nm.
    • 
              
  • factor1float correction factor between 0.8 and 1.2.
    • 
           
  • wavelength2uint Optional! wavelength in nm. Needs to be larger than previous wavelength.
    • 
           
  • factor2float Optional! correction factor between 0.8 and 1.2.
    • 
           
  • wavelength3uint Optional! wavelength in nm. Needs to be larger than previous wavelength.
    • 
           
  • factor3float Optional! correction factor between 0.8 and 1.2.
    • 
        


        
Use this as the second command of the command sequence to write the custom calibration to inject the tuple list for the correction wavelength factor. The command sequence of writing a customer calibration is SENS#:CORR:CSET:PRE, SENS#:CORR:CSET:POIN and SENS#:CORR:CSET#:DEF. To enable the new configuration use SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT and reboot the device or send the command: SENS#:REI. The command supports a variable parameter list length. Every correction can store up to to 10 wavelength - factor tuples. The command may be called with multiple tuples at once. The wavelength needs to be strictly ascending starting with the lowest. 
The factor can be determined with a comparison measurement with a known wavelength and power level. Best practice is to average some measurements, performed with the commands SENS#:AVER 300 and MEAS#?. (the example shows an averaging of 300) The factor can then be calculated with the formula factor = avgMeasPower / refPower.

        
>> SENS1:CORR:CSET:POIN 400,1.1,450,1.1,500,1.1,550,1.1

        
Second command of customer calibration command sequence. Next is SENS#:CORR:CSET#:DEF.

        
A maximum of 10 set points tuples are allowed. Only tuples of ascending wavelength and factor allowed.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:CSET:PREStarts updating customer calibration by writing slot meta information
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:CSET:PREamble 
<serial>
,
<calDate>
,
<author>
,
<filterPos>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • serialstring serial number of the related sensor. Max 19 characters.
    • 
              
  • calDatestring date of calibration. Max 19 characters.
    • 
              
  • authorstring author of calibration. Max 19 characters.
    • 
              
  • filterPos1 or 2 for related sensor filter position the correction is for.
    • 
        


        
Use this as first command of the customer calibration write command sequence to start writing the correction meta information. The command sequence of writing a customer calibration is SENS1:CORR:CSET:PRE, SENS#:CORR:CSET:POIN and SENS#:CORR:CSET#:DEF. To enable the new configuration use SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT and reboot device or send command SENS#:REI. After storing the meta information it is  mandatory to add at least one wavelength set point by using SENS#:CORR:CSET:POIN. To get the serial of the connected sensor call SYST:SENS#:IDN?. 

        
>> SENS1:CORR:CSET:PRE "191113108","2021-11-28","test",1

        
First command of customer calibration command sequence. Next is SENS#:CORR:CSET:POIN.

        
To delete a customer calibration use empty strings. For example SENSe1:CORR:CSET:PRE "","","",1.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:CSET#:DEFStores previously configured customer calibration in persistent memory
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:CSET
#
:DEFine

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
          
  • Sufix 2uint customer calibration memory slot between 1 and 4.
    • 
        


        
Stores the previously configured customer calibration object stored in volatile memory to persistent Powermeter storage. Only when stored persistently the correction object ready for usage. The command sequence of writing a customer calibration is  SENS#:CORR:CSET:PRE, SENS#:CORR:CSET:POIN and SENS1:CORR:CSET3:DEF. To enable the  new configuration use SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT and reboot device or send  command SENS#:REI.

        
>> SENS1:CORR:CSET3:DEF

        
Third command of customer calibration command sequence. Next is SENS#:REI.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:CSET#:POIN?Returns customer calibration set point tuples
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:CSET
#
:POINts?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
          
  • Sufix 2uint customer calibration memory slot between 1 and 4.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • wavelength1uint wavelength in nm.
    • 
          
  • factor1float correction factor between 0.8 and 1.2.
    • 
          
  • wavelength2uint wavelength in nm.
    • 
          
  • factor2float correction factor between 0.8 and 1.2.
    • 
          
  • wavelength3uint wavelength in nm.
    • 
          
  • factor3float correction factor between 0.8 and 1.2.
    • 
        


        
Call this command to query the customer calibration set points tuples. The result tuple list length is variable. All tuples are returned at once.To get the amount of returned tuples call  SENS#:CORR:CSET#:PRE? previously or parse to the end. Be aware this function only access data in the persistent customer calibration storage. So if you called SENS#:CORR:CSET:POIN previously and the data has not yet been stored in  persistent memory by the command SENS#:CORR:CSET#:DEF, this command will return old  information!

        
>> SENS1:CORR:CSET3:POIN?
<< 400,1.1,450,1.1,500,1.1,550,1.1

        
A maximum of 10 set points tuples is possible. Wavelength is ascending starting with lowest first.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:CSET#:PRE?Returns customer calibration meta information of given slot
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:CSET
#
:PREamble?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
          
  • Sufix 2uint customer calibration memory slot between 1 and 4.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • serialstring serial number of the related sensor. Max 19 characters.
    • 
          
  • calDatestring date of calibration. Max 19 characters.
    • 
          
  • authorstring author of calibration. Max 19 characters.
    • 
          
  • filterPosuint 1 or 2 for related sensor filter position the correction is for.
    • 
          
  • setPointsuint number of setpoins defined.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the customer calibration meta information. Be aware this function only access data in the persistent customer calibration storage. So if you called SENS#:CORR:CSET:PRE previously and the data has not yet been stored in  persistent memory by the command SENS#:CORR:CSET#:DEF, this command will return old  information!

        
>> SENS1:CORR:CSET3:PRE?
<< "191113108","2019-11-28","Musterman",1,2

        
If customer calibration is empty you get a result: "","","",0,0.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STATEnables/Disables customer calibration
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:CSET
#
:STATe 
<state>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
          
  • Sufix 2uint customer calibration memory slot between 1 and 4.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • statebool 1 to enable customer calibration. 0 to disable slot.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable/disable a customer calibration at given slot. The Powermeter stores up to 5 different customer calibrations. A customer calibration allows the customer to modify the sensor correction at  fixed wavelength set points. It is stored within the Powermeter and belongs to a single sensor identified by it's serial number. The factory calibration of the Powermeter and the sensor is not touched by the customer calibration. The Powermeter automatically applies the customer calibration if the related sensor is connected and the calibration is active. To test if a customer calibration is active and currently used  see UseCustomerCalibration flag bit 0 or 1 in STAT:AUX:COND?. The command sequence of writing a new customer calibration is SENS#:CORR:CSET:PRE,  SENS#:CORR:CSET:POIN and SENS#:CORR:CSET#:DEF. To enable the new configuration  use SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT and reboot device or send command SENS#:REI.

        
>> SENS1:CORR:CSET1:STAT 1

        
Be aware a wrong customer calibration will result in unexpected measurement results.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT?Tests if customer calibration is enabled/disabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:CSET
#
:STATe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
          
  • Sufix 2uint customer calibration memory slot between 1 and 4.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if customer calibration is enabled. 0 if slot is disabled.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if a customer calibration at given slot is enabled/disabled. For closer details read command SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT.

        
>> SENS1:CORR:CSET1:STAT?
<< 0

        
Be aware a wrong customer calibration will result in unexpected measurement results.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:ENERSets pyro sensor adapter responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:ENERgy[:PYRO][:RESPonse] 
<resp>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • respfloat,MIN,DEF,MAX Wavelength dependent responsivity in V/J. MIN, DEF or MAX for special parameters.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the pyro responsivity in V/J for pyro sensor adapters. The responsivity is used to calculate the energy based on the pyro voltage. The correct responsivity depends on the wavelength of the light. Adapters are sensor without head EEPROM. When working with adapters ensure the correct adapter type is selected by using INP#:ADAP. If you are working with a sensor with EEPROM use SENS#:CORR:WAV to change responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:ENER 0.09

        
Adapter sensors without EEPROM only!

        
Responsivity is a wavelength dependent value.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:ENER?Gets pyro sensor responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:ENERgy[:PYRO][:RESPonse]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialfloat, MIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! Nothing to query actual value in V/J. MIN, MAX or DEF for special values. Wavelength in nm to get the responsivity for (Not for adapters).
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • respfloat responsivity in V/J.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the pyro responsivity in V/J for pyro sensors with or without EEPROM. The wavelength related responsivity is used to calculate the energy based on the pyro voltage. Thorlabs pyro sensors store the responsivity curve internally. To query the EEPROM curve you can call this command multiple times with a wavelength in nm as parameter (Not for adapters). If no parameter is given the function returns the currently used responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:ENER?
<< 0.09


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:POWSets photodiode sensor adapter responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:POWer[:PDIode][:RESPonse] 
<resp>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • respfloat,MIN,DEF,MAX Wavelength dependent responsivity in A/W. MIN, DEF or MAX for special parameters.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the photodiode responsivity in A/W for photodiode sensor adapters. The responsivity is used to calculate the power based on the photodiode current. The correct responsivity depends on the light wavelength. Adapters are sensor without head EEPROM. When working with adapters ensure the correct adapter type is selected by using INP#:ADAP. If you are working with a sensor with EEPROM use SENS#:CORR:WAV to change responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:POW 1.34

        
Adapter sensors without EEPROM only!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:POW?Gets photodiode sensor responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:POWer[:PDIode][:RESPonse]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialfloat, MIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! Nothing to query actual value in A/W. MIN, MAX or DEF for special values. Wavelength in nm to get the responsivity for (Not for adapters).
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • respfloat responsivity in A/W.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the photodiode responsivity in A/W for photodiode sensors with or without EEPROM. The wavelength related responsivity is used to calculate the power based on the photodiode current. Thorlabs photodiode sensors store the responsivity curve internally. To query the EEPROM curve you can call this command multiple times with a wavelength in nm as parameter (Not for adapters). If no parameter is given the function returns the currently used responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:POW?
<< 1.34


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:POW:PDASets preamplified photodiode sensor adapter responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:POWer:PDA[:RESPonse] 
<resp>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • respfloat,MIN,DEF,MAX Wavelength dependent responsivity in V/W. MIN, DEF or MAX for special parameters.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the preamplified photodiode responsivity in V/W for thermopile sensor adapters. The responsivity is used to calculate the power based on the measured voltage. The correct responsivity depends on the wavelength of the light. Adapters are sensor without head EEPROM. When working with adapters ensure the correct adapter type is selected by using INP#:ADAP. If you are working with a sensor with EEPROM use SENS#:CORR:WAV to change responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:POW:PDA 1e-2

        
Adapter sensors without EEPROM only!

        
Responsivity is a wavelength dependent value.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:POW:PDA?Gets thermopile sensor responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:POWer:PDA[:RESPonse]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialfloat, MIN,DEF,MAX Optional! Nothing to query actual value in V/J. MIN, MAX or DEF for special values. Wavelength in nm to get the responsivity for (Not for adapters).
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • respfloat responsivity in V/W.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the preamplified photodiode responsivity in V/W for sensors with or without EEPROM. The wavelength related responsivity is used to calculate the power based on the measured voltage. To query the EEPROM curve you can call this command multiple times with a wavelength in nm as parameter (Not for adapters). If no parameter is given the function returns the currently used responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:POW:PDA?
<< 0.09


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:POW:THERSets thermopile sensor adapter responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:POWer:THERmopile[:RESPonse] 
<resp>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • respfloat,MIN,DEF,MAX Wavelength dependent responsivity in V/W. MIN, DEF or MAX for special parameters.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the thermopile responsivity in V/W for thermopile sensor adapters. The responsivity is used to calculate the power based on the thermopile voltage. The correct responsivity depends on the wavelength of the light. Adapters are sensor without head EEPROM. When working with adapters ensure the correct adapter type is selected by using INP#:ADAP. If you are working with a sensor with EEPROM use SENS#:CORR:WAV to change responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:POW:THER 1e-2

        
Adapter sensors without EEPROM only!

        
Responsivity is a wavelength dependent value.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:POW:THER?Gets thermopile sensor responsivity
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:POWer:THERmopile[:RESPonse]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialfloat, MIN,DEF,MAX Optional! Nothing to query actual value in V/J. MIN, MAX or DEF for special values. Wavelength in nm to get the responsivity for (Not for adapters).
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • respfloat responsivity in V/W.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the thermopile responsivity in V/W for thermopile sensors with or without EEPROM. The wavelength related responsivity is used to calculate the power based on the thermopile voltage. Thorlabs thermopile sensors store the responsivity curve internally. To query the EEPROM curve you can call this command multiple times with a wavelength in nm as parameter (Not for adapters). If no parameter is given the function returns the currently used responsivity.

        
>> SENS:CORR:POW:THER?
<< 0.09


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:WAVSets the wavelength
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:WAVelength 
<wavelength>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • wavelengthuint,MIN,MAX wavelength as whole number in nm. MIN or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set wavelength of light in nm. Wavelength is used to calculate sensor responsivity. If you are using adapter sensors you have to set responsivity directly for example using SENS#:CORR:POW. Wavelength parameter is stored persistently and restored after reboot.  If connected sensor type get changed, defaults are applied. If the sensor type stays same the parameter gets coerced automatically. 

        
>> SENS:CORR:WAV 850

        
Only supported for sensor heads with EEPROM. Adapter types have to set responsivity directly.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CORR:WAV?Gets the wavelength
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CORRection:WAVelength? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN or MAX to query special wavelength values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • wavelengthfloat wavelength in nm
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the wavelength in nm. If you are using adapter sensors you have to get responsivity directly using SENS#:CORR:POW?. Wavelength parameter is stored persistently and restored after reboot.  If connected sensor type get changed, defaults are applied. If the sensor type stays same the parameter gets coerced automatically. 

        
>> SENS:CORR:WAV? MIN
<< 1020

        
Only supported for sensor heads with EEPROM. Adapter types have to get responsivity directly.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:RANGSets a measurement range for given current
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer] 
<current>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • currentfloat,MIN,MAX Set gain to measure given current best. MIN or MAX for most or least sensitive gain.
    • 
        


        
This command sets a manual range for given current in Ampere. Setting a manual range will automatically disable auto ranging see SENS#:CURR:RANG:AUTO. Changing the measurement range will always interrupt the measurement for up to 10 milliseconds to allow the analogue hardware to settle. After this time measurement is continued automatically. For MIN you set the most sensitive gain level. For MAX you set least sensitive gain level. Manual range is stored persistently and gets restored after reboot. You may check for ranging flag bit 2 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if ranging is complete.

        
>> SENS:CURR:RANG 2.56e-5

        
Photodiode sensors only!

        
Setting a manual range automatically disables auto ranging. See SENS#:CURR:RANG:AUTO.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:RANG?Returns measurement range for current measurement
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer]? 
<current>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • currentfloat,MIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! current to get range maximum for. Special parameter to query special range info.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • rangeMaxfloat maximum current in Ampere supported by measurement range. For special parameter AUTO it will be a list.
    • 
        


        
This command returns measurement range information for current measurement in Ampere. If no parameter has been provided the actual used range maximal current is returned. When called with a current in Ampere float parameter the function will return the measurement range maximum fitting given current best. The following special parameters may be used: 
     
  • MIN maximum current, supported by the most sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • MAX maximum current, supported by the least sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • AUTO list of maximum current for all measurement ranges. Starts with the least sensitive gain level.
    •  

        
>> SENS:CURR:RANG? MAX
<< 9.93-e5

        
Photodiode sensors only!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:RANG:AUTOSets current measurement auto ranging
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:RANGe:AUTO 
<state>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • statebool 1 to enable auto ranging, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
This command enables or disables auto ranging feature for current measurement. If auto ranging is active the Powermeter compares the measured signal to the currently used measure range. If the signal is out of optimal range, the Powermeter automatically changes the measurement range. Changing the measurement range will always interrupt the measurement for up to 10 milliseconds to allow the analogue hardware to settle. After this time measurement is continued automatically. Auto ranging is not available for Pyro and Photodiode in PEAK mode. In this case you may want to run the SENS#:PEAK:SEAR command. You can ask for the actual range by using command SENS#:CURR:RANG?. If you set a manual range like command SENS#:CURR:RANG auto ranging gets disabled automatically. Auto range enable state is stored persistently and restored after reboot. If you change sensor type auto ranging is enabled by default. You may check for ranging flag bit 2 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if ranging took place complete.

        
>> SENS:CURR:RANG:AUTO 1

        
Auto ranging is not available for Pyro and Photodiode in PEAK mode.

        
For scope mode it makes sense to disable auto ranging to get a seamless result stream.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:RANG:AUTO?Tests if current auto ranging is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:RANGe:AUTO?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if auto ranging is active, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
This command tests if auto ranging is enabled for current measurement. For closer details read SENS#:CURR:RANG:AUTO. You can query the currently used range by using SENS#:CURR:RANG?. Auto range enable state is stored persistently and restored after reboot.

        
>> SENS:CURR:RANG:AUTO?
<< 0

        
Auto ranging is not available for Pyro and Photodiode in PEAK mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:RANG:SEARSearches for a range fitting actual CW current signal best
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:RANGe:SEARch

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
This command enables auto ranging until a stable range has been found. Then auto ranging is disabled again. Use this command to automatically search for a best fitting range after changing the input signal. If auto ranging was enabled previously it will be disabled afterwards. Of cause the command requires a stable CW signal during the search. You can query the currently used range by using SENS#:CURR:RANG?. A similar function is available for Pyro and Photodiode in Peak measure mode. See SENS#:PEAK:SEAR command. Resulting range is stored persistently and will be restored after reboot.

        
>> SENS:CURR:RANG:SEAR

        
The function can block remote interface for multiple seconds. Only supported for Photodiode in CW mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:REFSets relative current measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:REFerence 
<refCurr>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • refCurrfloat,MIN,MAX,DEF reference current in Ampere. MIN, DEF or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to define a current offset in Ampere for relative measurements. To switch to relative measurements ensure delta mode is also enabled by SENS#:CURR:REF:STAT.  All non zero parameter values result in a relative measurement. To get relative measurement results call MEAS#:CURR? afterwards. The fast measurement stream does not support relative measurements.  Relative current offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:CURR:REF 0.3

        
Delta current measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:REF?Gets relative current measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:REFerence? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN, MAX or DEF to query special offset values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • refCurrfloat reference current in Ampere.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the actual current offset in Ampere for relative measurements. Even if a non zero offset has been set it will not be used until delta mode is enabled by command SENS#:CURR:REF:STAT. Relative current offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:CURR:REF?
<< 0.3

        
Delta current measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:REF:STATEnables current delta mode
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:REFerence:STATe 
<enable>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool 1 to enable delta mode, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable current delta mode. If delta mode is enabled and a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:CURR:REF previously, MEAS#:CURR? will return relative measurements. If  delta mode gets disabled again the measurement command will return absolute measurements again even if a non zero offset has been set previously. Delta mode is always disabled after reboot or sensor change.

        
>> SENS:CURR:REF:STAT 1

        
Delta current measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:CURR:REF:STAT?Tests if current delta mode is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:CURRent[:DC]:REFerence:STATe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • enablebool 1 if delta mode enabled, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if current delta mode is enabled. If delta mode is enabled and  a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:CURR:REF previously, MEAS#:CURR? will return relative  measurements.

        
>> SENS:CURR:REF:STAT?
<< 1

        
Delta current measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:COND:LEVSets energy signal valid window
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy[:DC]:CONDition:LEVel 
<min>
, 
<max>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • minfloat minimal valid power value in Watt.
    • 
              
  • maxfloat maximal valid power value in Watt.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to define the energy value interval (window) within the measured signal is detected as valid. The PM uses 5 percent hysteresis if the window has been left until it shows valid again. You can also link a GPIO pin to reflect this flag using command SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC.

        
>> SENS:ENER:COND:LEV 0, 1e-3

        
If signal stays within defined interval can be monitored in software and hardware by GPIO pin.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:COND:LEV?Queries energy signal valid window
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy[:DC]:CONDition:LEVel?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • minfloat minimal valid energy value in Joule.
    • 
          
  • maxfloat maximal valid energy value in Joule.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the energy value interval (window) within the measured signal is detected as valid. For closer details read command SENS#:COND?.

        
>> SENS:ENER:COND:LEV?
<< 0, 1e-3

        
If signal stays within defined interval can be monitored in software and hardware by GPIO pin.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:RANGSets a measurement range for given energy
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy:RANGe[:UPPer] 
<energy>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • energyfloat,MIN,MAX Set gain to measure given energy best. MIN or MAX for most or least sensitive gain.
    • 
        


        
This command sets a manual range for given energy in J. Changing the measurement range will always interrupt the measurement for up to 10 milliseconds to allow the analogue hardware to settle. After this time measurement is continued automatically. For MIN you set the most sensitive gain level. For MAX you set least sensitive gain level. Manual range is stored persistently and gets restored after reboot. You may check for ranging flag bit 2 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if ranging took place complete.

        
>> SENS:ENER:RANG 2.56e-5

        
Pyro only!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:RANG?Returns measurement range for energy measurement
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy:RANGe[:UPPer]? 
<energy>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • energyfloat,MIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! energy to get range maximum for. Special parameter to query special range info.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • rangeMaxfloat maximum energy in Joule supported by measurement range. For special parameter AUTO it will be a list.
    • 
        


        
This command returns measurement range information for energy measurement in J. If no parameter has been provided the actual used range maximum energy is returned. When called with an energy in Joule float parameter the function will return the measurement range maximum fitting given energy best. The following special parameters may be used: 
     
  • MIN maximum energy, supported by the most sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • MAX maximum energy, supported by the least sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • AUTO list of maximum energy for all measurement ranges. Starts with the least sensitive gain level.
    •  

        
>> SENS:ENER:RANG? MIN
<< 0.98e-5

        
Pyro only!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:REFSets relative energy measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy:REFerence 
<refEner>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • refEnerfloat,MIN,MAX,DEF reference energy in Joule. MIN, DEF or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to define an energy offset in Joule for relative measurements. To switch to relative measurements ensure delta mode is also enabled by SENS#:ENER:REF:STAT.  All non zero parameter values result in a relative measurement. To get relative measurement results call MEAS#:ENER? afterwards. The fast measurement stream does not support relative measurements.  Relative energy offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:ENER:REF 2

        
Delta energy measurement is only available for Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:REF?Gets relative energy measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy:REFerence? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN, MAX or DEF to query special offset values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • refEnerfloat reference energy in J.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the actual energy offset in Joule for relative measurements. Even if a non zero offset has been set it will not be used until delta mode is enabled by command SENS#:ENER:REF:STAT. Relative energy offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:ENER:REF?
<< 2
