Delta energy measurement is only available for Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:REF:STATEnables energy delta mode
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy:REFerence:STATe 
<enable>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool 1 to enable delta mode, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable energy delta mode. If delta mode is enabled and a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:ENER:REF previously, MEAS#:ENER? will return relative measurements. If  delta mode gets disabled again the measurement command will return absolute measurements again even if a non zero offset has been set previously. Delta mode is always disabled after reboot or sensor change.

        
>> SENS:ENER:REF:STAT 1

        
Delta energy measurement is only available for Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:ENER:REF:STAT?Tests if energy delta mode is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:ENERgy:REFerence:STATe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • enablebool 1 if delta mode enabled, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if energy delta mode is enabled. If delta mode is enabled and  a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:ENER:REF previously, MEAS#:ENER? will return relative  measurements.

        
>> SENS:ENER:REF:STAT?
<< 1

        
Delta energy measurement is only available for Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:FREQ:MODEChanges measurement mode of photodiode between peak and continuos
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:FREQuency:MODE 
<mode>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • modeCW,PEAK photodiode measurement mode.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the measure mode of the photodiode sensor. The Powermeter can measure photodiode sensors in CW mode. This mode should be used for CW input signals. If you are measuring modulated signals like sinus, triangle or square in CW mode you are measuring the average power. If you are interested in the peak power you have to use the PEAK mode. This mode will only return a single measure result for every peak found. In CW mode the Powermeter will constantly output measure results. In PEAK mode the output depends on the input signal modulation frequency. PEAK mode requires the threshold and range parameters to be set manually by commands SENS#:PEAK and SENS#:POW:RANG or by using the peak finder algorithm SENS#:PEAK:SEAR. 

        
>> SENS:FREQ:MODE CW

        
Photodiode only!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:FREQ:MODE?Queries sensor measurement mode
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:FREQuency:MODE?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • modeCW,PEAK photodiode measurement mode.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the measurement method of the connected sensor. Pyro sensors always use the PEAK measurement method. Photodiode support CW and PEAK mode. For closer details read description of command SENS#:FREQ:MODE. 

        
>> SENS:FREQ:MODE?
<< CW


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:HUM:DATA?Returns the humidity of external I2C environmental sensor
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:HUMidity:DATA?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint 4 for I2C digital temperature sensor. Default is 4.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • humidityfloat last measured humidity in percent.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the recent measured humidity of the external I2C environmental sensor in percent.  The Powermeter updates the humdity at 2Hz. If you query the humidity faster you will  receive the same results multiple times. 

        
>> SENS:HUM:DATA?
<< 32.0233


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:PEAKSets peak detection and frequency measurement threshold
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:PEAKdetector[:THReshold] 
<perc>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • percuint, MIN, MAX, DEF percentage of actual measurement range. MIN, DEF or MAX for special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the peak detection threshold in percent. The percentage is relatively compared  to the actually used measurement range maximum value. For Pyro or modulated Photodiode signals the  Powermeter compares sensor signal to a threshold signal to decide if a new pulse has been found. If the threshold is too low noise floor may be detected as peak signals. If the threshold is too high  the Powermeter will not measure a single pulse. The threshold is also used for light modulation  frequency measurement MEAS#:FREQ?.  Be aware for pulsed signals auto ranging is not supported. You have to set a range manually using  for example command SENS#:VOLT:RANG. If you have a repetitive pulse signal you can also start the peak  finder background operation to let the Powermeter set range and threshold parameter automatically  by sending command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR.

        
>> SENS:PEAK 25


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:PEAK?Gets peak detection and frequency measurement threshold
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:PEAKdetector[:THReshold]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN, MAX or DEF to query special threshold values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • percuint percentage of actual measurement range.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the peak detection threshold in percent. For closer details about the threshold read SENS#:PEAK description.

        
>> SENS:PEAK?
<< 25


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:PEAK:FILTEnables overshoot filter for peak detection
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:PEAKdetector:FILTer 
<state>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • statespecial OVERshoot for overshoot filtering. NONE to disable filtering.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable or disable peak overshoot filter. If the filter is enabled, the Powermeter will filter Over- and Undershoots on the sensor signal during peak measurement. This is useful for Photodiode when measuring TTL signals. For any other modulation like sinus or triangle disable the filter. 

        
>> SENS:PEAK:FILT OVER

        
Only available for photodiode in PEAK mode.

        
Enable filter for TTL modulated light measurements using a photodiode.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:PEAK:FILT?Tests if overshoot filter for peak detection is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:PEAKdetector:FILTer?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statespecial OVERshoot for overshoot filtering. NONE to disable filtering.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if peak overshoot filter is enabled. If the filter is enabled, the Powermeter will filter over- and undershoots on the sensor signal during peak measurement. This is useful for Photodiode when measuring TTL signals. For any other modulation like sinus or triangle disable the filter. 

        
>> SENS:PEAK:FILT?
<< OVER

        
Only available for photodiode in PEAK mode.

        
Enable filter for TTL modulated light measurements using a photodiode.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:PEAK:SEARStarts or aborts the peak finder background operation
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:PEAKdetector:SEARch

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to start or abort the peak finder background algorithm. If the Powermeter receives this command it stops normal measurement and will try to find a measurement range and peak detection threshold fitting the pulsed input signal best asynchronously. You can use the command SENS#:PEAK:SEAR? or poll for the StatusPeakFinder flag in Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? to test if background operation terminated. The peak finder algorithm will always terminate even if no pulse has been detected. The peak finder algorithm is only available for repetitive pulsed input signals measured with Pyro or Photodiode in PEAK mode. To switch Photodiode to PEAK mode use SENS#:FREQ:MODE command. If you want to abort previously started procedure send the same command while peak finder is active. If peak finder is complete (by error or success) you may want to test for error using  SYST:ERR? command. You can use SENS#:PEAK? and for example SENS#:VOLT:RANG? to query the automatically set parameters later. A similar command is available for Photodiode in CW mode. See e.g. SENS#:POW:RANG:SEAR. You may check for peak finder flag bit 3 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if peak finder algorithm is running in background. .     

        
>> SENS:PEAK:SEAR

        
Only available for repetitive pulsed input signals measured by Pyro or Photodiode in PEAK mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:PEAK:SEAR?Tests if peak finder background operation is running
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:PEAKdetector:SEARch?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if peak finder is active, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if asynchronously running peak finder algorithms is running in background. You can also poll the  StatusPeakFinder flag in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND?. For more details about peak finder algorithm read  SENS#:PEAK:SEAR command description.

        
>> SENS:PEAK:SEAR?
<< 0

        
Only available for repetitive pulsed input signals measured by Pyro or Photodiode in PEAK mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POS:REFSets the beam position delta coordinate
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POSition:REFerence 
<x>
,
<y>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint channel the sensor head is connected to. Here always 1 (default).
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • xuint x beam position zero offset in um
    • 
              
  • yuint y beam position zero offset in um
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the the beam position delta coordinate in um. Setting delta directly will not start the asynchronous zeroing procedure. In most cases you want the Powermeter to measure delta reference itself using SENS#:POS:REF:COLL: command.  Delta parameter is not stored persistently. It will be lost after reboot!

        
>> SENS:POS:REF 0,0

        
This method is only available for 4 quadrant thermopile sensors.

        
Set to 0 to disable position zero correction.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POS:REF?Queries the beam position delta coordinate
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POSition:REFerence?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint channel the sensor head is connected to. Here always 1 (default).
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • xuint x beam position zero offset in um
    • 
          
  • yuint y beam position zero offset in um
    • 
        


        
Use this command to get beam position delta coordinate in um. To update the delta value you can either call SENS#:POS:REF:COLL: or the SENS#:POS:REF command.  Delta parameter is not stored persistently. It will be lost after reboot!

        
>> SENS:POS:REF?
<< -119,35

        
This method is only available for 4 quadrant thermopile sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POS:REF:COLL:Starts a position delta background measuremenof task
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POSition:REFerence:COLLect:[INITiate]

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint channel the sensor head is connected to. Here always 1 (default).
    • 
        


        
Use this command to start a background task to measure the actual beam position and use it as position delta in the future. Before starting the correction ensure light source is constantly hitting the sensor area. Position will float if no beam is hitting the sensor. This command only starts the delta measurement procedure running in background for at least one second.  During this delta procedure, measuring is not possible. To test if this background task is  still running use SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO:STAT? or poll for Zeroing flag in STAT:OPER:COND?.  If you want to abort previously started procedure use the SENS#:POS:REF:COLL:ABOR command. If delta is complete (by error or success) you may want to test for error using SYST:ERR? command. If you want to set a custom delta value use SENS#:POS:REF command.  Delta parameter is not stored persistently. It will be lost after reboot!

        
>> SENS:POS:REF:COLL

        
This method is only available for 4 quadrant thermopile sensors.

        
Best practice is to measure delta beam position with constant signal on sensor.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POS:REF:COLL:ABORAborts previously started position delta measuring background process
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POSition:REFerence:COLLect:ABORt

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint channel the sensor head is connected to. Here always 1 (default).
    • 
        


        
Use this command to abort a previously started position delta measuring background process.  Aborting the sequence will end the background operation and enables measuring with the old position delta value. To start a new delta measurement use SENS#:POS:REF:COLL: command.

        
>> SENS:POS:REF:COLL:ABOR

        
This method is only available for 4 quadrant thermopile sensors.

        
Aborting if zeroing is already complete or has never been started has no effect.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:COND:LEVSets power signal valid window
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:CONDition:LEVel 
<min>
, 
<max>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • minfloat minimal valid power value in Watt.
    • 
              
  • maxfloat maximal valid power value in Watt.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to define the power value interval (window) within the measured signal is detected as valid. The PM uses 5 percent hysteresis if the window has been left until it shows valid again. You can also link a GPIO pin to reflect this flag using command SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC.

        
>> SENS:POW:COND:LEV 0, 1e-3

        
If signal stays within defined interval can be monitored in software and hardware by GPIO pin.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:COND:LEV?Queries power signal valid window
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:CONDition:LEVel?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • minfloat minimal valid power value in Watt.
    • 
          
  • maxfloat maximal valid power value in Watt.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the power value interval (window) within the measured signal is detected as valid.

        
>> SENS:POW:COND:LEV?
<< 0, 1e-3

        
If signal stays within defined interval can be monitored in software and hardware by GPIO pin.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:RANGSets a measurement range for given power
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer] 
<power>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • powerfloat,MIN,MAX Set gain to measure given power best. MIN or MAX for most or least sensitive gain.
    • 
        


        
This command sets a manual range for given power in W. Setting a manual range will automatically disable auto ranging see SENS#:POW:RANG:AUTO. Changing the measurement range will always interrupt the measurement for up to 10 milliseconds to allow the analogue hardware to settle. After this time measurement is continued automatically. For MIN you set the most sensitive gain level. For MAX you set least sensitive gain level. Manual range is stored persistently and gets restored after reboot. You may check for ranging flag bit 2 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if ranging is complete.

        
>> SENS:CURR:RANG 2.56e-5

        
Photodiode and Thermopile sensors only!

        
Setting a manual range automatically disables auto ranging. See SENS#:POW:RANG:AUTO.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:RANG?Returns measurement range for power measurement
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer]? 
<power>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • powerfloat,MIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! power to get range maximum for. Special parameter to query special range info.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • rangeMaxfloat maximum power in Watt supported by measurement range. For special parameter AUTO it will be a list.
    • 
        


        
This command returns measurement range information for power measurement in Watt. If no parameter has been provided the actual used range maximum power is returned. When called with a power in Watt float parameter the function will return the measurement range maximum fitting given power best. The following special parameters may be used: 
     
  • MIN maximum power, supported by the most sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • MAX maximum power, supported by the least sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • AUTO list of maximum power for all measurement ranges. Starts with the least sensitive gain level.
    •  

        
>> SENS:POW:RANG? 2-e5
<< 3.23-e5

        
Photodiode and Thermopile sensors only!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:RANG:AUTOSets power measurement auto ranging
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:RANGe:AUTO 
<state>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • statebool 1 to enable auto ranging, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
This command enables or disables auto ranging feature for power measurement. If auto ranging is active the Powermeter compares the measured signal to the currently used measure range. If the signal is out of optimal range, the Powermeter automatically changes the measurement range. Changing the measurement range will always interrupt the measurement for up to 10 milliseconds to allow the analogue hardware to settle. After this time measurement is continued automatically. Auto ranging is not available for Pyro and Photodiode in PEAK mode. In this case you may want to run the SENS#:PEAK:SEAR command. You can ask for the actual range by using command SENS#:POW:RANG?. If you set an manual range like command SENS#:POW:RANG auto ranging gets disabled automatically. Auto range enable state is stored persistently and restored after reboot. If you change sensor type auto ranging is enabled by default. You may check for ranging flag bit 2 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if ranging took place complete.

        
>> SENS:POW:RANG:AUTO 1

        
Auto ranging is not available for Pyro and Photodiode in PEAK mode.

        
For scope mode it makes sense to disable auto ranging to get a seamless result stream.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:RANG:AUTO?Tests if power auto ranging is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:RANGe:AUTO?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if auto ranging is active, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
This command tests if auto ranging is enabled for power measurement. For closer details read SENS#:POW:RANG:AUTO. You can query the currently used range by using SENS#:POW:RANG?. Auto range enable state is stored persistently and restored after reboot.

        
>> SENS:POW:RANG:AUTO?
<< 0

        
Auto ranging is not available for Pyro and Photodiode in PEAK mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:RANG:SEARSearches for a range fitting actual CW power signal best
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:RANGe:SEARch

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
This command enables auto ranging until a stable range has been found. Then auto ranging is disabled again. Use this command to automatically search for a best fitting range after changing the input signal. If auto ranging was enabled previously it will be disabled afterwards. The command requires a stable CW signal during the search. You can query the currently used range by using SENS#:POW:RANG?. A similar function is available for Pyro and Photodiode in Peak measure mode. See SENS#:PEAK:SEAR command. Resulting range is stored persistently and will be restored after reboot.

        
>> SENS:POW:RANG:SEAR

        
The function can block remote interface for multiple seconds. Only supported for Photodiode in CW mode.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:REFSets relative power measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:REFerence 
<refPow>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • refPowfloat,MIN,MAX,DEF reference power in W. MIN, DEF or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to define a power offset in Watt for relative measurements. To switch to relative measurements ensure delta mode is also enabled by SENS#:POW:REF:STAT.  All non zero parameter values result in a relative measurement. To get relative measurement results call MEAS#? afterwards. The fast measurement stream does not support relative measurements.  Relative power offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:POW:REF 2

        
Delta power measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:REF?Gets relative power measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:REFerence? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN, MAX or DEF to query special offset values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • refPowfloat reference power in W.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the actual power offset in Watt for relative measurements. Even if a non zero offset has been set it will not be used until delta mode is enabled by command SENS#:POW:REF:STAT. Relative power offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:POW:REF?
<< 2

        
Delta power measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:REF:STATEnables power delta mode
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:REFerence:STATe 
<enable>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool 1 to enable delta mode, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable power delta mode. If delta mode is enabled and a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:POW:REF previously, MEAS#? will return relative measurements. If  delta mode gets disabled again the measurement command will return absolute measurements again even if a non zero offset has been set previously. Delta mode is always disabled after reboot or sensor change.

        
>> SENS:POW:REF:STAT 1

        
Delta power measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:REF:STAT?Tests if power delta mode is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:REFerence:STATe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • enablebool 1 if delta mode enabled, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if power delta mode is enabled. If delta mode is enabled and  a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:POW:REF previously, MEAS#:CURR? will return relative  measurements.

        
>> SENS:POW:REF:STAT?
<< 1

        
Delta power measurement is only available for Photodiode sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:UNITSelects the power unit
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:UNIT 
<unit>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • unitW, DBM choose power unit between Watt or dBm.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the power unit between Watt and dBm. The unit affects the results of the  MEAS#? command. The fast measurement stream does not support dBm unit!

        
>> SENS:POW:UNIT DBM


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:POW:UNIT?Returns the power unit
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:POWer[:DC]:UNIT?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • unitW, DBM power unit.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the actual used power unit. For closer details read command  SENS#:POW:UNIT.

        
>> SENS:POW:UNIT?
<< DBM


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:REIReconnect connected sensor
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:REInit

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to reconnect the connected sensor. The command simulates a unplug and plug in of the sensor connector. This final step is mandatory after changing the customer calibration for the sensor currently plugged in. Calling this command will interrupt the ongoing measurement.

        
>> SENS:REI


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:RES:DATA?Returns the resistance of external NTC
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:RESistance:DATA?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint external NTC channel number 5 for NTC1 or 6 for NTC2. Default is 5.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • resistancefloat last measured resistance in Ohm.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the recent measured resistance of the external NTC in Ohm.  The Powermeter updates the resistance at 5Hz. If you query the resistance faster you will  receive the same resistance multiple times. To query the sensor head resistance use MEAS#:RES?. If you use a special NTC temperature sensor ensure Beta SENS#:CORR:COEF:BETA? and R0 SENS#:CORR:COEF:RES? parameters are correct. To get the external NTC temperature use SENS#:TEMP:DATA?.

        
>> SENS:RES:DATA?
<< 5988.23


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:RSTResets single measure channel to defaults
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:RST

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to reset a single measure channel to defaults. To reset the entire device use RST.

        
>> SENS:REI


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:TEMP:DATA?Returns the temperature of external NTC or I2C environmental sensor
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:TEMPerature:DATA?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint external NTC channel number 5 for NTC1, 6 for NTC2 or 3 for I2C digital temperature sensor. Default is 5.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • temperaturefloat last measured temperature in degree Celsius.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the recent measured temperature of the external NTC or external environmental sensor in degree Celsius. The Powermeter updates the NTC temperature at 5Hz and the environmental sensor at 2Hz. If you query the temperature faster you will receive the same temperature multiple times. To query the sensor head temperature use MEAS#:TEMP?. If you use a special NTC temperature sensor ensure Beta SENS#:CORR:COEF:BETA? and R0 SENS#:CORR:COEF:RES? parameters are correct. To get the external NTC resistance use SENS#:RES:DATA?. Before calling this function you may check if the NTC is connected by reading Auxiliary register STAT:AUX:COND? and check for NTC connected flag bit 4 and 5.

        
>> SENS:TEMP:DATA?
<< 21.32


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:RANGSets a measurement range for given voltage
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer] 
<voltage>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • voltagefloat,MIN,MAX Set gain to measure given voltage best. MIN or MAX for most or least sensitive gain.
    • 
        


        
This command sets a manual range for given voltage in W. Changing the measurement range will always interrupt the measurement for up to 10 milliseconds to allow the analogue hardware to settle. After this time measurement is continued automatically. For MIN you set the most sensitive gain level. For MAX you set least sensitive gain level. Manual range is stored persistently and gets restored after reboot. You may check for ranging flag bit 2 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if ranging took place complete.

        
>> SENS:CURR:RANG 2.56e-5

        
Pyro and Thermopile sensors only!

        
Setting a manual range automatically disables auto ranging for Thermopile. See SENS#:VOLT:RANG:AUTO.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:RANG?Returns measurement range for voltage measurement
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage[:DC]:RANGe[:UPPer]? 
<voltage>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • voltagefloat,MIN,MAX,AUTO Optional! voltage to get range maximum for. Special parameter to query special range info.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • rangeMaxfloat maximum voltage in Volt supported by measurement range. For special parameter AUTO it will be a list.
    • 
        


        
This command returns measurement range information for voltage measurement in Volt. If no parameter has been provided the actual used range maximum voltage is returned. When called with a voltage float parameter the function will return the measurement range maximum fitting given voltage best. The following special parameters may be used: 
     
  • MIN maximum voltage, supported by the most sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • MAX maximum voltage, supported by the least sensitive gain level.
    •  
  • AUTO list of maximum voltage for all measurement ranges. Starts with the least sensitive gain level.
    •  

        
>> SENS:VOLT:RANG? AUTO
<< 98, 0.98, 0.98e-1, 0.98e-2, 0.98e-3, 0.98e-4, 0.98e-5

        
Pyro and Thermopile sensors only!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:RANG:AUTOSets voltage measurement auto ranging
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage[:DC]:RANGe:AUTO 
<state>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • statebool 1 to enable auto ranging, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
This command enables or disables auto ranging feature for thermopile voltage measurement. If auto ranging is active the Powermeter compares the measured signal to the currently used measure range. If the signal is out of optimal range, the Powermeter automatically changes the measurement range. Changing the measurement range will always interrupt the measurement for up to 10 milliseconds to allow the analogue hardware to settle. After this time measurement is continued automatically. Auto ranging is not available for Pyro sensors. In this case you may want to run the SENS#:PEAK:SEAR command. You can ask for the actual range by using command SENS#:VOLT:RANG?. If you set an manual range like command SENS#:VOLT:RANG auto ranging gets disabled automatically. Auto range enable state is stored persistently and restored after reboot. If you change sensor type auto ranging is enabled by default. You may check for ranging flag bit 2 in the Operation Status register STAT:OPER:COND? so see if ranging took place complete.

        
>> SENS2:VOLT:RANG:AUTO 1

        
Auto ranging is not available for Pyro!

        
For scope mode it makes sense to disable auto ranging to get a seamless result stream.

      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:RANG:AUTO?Tests if voltage auto ranging is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage[:DC]:RANGe:AUTO?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 if auto ranging is active, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
This command tests if auto ranging is enabled for voltage measurement. For closer details read SENS#:VOLT:RANG:AUTO. You can query the currently used range by using SENS#:VOLT:RANG?. Auto range enable state is stored persistently and restored after reboot.

        
>> SENS2:VOLT:RANG:AUTO?
<< 0

        
Auto ranging is not available for Pyro!


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:REFSets relative voltage measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage[:DC]:REFerence 
<refVolt>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • refVoltfloat,MIN,MAX,DEF reference energy in W. MIN, DEF or MAX to set special values.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to define a voltage offset in Volt for relative measurements. To switch to relative measurements ensure delta mode is also enabled by SENS#:VOLT:REF:STAT.  All non zero parameter values result in a relative measurement. To get relative measurement results call MEAS#:VOLT? afterwards. The fast measurement stream does not support relative measurements.  Relative voltage offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:VOLT:REF 2

        
Delta voltage measurement is only available for Thermopile and Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:REF?Gets relative voltage measurement offset
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage[:DC]:REFerence? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! nothing to query actual value. MIN, MAX or DEF to query special offset values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • refVoltfloat reference voltage Volt.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the actual voltage offset in Volt for relative measurements. Even if a non zero offset has been set it will not be used until delta mode is enabled by command SENS#:VOLT:REF:STAT. Relative voltage offset parameter is not stored persistently. It will be reset to zero after reboot!

        
>> SENS:VOLT:REF?
<< 2

        
Delta voltage measurement is only available for Thermopile and Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:REF:STATEnables voltage delta mode
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage:REFerence:STATe 
<enable>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool 1 to enable delta mode, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable voltage delta mode. If delta mode is enabled and a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:VOLT:REF previously, MEAS#:VOLT? will return relative measurements. If  delta mode gets disabled again the measurement command will return absolute measurements again even if a non zero offset has been set previously. Delta mode is always disabled after reboot or sensor change.

        
>> SENS:VOLT:REF:STAT 1

        
Delta voltage measurement is only available for Thermopile and Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

      

        SENS#:VOLT:REF:STAT?Tests if voltage delta mode is enabled
      

      

        
SENSe
#
:VOLTage:REFerence:STATe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • enablebool 1 if delta mode enabled, 0 otherwise.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if voltage delta mode is enabled. If delta mode is enabled and  a non zero offset has been set by SENS#:VOLT:REF previously, MEAS#:VOLT? will return relative  measurements.

        
>> SENS:VOLT:REF:STAT?
<< 1

        
Delta voltage measurement is only available for Thermopile and Pyro sensors.


      

    

    

    
Unfold all SOUR Commands

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:DATADeprecated: Sets GPIO output pin level to high or low
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:DATA 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint bitmask with bit set to 1 for high output of pin. Set bit 0 for low output of pin.
    • 
        


        
Do not use this command in new designs. The command sets the level of all PM5020 external IO pins configured as output. A bit 1 will set a high output level for the mapped output pin. A bit 0 will drive output pin low. If a pin is  configured as input or alternate usage the level is skipped. It is best practice to set level  of these pins to 0 anyway. 

        
>> SOUR:DIG:DATA 2

        
Deprecated! Use SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA instead.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:DATA?Deprecated: Reads back GPIO input/output levels
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:DATA?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint bitmask with bit set to 1 for all inputs or outputs with high level. Bit set to 0 for low level or alternate pin usage.
    • 
        


        
Do not use this command in new designs. The command reads the level of all PM5020 external IO pins configured as output or input and sets bit 1 when pin level is high. If a pin is configured in alternate function the bit is always read back as 0. For closer details about the bitmask calculations read command SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA.

        
>> SOUR:DIG:DATA?
<< 4

        
Deprecated! Use SOUR:DIG:INP:DATA? or SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA? instead.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:ENABDeprecated: Configures all GPIO pin as input our output simultaneously
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:ENABle 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint bitmask with bit 1 for all pins configured in input direction. Set bit 0 for pin output direction.
    • 
        


        
Do not use this command in new designs. The command will configure all pins as input where bitmask bit is 1. If bit is 0 the pin is configured as output. A bitmask of 3 for example sets GPIO0 and GPIO1 as input and GPIO2,GPIO3 and AUX as output.  For closer details about the bitmask calculations read command SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA.

        
>> SOUR:DIG:ENAB 3

        
Deprecated! Use SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC instead.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:ENAB?Deprecated: Gets GPIO input/output pin direction
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:ENABle?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint bitmask with bit set to 1 for all pins configured in input direction. Bit set to 0 for output or alternate usage.
    • 
        


        
Do not use this command in new designs. The command will return a bitmask with a bit set to 1 for every signal configured  as input. A bit value 0 represents a output or alternate pin function.  A result of 6 for example says GPIO1 and GPIO2 are configured as input. All other pins are configured as output or alternate usage. For closer details about the bitmask calculations read command SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA.

        
>> SOUR:DIG:ENAB?
<< 6

        
Deprecated! Use SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC? instead.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:INP:DATA?Reads the GPIO input pins and returns bit mask
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:INPut:DATA?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint bitmask with bit 1 for all input signals read back as high
    • 
        


        
Use this to read GPIO input pin levels and to return a bitmask with a 1 bit for every input signal read back as high. All input signals use an internal 10 kOhm pulldown resistor. If a pin is configured for something else the bit is always read back as 0. To read output pins use  SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA?. To change the pin usage use command SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC.  For closer details about the bitmask read SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA.

        
>> SOUR:DIG:INP:DATA?
<< 7

        
Max input voltage is 3.3V. To prevent floating signals an internal pullup resistor is connected.

      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATAChanges one or multiple GPIO signal simultaneously
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:OUTPut:DATA 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint bitmask with with pin level for all GPIO pins
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the output level of the GPIO output pins simultaneously. If a pin of the mask is not configured for output the mapped output level is skipped. To change the pin usage use SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC.  The bitmask contains a 1 bit for every high 3.3V level. Bit at position 0 is related to GPIO 0, Bit at position 1 is mapped to GPIO 1 and so on. Front AUX is bit 4. To calculate the bitmask simply sum up the following numbers.  
     
  • GPIO0: 1
    •  
  • GPIO1: 2
    •  
  • GPIO2: 4
    •  
  • GPIO3: 8
    •  
  • AUX: 16
    •  
 So for example to set GPIO2 and AUX high calculate bitmask = 4 + 16 = 20. The configured output level is not stored persistently and is reset to low after reboot by default. Every output pin can drive up to 10 mA.

        
>> SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA 12

        
Pins outputs 0 or 3.3V and max current is 10mA.

      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA?Reads the GPIO output pins and returns bit mask
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:OUTPut:DATA?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint bitmask with bit 1 for all output signals read back as high
    • 
        


        
Use this to read GPIO output pin levels and to return a bitmask with a 1 bit for every output signal read back as high. If a pin is configured for something else the bit is always read back as 0. To read input pins use  SOUR:DIG:INP:DATA?. To change the pin usage use command SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC.  For closer details about the bitmask read SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA. 

        
>> SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA?
<< 20

        
Pins outputs 0 or 3.3V and max current is 10mA.

      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNCConfigures PM5020 IO pin usage
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:PIN
#
:FUNCtion 
<funct>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint pin number 1 to 4 for PM5020 rear GPIO pins and 5 for front AUX. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • functspecial new pin function for pin. See top listing.
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to configure the usage of a single PM5020 IO pin. Every 3.3V IO pin at the rear of the PM and the front AUX pin have several usages. Usage is stored in the device and is automatically recovered after reboot. Be aware changing the usage may result in an change of the signal level. If the pin is configured in any IALT function, an internal pullup resistor is applied. So you have to drive the signal low to activate the alternate function. If the pin is configured as OUTput or OALT it can drive up to 10 mA. The following usages are supported: 
     
  • INPut: Pin used as manual input pin. See SOUR:DIG:INP:DATA? to read level.
    •  
  • OUTput: Pin used as manual output pin. See SOUR:DIG:OUTP:DATA to change level.
    •  
  • IALTernative: Input direction first alternate function.
    •  
  • OALTernative: Output direction first alternate function.
    •  
  • IALT2ernative: Input direction second alternate function.
    •  
  • OALT2ernative: Output direction second alternate function.
    •  
  • IALT3ernative: Input direction third alternate function.
    •  
  • OALT3ernative: Output direction third alternate function.
    •  
 The following functions are supported by the single pins: 
     
  • GPIO0:
       
    • INP: Input pin. Pulldown resistor applied.
      •  
    • OUTP: Output pin. Default sig low. Up to 10mA.
      •  
    • IALT: Block DAC output for channel 1 when signal is low.
      •  
    • OALT: Channel 1 within pass fail window. Low when signal is in window. See cmd SENS#:POW:COND:LEV.
      •  
     
    •  
  • GPIO1:
       
    • INP: Input pin. Pulldown resistor applied.
      •  
    • OUTP: Output pin. Default sig low. Up to 10mA.
      •  
    • IALT: Block DAC output for channel 2 when signal is low.
      •  
    • OALT: Channel 2 within pass fail window. Low when signal is in window. See command SENS#:POW:COND:LEV.
      •  
     
    •  
  • GPIO2:
       
    • INP: Input pin. Pulldown resistor applied.
      •  
    • OUTP: Output pin. Default sig low. Up to 10mA.
      •  
    • IALT: Shutter state. Set to low to open shutter. Requires shutter interlock to be closed as well. See CON:SHUT:INT?
      •  
    • OALT: Shutter monitor pin. Driven high when shutter is open. Up to 10mA.
      •  
     
    •  
  • GPIO3:
       
    • INP: Input pin. Pulldown resistor applied.
      •  
    • OUTP: Output pin. Default sig low. Up to 10mA.
      •  
    • IALT: Measure log state. Set to low to start measure logging.
      •  
    • OALT: Measure log monitor pin. Driven high when capture is running. Up to 10mA.
      •  
     
    •  
  • AUX:
       
    • INP: Aux as input pin. Pulldown resistor applied.
      •  
    • OUTP: Aux as output pin. Default sig low. Up to 10mA.
      •  
    • IALT: Block DAC output for channel 1 and 2 when signal is low.
      •  
    • OALT: Scope mode trigger output. Up to 10mA. See command MEAS#:ARR:HWT?.
      •  
    • IALT2: Shutter state. Set to low to open shutter. Requires shutter interlock to be closed as well. See CON:SHUT:INT?
      •  
    • OALT2: Shutter monitor pin. Driven high when shutter is open. Up to 10mA.
      •  
    • IALT3: Measure log state. Set to low to start measure logging.
      •  
    • OALT3: Measure log monitor pin. Driven high when capture is running. Up to 10mA.
      •  
     
    •  

        
>> SOUR:DIG:PIN3:FUNC OUTP

        
Not all pins support all pin functions.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC?Queries the PM5020 IO pin usage
      

      

        
SOURce:DIGital:PIN
#
:FUNCtion?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint pin number 1 to 4 for PM5020 rear GPIO pins and 5 for front AUX. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • pinFuncspecial INP,OUTP,IALT,OALT, ...
    • 
        


        
 This command reads the current configuration of a single PM5020 IO pin. For closer details read SOUR:DIG:PIN#:FUNC.

        
>> SOUR:DIG:PIN1:FUNC?
<< IALT

        
Not all pins support all pin functions.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR#:VOLT?Queries analogue output voltage
      

      

        
SOURce
#
:VOLTage[:LEVel][:IMMediate][:AMPLitude]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Analogue output channel from 2 to 9. Default 2.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX Optional! nothing to query actual output voltage. MIN or MAX to query special limit voltages.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • voltagefloat output voltage on channel
    • 
        


        
 Returns the currently output voltage in Volt for given source channel. These are the available channels: 
     
  • SOUR2: Power/energy range independent voltage of channel 1
    •  
  • SOUR3: Sensor channel 1 measured beam position x coordinate.
    •  
  • SOUR4: Sensor channel 1 measured beam position y coordinate.
    •  
  • SOUR5: Customer defined voltage related to sensor channel 1. Used by GUI to output analogue signals.
    •  
  • SOUR6: Power/energy range independent voltage of channel 1
    •  
  • SOUR7: Sensor channel 2 measured beam position x coordinate.
    •  
  • SOUR8: Sensor channel 2 measured beam position y coordinate.
    •  
  • SOUR9: Customer defined voltage related to sensor channel 2. Used by GUI to output analogue signals.
    •  
 If a sensor supports measuring beam position, the x and y coordinate analogue output is used automatically. For all sensor types the outputs are used for power/energy range independent output on X out. And the customer defined voltage on Y out.

        
>> SOUR2:VOLT?
<< 2.234


      

    

    

      

        SOUR#:VOLT:CORR:SLOPSets the analogue output gain
      

      

        
SOURce
#
:VOLTage:CORRection:SLOPe[:OUTPut][:MAGNitude] 
<slope>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Analogue output channel from 2 to 9. Default 2.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • slopefloat,MIN,DEF,MAX new gain slope for given channel. MIN,DEF or MAX to set predefined values.
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to set the analogue output voltage conversion gain.  The gain is used to convert the represented physical unit to the  output voltage. It allows amplification (value smaller than 1) and  attenuation(value bigger than 1) of the signal. The unit of the gain depends on the selected analogue out channel. 
     
  • SOUR2 and SOUR 6 (Generated power/energy output): A/W for photodiode sensors, V/W for thermopile sensors or V/J for pyroelectric sensor.
    •  
  • SOUR3 and SOUR 7 (Beam X pos output): V/um
    •  
  • SOUR4 and SOUR 8 (Beam Y pos output): V/um
    •  
  • SOUR5 and SOUR 9 (Customer output. Used by GUI): V/customer signal unit
    •  
  • SOUR10 and SOUR 11 Real analouge output): V/W for power sensors or V/A or V/V. (Getter only!)
    •  
 The gain is stored persistently and is automatically used after reboot.

        
>> SOUR2:VOLT:CORR:SLOP 1e-3

        
SOUR10 and SOUR11 are only allowed for command SOUR#:VOLT:CORR:SLOP?. The value is calculated internally.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR#:VOLT:CORR:SLOP?Queries the analogue output gain level
      

      

        
SOURce
#
:VOLTage:CORRection:SLOPe[:OUTPut][:MAGNitude]? 
<special>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Analogue output channel from 2 to 11. Default 2.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,DEF,MAX Optional! nothing to query actual slope. MIN,DEF or MAX to query predefined values.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • slopefloat slope in V/W or V/J V/um depending on channel
    • 
        


        
 Use this query to get the analogue output voltage conversion gain.  The gain is used to convert the represented physical unit to the  output voltage. For closer details read SOUR#:VOLT:CORR:SLOP.

        
>> SOUR2:VOLT:CORR:SLOP?
<< 1e3

        
SOUR10 and SOUR11 are not allowed for command SOUR#:VOLT:CORR:SLOP. The value is calculated internally.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR#:VOLT:RANGSets the analogue output voltage range
      

      

        
SOURce
#
:VOLTage:RANGe 
<mode>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Analogue output channel from 2 to 11. Default 2.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • modeuint output voltage range. See list in command details.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the voltage range for given analogue output channel. The following list gives an overview of the available voltage ranges. 
     
  • 0:  0 up to 10V
    •  
  • 1:  0 up to 4V
    •  
  • 2:  0 up to 2V
    •  
  • 3:  0 up to 1V
    •  
  • 4: -5 up to 5V
    •  
  • 5: -2 up to 2V
    •  
 The analogue out channels support the following ranges. 
     
  • SOUR2 and SOUR 6 (Generated power/energy output): 0, 1, 2, 3
    •  
  • SOUR3 and SOUR 7 (Beam X pos output): 0, 1, 4, 5
    •  
  • SOUR4 and SOUR 8 (Beam Y pos output): 0, 1, 4, 5
    •  
  • SOUR5 and SOUR 9 (Customer output. Used by GUI): 0, 1, 2, 3
    •  
  • SOUR10 and SOUR 11 (Real analouge output): 0, 1, 2, 3
    •  
 The selected voltage range is stored persistently and is automatically reused after reboot. 

        
>> SOURce4:VOLTage:RANGe 2

        
Not all source channels support all voltage ranges.


      

    

    

      

        SOUR#:VOLT:RANG?Queries the analogue output voltage range
      

      

        
SOURce
#
:VOLTage:RANGe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Analogue output channel from 2 to 11. Default 2.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • modeuint output voltage range.
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to query the used analogue output voltage range for given channel.  For closer details read the command SOUR#:VOLT:RANG section.

        
>> SOURce4:VOLTage:RANG?
<< 3


      

    

    

      

        SOUR#:VOLT:ROUTSets the light sensor signal analogue output route
      

      

        
SOURce
#
:VOLTage:ROUTe 
<route>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Analogue output channel 10 for channel 1 or 11 for channel 2. Default 10.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • routeSPEC new light sensor signal analogue output route.
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to select the sensor signal analogue output route. The PM5020 outputs the amplified voltage or current of the light sensor signal to the customer. The settings for real analogue output is mapped on SOUR11 for chan 1 and SOUR12 for chan 2. There are three routes available: 
     
  • PURe (Direct Route): The raw amplified signal is output. This signal is  related to the photo current or voltage. It is not wavelength or zero compensated.
    •  
  • CBA (Compensated Base Unit):  The raw amplified signal is multiplied with  a correction factor in hardware to compensate the dark current/voltage. The signal is the photo  current or voltage and is not wavelength compensated.
    •  
  • CMA (Compensated Main Unit):  The raw amplified signal is multiplied with a correction  factor in hardware to output a analogue voltage related  to power or energy. The signal is zero and wavelength compensated.
    •  
 The sensor signal route is stored persistently and is automatically reused after reboot.

        
>> SOUR11:VOLTage:ROUT CMA


      

    

    

      

        SOUR#:VOLT:ROUT?Queries the analogue light sensor signal output route
      

      

        
SOURce
#
:VOLTage:ROUTe?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint Analogue output channel 10 for channel 1 or 11 for channel 2. Default 10.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • SPEC currently used light sensor signal analogue output route. PURe, CMA, CBA
    • 
        


        
 Use this command to query the real analogue output route. For closer details read SOUR#:VOLT:ROUT.

        
>> SOUR11:VOLT:ROUT?
<< CBA


      

    

    

    
Unfold all STAT Commands

    

      

        STAT:AUX?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Event register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary[:EVENt]?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide event register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Event register bit mask. The register summarizes multi channel Auxiliary equipment changes like the two NTC channels. To get detail event information about the single channels or more detail information use STAT:AUX:DET?.
 Reading this event register automatically resets the register back to 0. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every event occurred since the register has been read the last time. If the same event occurs multiple times the event bit stays 1. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:COND? description. The event register can store a change of the Auxiliary Condition register. The two transition registers are used to mask changes of the condition register to the event register. If a certain bit in the condition register is set from 0 to 1 and the bit at the same position in the positive transition register STAT:AUX:PTR is set 1, the event register at the bit position is set to 1. It is also possible to detect condition register changes from 1 back to 0 using the negative transition register STAT:AUX:NTR following the same logic. 
 Changes of the event register can be summarized to the SCPI status register bit 0 if enabled by STAT:AUX:ENAB. To read the SCPI status register call STB?. After reboot or CLS the events are all reset to 0.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX?
<< 253

        
Some events might get lost if same event occurs multiple times without the event register being read in between.

        
Reading the event register automatically resets register to 0. To get the events bit positions read STAT:AUX:COND?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:COND?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Condition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:CONDition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide condition register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Condition register bit mask. This register provides basic condition information about the device auxiliary state like for example customer calibration state. The register also summarizes multi channel Auxiliary equipment like the two NTC channels. To get detail information about the single channels or more detail information use STAT:AUX:DET:COND?.
 The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition being active at the moment. Be aware some conditions might only last for a very short time period. In this case using the event register STAT:AUX? makes more sense. Configure the positive STAT:AUX:PTR or negative STAT:AUX:NTR transition register to map changes of the condition register to the event register. These are the masked events:
  
     
  • bit 0: NTC 1 and/or NTC 2 connected. Check STAT:AUX:DET:COND? to get the channel info. Use SENS#:TEMP:DATA? to read measured temperature.
    •  
  • bit 1: Environment sensor connected. Check STAT:AUX:DET:COND? to get the channel info. Use SENS#:TEMP:DATA? to read measured temperature.
    •  
  • bit 2: Customer calibration supported by device. Always 1.
    •  
  • bit 3: Customer calibration active. Check STAT:AUX:DET:COND? to get the channel info.
    •  
  • bit 4: External power supply connected. Always 1.
    •  
  • bit 9: CPU overheated.
    •  
  • bit 10: Sensor signal out of window. Check STAT:AUX:DET:COND? to get the channel info. Use SENS#:POW:COND:LEV to define the sensor signal window.
    •  
  • bit 11: Fan running. Check STAT:AUX:DET:COND? to get the channel info. Use CON:FAN#:MODE to control the fans.
    •  
  • bit 13: Auxiliary detail event summary. See STAT:AUX:DET:COND?.
    •  
 All other condition bits are reserved. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:COND?
<< 2182

        
To test for short lasting conditions better use the event register STAT:AUX?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Event register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail[:EVENt]?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide event register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Event register bit mask. This Auxiliary Detail register provides detail event information about the device auxiliary changes like the shutter state. The register also informs about changes of the multi channel auxiliary equipment like the external NTC channels. To get the summarized more generic event information about the Auxiliary for use STAT:AUX?.
 Reading this event register automatically resets the register back to 0. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every event occurred since the register has been read the last time. If the same event occurs multiple times the event bit stays 1. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:DET:COND? description. The event register can store a change of the Auxiliary Detail Condition register. The two transition registers are used to mask changes of the condition register to the event register. If a certain bit in the condition register is set from 0 to 1 and the bit at the same position in the positive transition register STAT:AUX:DET:PTR is set 1, the event register at the bit position is set to 1. It is also possible to detect condition register changes from 1 back to 0 using the negative transition register STAT:AUX:DET:NTR following the same logic. 
 Changes of the event register can be summarized to the Auxiliary Condition register bit 13 if enabled by STAT:AUX:DET:ENAB. After reboot or CLS the events are all reset to 0.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:DET:AUX?
<< 253

        
Some events might get lost if same event occurs multiple times without the event register being read in between.

        
Reading the event register automatically resets register to 0. To get the events bit positions read STAT:AUX:COND?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET:COND?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Condition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail:CONDition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide condition register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Condition register bit mask. This Auxiliary Detail register provides detail condition information about the device auxiliary like the shutter state. The register informs about multi channel auxiliary equipment like the external NTC channels. To get the summarized more generic information about the Auxiliary condition for use STAT:AUX:COND?.
 The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition being active at the moment. Be aware some conditions might only last for a very short time period. In this case using the event register STAT:AUX:DET? makes more sense. Configure the positive STAT:AUX:DET:PTR or negative STAT:AUX:DET:NTR transition register to map changes of the condition register to the event register. These are the masked events:
  
     
  • bit 0: Customer calibration for measure channel 1 active. Use SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT to enable/disable customer calibration.
    •  
  • bit 1: Customer calibration for measure channel 2 active. Use SENS#:CORR:CSET#:STAT to enable/disable customer calibration.
    •  
  • bit 2: Measure channel 1 out of signal window. Use SENS#:POW:COND:LEV to define the sensor signal window.
    •  
  • bit 3: Measure channel 2 out of signal window. Use SENS#:POW:COND:LEV to define the sensor signal window.
    •  
  • bit 4: External NTC 1 connected. Use SENS#:TEMP:DATA? to read measured temperature.
    •  
  • bit 5: External NTC 2 connected. Use SENS#:TEMP:DATA? to read measured temperature.
    •  
  • bit 6: Fan 1 running. Use CON:FAN#:MODE to to control the fan.
    •  
  • bit 7: Fan 2 running. Use CON:FAN#:MODE to to control the fan.
    •  
  • bit 8: Fan 1 alarm. Currently unused.
    •  
  • bit 9: Fan 2 alarm. Currently unused.
    •  
  • bit 10: Shutter interlock open. Alternative by command CON:SHUT:INT?.
    •  
  • bit 11: Shutter current state. See CON:SHUT to control state. Also affected by interlock state!
    •  
  • bit 12: Shutter connection state. Alternative by command CON:SHUT:CON?.
    •  
  • bit 13: Environmental sensor 1 connected. Use SENS#:TEMP:DATA? to read temperature and SENS#:HUM:DATA? to read humidity.
    •  
 All other condition bits are reserved. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:DET:COND?
<< 2182

        
To test for short lasting conditions better use the event register STAT:AUX:DET?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET:ENABSets the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail:ENABle 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for enable register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the STAT:AUX:COND? register bit 13. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:DET:COND? description. This enable register acts like a filter mask for all auxiliary events (see STAT:AUX:DET?) that should be forwarded to the Auxiliary Condition register bit 13. If the enable mask is set with all bits 1, the Auxiliary Condition register bit 13 is set to 1 whenever one or multiple events are set in STAT:AUX:DET? register. The idea behind this abstraction concept is to read the Auxiliary Condition and check for bit 13 to change. Whenever the bit changed the user then may query the getAuxDetailEventReg Register to get the details. Changing the enable register with active events might directly update the summarized SCPI status register bit.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:DET:ENAB 65280

        
Ensure that the positive and negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET:ENAB?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail:ENABle?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 8 bit wide SCPI status register bit 0. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:DET:COND? description. For closer details about the Auxiliary Detail Enable register read STAT:AUX:DET:ENAB. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:DET:ENAB?
<< 65280

        
Ensure that the positive or negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET:NTRSets the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail:NTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:AUX:DET?. As it is the negative transition register, only condition register bit changes from 1 back to 0 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:DET:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 4 (binary: 100 bit at position 2) and sensor 1 signal enters defined window, the event register value bit at position 2 is set to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:DET:NTR 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET:NTR?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail:NTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:AUX:DET?. For closer details about Negative Transition register read description STAT:AUX:DET:NTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:DET:NTR?
<< 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET:PTRSets the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail:PTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the Auxiliary Event register STAT:AUX:DET?. As it is the positive transition register, only condition register bit changes from 0 to 1 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:DET:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 4 (binary: 100 bit at position 2) and sensor 1 signal leaves defined window, the event register value bit at position 2 is set to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:DET:PTR 8

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:DET:PTR?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Detail Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:DETail:PTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Detail Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:AUX:DET?. For closer details about Positive Transition register read description STAT:AUX:DET:PTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:DET:PTR?
<< 65280

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:ENABSets the SCPI Auxiliary Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:ENABle 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for enable register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 8 bit wide SCPI status register bit 0. See STB?. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:COND? description. This enable register acts like a filter mask for all auxiliary events (see STAT:AUX?) that should be forwarded to the SCPI status register. If the enable mask is set with all bits 1, the SCPI status register bit 0 is set to 1 whenever one or multiple events are set in STAT:AUX? register. The idea behind this abstraction concept is to read the SCPI status register and check for bit 0 to change. Whenever the bit changed the user then may query this Auxiliary Event register to get the details. Changing the enable register with active events might directly update the summarized SCPI status register bit.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:ENAB 65280

        
Ensure that the positive and negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:ENAB?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:ENABle?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 8 bit wide SCPI status register bit 0. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:COND? description. For closer details about the Auxiliary Enable register read STAT:AUX:ENAB.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:ENAB?
<< 65280

        
Ensure that the positive or negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:NTRSets the SCPI Auxiliary Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:NTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:AUX?. As it is the negative transition register, only condition register bit changes from 1 back to 0 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 2 (binary: 10 bit at position 1) and all external NTCs are disconnected from NTC1 and NTC2 it will also set the event register value bit at position 1 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:NTR 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:NTR?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:NTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:AUX?. For closer details about Negative Transition register read description STAT:AUX:NTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:NTR?
<< 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:PTRSets the SCPI Auxiliary Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:PTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the Auxiliary Event register STAT:AUX?. As it is the positive transition register, only condition register bit changes from 0 to 1 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:AUX:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 2 (binary: 10 bit at position 1) and an external NTC is connected to NTC1 or NTC2 it will also set the event register value bit at position 1 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:PTR 8

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:AUX:PTR?Queries the SCPI Auxiliary Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:AUXiliary:PTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Auxiliary Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:AUX?. For closer details about Positive Transition register read description STAT:AUX:PTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:AUX:PTR?
<< 65280

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER?Queries the SCPI Operation Event register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation[:EVENt]?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide event register bit mask.
    •
