Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Event register bit mask. This Operation Event register summarizes the states of the two measure channel Operation Event registers. To query the Operation Event register for a single measure channel use STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?.
  Reading this event register automatically resets the register back to 0. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every event occurred since the register has been read the last time. If the same event occurs multiple times the event bit stays 1. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:COND? description. The event register can store a change of the Operation Condition register. The two transition registers are used to mask changes of the condition register to the event register. If a certain bit in the condition register is set from 0 to 1 and the bit at the same position in the positive transition register STAT:OPER:PTR is set 1, the event register at the bit position is set to 1. It is also possible to detect condition register changes from 1 back to 0 using the negative transition register STAT:OPER:NTR following the same logic. 
 Using the event register makes sense for short lasting conditions like a range change for example. Changes of the event register can be summarized to the SCPI status register bit 7 if enabled by STAT:OPER:ENAB. To read the SCPI status register call STB?. After reboot or CLS the events are all reset to 0.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER?
<< 253

        
Some events might get lost if same event occurs multiple times without the event register being read in between.

        
Reading the event register automatically resets register to 0. To get the events bit positions read STAT:OPER:COND?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:COND?Queries the SCPI Operation Condition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:CONDition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide condition register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Condition register bit mask. This Operation Condition register summarizes the states of the two measure channel Operation Condition registers. To get the Operation Condition Register for a single measure channel use STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND?.
 The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition being active at the moment. Be aware some conditions might only last for a very short time period like a range change for example. In this case using the event register STAT:OPER? makes more sense. Configure the positive STAT:OPER:PTR or negative STAT:OPER:NTR transition register to map changes of the condition register to the event register. These are the masked events:
  
     
  • bit 2: Measure range changing on channel 1 or 2 condition. See SENS#:POW:RANG.
    •  
  • bit 3: Peak finder algorithm on channel 1 or 2 running. See SENS#:PEAK:SEAR
    •  
  • bit 4: Measurements on channel 1 or 2 are active conditions.
    •  
  • bit 5: Scope triggered condition. See MEAS#:ARR:HWT?.
    •  
  • bit 6: Scope armed condition. See MEAS#:ARR:HWT?.
    •  
  • bit 7: Zeroing algorithm on channel 1 or 2 running. See SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO.
    •  
  • bit 8: Sensor 1 or 2 connected condition.
    •  
  • bit 9: Data ready to fetch for channel 1 or 2. See MEAS#?.
    •  
  • bit 10: Thermopile accelerator for channel 1 or 2 condition. See INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO.
    •  
  • bit 11: Light sensor head 1 or 2 overheated condition.
    •  
  • bit 12: Sensor power integration of head 1 or 2. See INP#:THER:INTE:ENAB.
    •  
  • bit 13: Instrument 1 summary register event active. See STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:ENAB.
    •  
  • bit 14: Instrument 2 summary register event active. See STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:ENAB.
    •  
 All other condition bits are reserved. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:COND?
<< 2182

        
To test for short lasting conditions like a range change use the event register STAT:OPER?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:ENABSets the SCPI Operation Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:ENABle 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for enable register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 8 bit wide SCPI status register bit 7. See STB?. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:COND? description. This enable register acts like a filter mask for all operation events (see STAT:OPER?) that should be forwarded to the SCPI status register. If the enable mask is set with all bits 1, the SCPI status register bit 7 is set to 1 whenever one or multiple events are set in STAT:OPER? register. The idea behind this abstraction concept is to read the SCPI status register and check for bit 7 to change. Whenever the bit changed the user then may query this Operation Event register to get the details. Changing the enable register with active events might directly update the summarized SCPI status register bit.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:ENAB 65280

        
Ensure that the positive and negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:ENAB?Queries the SCPI Operation Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:ENABle?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 8 bit wide SCPI status register bit 7. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:COND? description. For closer details about the Operation Enable register read STAT:OPER:ENAB.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:ENAB?
<< 65280

        
Ensure that the positive or negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?Queries the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Event register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
[:EVENt]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide event register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Instrument Summary Event register bit mask. This event register belongs to one of the Powermeter measure channels. To query the summarized Operation Event register use STAT:OPER:COND?.
  Reading this event register automatically resets the register back to 0. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every event occurred since the register has been read the last time. If the same event occurs multiple times the event bit stays 1. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. The event register can store a change of the Operation Condition register. The two transition registers are used to mask changes of the condition register to the event register. If a certain bit in the condition register is set from 0 to 1 and the bit at the same position in the positive transition register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:PTR is set 1, the event register at the bit position is set to 1. It is also possible to detect condition register changes from 1 back to 0 using the negative transition register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:NTR following the same logic. 
 Using the event register makes sense for short lasting conditions like a range change for example. Changes of the event register can be summarized in the STAT:OPER:COND? register  bit 13 (channel 1) or 14 (channel 2) when  enabled by STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:ENAB.  After reboot or CLS the events are all reset to 0.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1?
<< 253

        
Some events might get lost if same event occurs multiple times without the event register being read in between.

        
Reading the event register automatically resets register to 0. To get the events bit positions read STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND?Queries the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Condition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:CONDition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide condition register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Instrument Summary Condition register bit mask. This condition register belongs to one of  the Powermeter measure channels. To query the summarized Operation Condition  register use STAT:OPER:COND?.
  The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition being active at the moment. Be aware some conditions might only last for a very short time period like a range change for example. In this case using the event register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#? makes more sense. Configure the positive STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:PTR or negative STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:NTR transition register to map changes of the condition register to the event register. These are the masked events:
  
     
  • bit 2: Measure range changing on channel 1 or 2 condition. See SENS#:POW:RANG.
    •  
  • bit 3: Peak finder algorithm on channel 1 or 2 running. See SENS#:PEAK:SEAR
    •  
  • bit 4: Measurements on channel 1 or 2 are active conditions.
    •  
  • bit 5: Scope triggered condition. See MEAS#:ARR:HWT?.
    •  
  • bit 6: Scope armed condition. See MEAS#:ARR:HWT?.
    •  
  • bit 7: Zeroing algorithm on channel 1 or 2 running. See SENS#:CORR:COLL:ZERO.
    •  
  • bit 8: Sensor 1 or 2 connected condition.
    •  
  • bit 9: Data ready to fetch for channel 1 or 2. See MEAS#?.
    •  
  • bit 10: Thermopile accelerator for channel 1 or 2 condition. See INP#:THER:ACC:AUTO.
    •  
  • bit 11: Light sensor head 1 or 2 overheated condition.
    •            
  • bit 12: Sensor power integration of head 1 or 2. See INP#:THER:INTE:ENAB.
    •  
 All other condition bits are reserved. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1:COND?
<< 2182

        
To test for short lasting conditions like a range change use the event register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:ENABSets the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:ENABle 
<bitmask>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for enable register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Instrument Summary Enable register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:OPER:ENAB? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 16 bit wide STAT:OPER:COND? register bit 13 (channel 1) or bit 14 (channel 2). To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. This enable register acts like a filter mask for all operation events (see STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?) that should be forwarded to the SCPI Operation Condition Register. If the enable mask is set with all bits 1, the STAT:OPER:COND? register bit 13 (channel 1) or 14 (channel 2) is set to 1 whenever one or multiple events are set in STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#? register. The idea behind this abstraction concept is to read the SCPI Operation Condition Register and check for bit 13 or 14 to change. Whenever the bit changed the user then may query the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#? to get the details. Changing the enable register with active events might directly update the summarized SCPI status register bit.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1:ENAB 65280

        
Ensure that the positive and negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:ENAB?Queries the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:ENABle?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Instrument Summary Enable register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:OPER:ENAB? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 16 bit wide STAT:OPER:COND? register bit 13 (channel 1) or bit 14 (channel 2). To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. For closer details about the Operation  Instrument Summary Enable register read STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:ENAB.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM2:ENAB?
<< 65280

        
Ensure that the positive or negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:NTRSets the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:NTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Instrument Summary Negative Transition register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:OPER:NTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?. As it is the negative transition register, only condition register bit changes from 1 back to 0 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 2048 (binary: 100000000000 bit at position 11) and the sensor head chills after running hot (condition register at position 11 changes back from 1 to 0) it will also set the event register value bit at position 11 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1:NTR 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:NTR?Queries the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:NTRansition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Negative Instrument Summary Transition register bit mask.  The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:OPER:NTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?. For closer details about Negative Transition register read description STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:NTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1:NTR?
<< 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:PTRSets the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:PTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Instrument Summary Positive Transition register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:OPER:PTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the Operation Event register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?. As it is the positive transition register, only condition register bit changes from 0 to 1 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 4 (binary: 100 bit at position 2) and the Powermeter changes the range (condition register at position 2) it will also set the event register value bit at position 2 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1:PTR 36

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:PTR?Queries the SCPI Operation Instrument Summary Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:PTRansition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Instrument Summary Positive Transition register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:OPER:PTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#?. For closer details about Positive Transition register read description STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM#:COND?.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:INST:ISUM1:PTR?
<< 65280

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:NTRSets the SCPI Operation Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:NTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:OPER?. As it is the negative transition register, only condition register bit changes from 1 back to 0 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 2048 (binary: 100000000000 bit at position 11) and the sensor head chills after running hot (condition register at position 11 changes back from 1 to 0) it will also set the event register value bit at position 11 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:NTR 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:NTR?Queries the SCPI Operation Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:NTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:OPER?. For closer details about Negative Transition register read description STAT:OPER:NTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:NTR?
<< 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:PTRSets the SCPI Operation Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:PTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the Operation Event register STAT:OPER?. As it is the positive transition register, only condition register bit changes from 0 to 1 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:OPER:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 4 (binary: 100 bit at position 2) and the Powermeter changes the range (condition register at position 2) it will also set the event register value bit at position 2 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:PTR 36

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:OPER:PTR?Queries the SCPI Operation Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:OPERation:PTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Operation Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:OPER?. For closer details about Positive Transition register read description STAT:OPER:PTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:OPER:PTR?
<< 65280

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:PRESPre-sets all SCPI status register with default values
      

      

        
STATus:PRESet

        
Use this command to pre set all SCPI status registers with default values.  All ENABle and NTRansition Registers are set to 0. The PTRansition registers are set to 65535. The event registers are cleared to 0.

        
>> STAT:PRES


      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES?Queries the SCPI Questionable Event register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable[:EVENt]?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide event register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Event register bit mask. This Questionable Event register summarizes the states of the two measure channel Questionable Event registers. To query the Questionable Event register for a single measure channel use STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?.
 Reading this event register automatically resets the register back to 0. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every event occurred since the register has been read the last time. If the same event occurs multiple times the event bit stays 1. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:COND? description. The event register can store a change of the Questionable Condition register. The two transition registers are used to mask changes of the condition register to the event register. If a certain bit in the condition register is set from 0 to 1 and the bit at the same position in the positive transition register STAT:QUES:PTR is set 1, the event register at the bit position is set to 1. It is also possible to detect condition register changes from 1 back to 0 using the negative transition register STAT:QUES:NTR following the same logic. 
 Using the event register makes sense for short lasting conditions like a small peak causing overflow of measure range for example. Changes of the event register can be summarized to the SCPI status register bit 3 if enabled by STAT:QUES:ENAB. To read the SCPI status register call STB?. After reboot or CLS the events are all reset to 0. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES?
<< 253

        
Some events might get lost if same event occurs multiple times without the event register being read in between.

        
Reading the event register automatically resets register to 0. To get the events bit positions read STAT:QUES:COND?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:COND?Queries the SCPI Questionable Condition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:CONDition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide condition register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Condition register bit mask. This Questionable Condition register summarizes the states of the two measure channel Questionable Condition registers. To get the Questionable Condition Register for a single measure channel use STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND?.
 The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition being active at the moment. Be aware some conditions might only last for a very short time period like a small peak causing overflow of measure range for example. In this case using the event register STAT:QUES? makes more sense. Configure the positive STAT:QUES:PTR or negative STAT:QUES:NTR transition register to map changes of the condition register to the event register. These are the masked events:
  
     
  • bit 0: Questionable Voltage measurement. MEAS#:VOLT? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
  • bit 1: Questionable Current measurement. MEAS#:CURR? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
  • bit 3: Questionable Power measurement. MEAS#? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
  • bit 8: Questionable Calibration. Device not calibrated or calibration due.
    •  
  • bit 9: Questionable Energy measurement. MEAS#:ENER? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
  • bit 13: Measurement channel 1 summary. See STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?.
    •  
  • bit 14: Measurement channel 2 summary. See STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?.
    •  
 All other condition bits are reserved. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:COND?
<< 2182

        
To test for short lasting conditions better use the event register STAT:QUES?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:ENABSets the SCPI Questionable Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:ENABle 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for enable register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 8 bit wide SCPI status register bit 3. See STB?. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:COND? description. This enable register acts like a filter mask for all operation events (see STAT:QUES?) that should be forwarded to the SCPI status register. See STB?. If the enable mask is set with all bits 1, the SCPI status register bit 3 is set to 1 whenever one or multiple events are set in STAT:QUES? register. The idea behind this abstraction concept is to read the SCPI status register and check for bit 3 to change. Whenever the bit changed the user then may query this Questionable Event register to get the details. Changing the enable register with active events might directly update the summarized SCPI status register bit.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:ENAB 65280

        
Ensure that the positive and negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:ENAB?Queries the SCPI Questionable Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:ENABle?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Enable register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 8 bit wide SCPI status register bit 7. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:COND? description. For closer details about the Questionable Enable register read STAT:QUES:ENAB.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:ENAB?
<< 65280

        
Ensure that the positive or negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?Queries the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Event register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
[:EVENt]?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide event register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Instrument Summary Event register bit mask. This event register belongs to one of the Powermeter measure channels. To query the summarized Questionable Event register use STAT:QUES?.
 Reading this event register automatically resets the register back to 0. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every event occurred since the register has been read the last time. If the same event occurs multiple times the event bit stays 1. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. The event register can store a change of the Questionable Condition register. The two transition registers are used to mask changes of the condition register to the event register. If a certain bit in the condition register is set from 0 to 1 and the bit at the same position in the positive transition register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:PTR is set 1, the event register at the bit position is set to 1. It is also possible to detect condition register changes from 1 back to 0 using the negative transition register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:NTR following the same logic. 
 Using the event register makes sense for short lasting conditions like a small peak causing overflow of measure range for example. Changes of the event register can be summarized in the STAT:QUES:COND? register bit 13 (channel 1) or 14 (channel 2) when enabled by STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:ENAB. After reboot or CLS the events are all reset to 0.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM1?
<< 253

        
Some events might get lost if same event occurs multiple times without the event register being read in between.

        
Reading the event register automatically resets register to 0. To get the events bit positions read STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND?Queries the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Condition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:CONDition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide condition register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Instrument Summary Condition register bit mask. This condition register belongs to one of the Powermeter measure channels. To query the summarized Questionable Condition register use STAT:QUES:COND?.
  The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition being active at the moment. Be aware some conditions might only last for a very short time period like a like a small peak causing overflow of measure range for example. In this case using the event register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#? makes more sense. Configure the positive STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:PTR or negative STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:PTR? transition register to map changes of the condition register to the event register. These are the masked events:
  
     
  • bit 0: Questionable Voltage measurement. MEAS#:VOLT? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
  • bit 1: Questionable Current measurement. MEAS#:CURR? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
  • bit 3: Questionable Power measurement. MEAS#? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
  • bit 8: Questionable Calibration. Device not calibrated or calibration due.
    •  
  • bit 9: Questionable Energy measurement. MEAS#:ENER? will return infinity as signal out of measure range.
    •  
 All other condition bits are reserved. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM2:COND?
<< 2182

        
To test for short lasting conditions like a range change use the event register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:ENABSets the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:ENABle 
<bitmask>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for enable register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Instrument Summary Enable register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:QUES:ENAB? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 16 bit wide STAT:QUES:COND? register bit 13 (channel 1) or bit 14 (channel 2). To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. This Enable register acts like a filter mask for all operation events (see STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?) that should be forwarded to the SCPI Questionable Condition Register. If the enable mask is set with all bits 1, the STAT:QUES:COND? register bit 13 (channel 1) or 14 (channel 2) is set to 1 whenever one or multiple events are set in STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#? register. The idea behind this abstraction concept is to read the SCPI Questionable Condition Register and check for bit 13 or 14 to change. Whenever the bit changed the user then may query the STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#? to get the details. Changing the enable register with active events might directly update the summarized SCPI status register bit.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM1:ENAB 65280

        
Ensure that the positive and negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:ENAB?Queries the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Enable register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:ENABle?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide enable register bit mask.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Instrument Summary Enable register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:QUES:ENAB? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every enabled event that should be forwarded to the 16 bit wide STAT:QUES:COND? register bit 13 (channel 1) or bit 14 (channel 2). To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. For closer details about the Quesation  Instrument Summary Enable register read STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:ENAB.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM2:ENAB?
<< 65280

        
Ensure that the positive or negative transition registers are set accordingly to change the event register. Forwarding only works if event register gets updated.

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no events are forwarded.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:NTRSets the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:NTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Instrument Summary Negative Transition register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:QUES:NTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?. As it is the negative transition register, only condition register bit changes from 1 back to 0 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND? description.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM1:NTR 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:NTR?Queries the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:NTRansition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Negative Instrument Summary Transition register bit mask.  The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:QUES:NTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?. For closer details about Negative Transition register read description STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:NTR. Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM1:NTR?
<< 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:PTRSets the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:PTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Instrument Summary Positive Transition register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:QUES:PTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the Questionable Event register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?. As it is the positive transition register, only condition register bit changes from 0 to 1 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 8 (binary: 1000 bit at position 4) and the Powermeter measures a short peak causing a overflow of measure range the Questionable Power Measurement flag will become true for a short moment it will also set the event register value bit at position 4 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM1:PTR 36

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:PTR?Queries the SCPI Questionable Instrument Summary Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:INSTrument:ISUMmary
#
:PTRansition?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Instrument Summary Positive Transition register bit mask. The register is the measure channel dependent version of the STAT:QUES:PTR? register. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#?. For closer details about Positive Transition register read description STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM#:PTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:INST:ISUM2:PTR?
<< 65280

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:NTRSets the SCPI Questionable Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:NTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:QUES?. As it is the negative transition register, only condition register bit changes from 1 back to 0 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:COND? description.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:NTR 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:NTR?Queries the SCPI Questionable Negative Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:NTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Negative Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:QUES?. For closer details about Negative Transition register read description STAT:QUES:NTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:NTR?
<< 260

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 0. So no condition changes from bit 1 to 0 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:PTRSets the SCPI Questionable Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:PTRansition 
<bitmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to set the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the Questionable Event register STAT:QUES?. As it is the positive transition register, only condition register bit changes from 0 to 1 update the bits in the event register. To get the meaning of the single bits read the STAT:QUES:COND? description. For example if you set this register value to 8 (binary: 1000 bit at position 3) and the Powermeter measures a short peak causing a overflow of measure range the Questionable Power Measurement flag will become true for a short moment it will also set the event register value bit at position 3 to 1.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:PTR 8

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

      

        STAT:QUES:PTR?Queries the SCPI Questionable Positive Transition register
      

      

        
STATus:QUEStionable:PTRansition?

        
Response
    
          
  • bitmaskuint 16 bit wide bit mask for positive transition register.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the SCPI 16 bit wide Questionable Positive Transition register bit mask. The register content is a bit mask with a 1 bit for every condition change that should be mapped to the operation event register STAT:QUES?. For closer details about Positive Transition register read description STAT:QUES:PTR.
 Read SCPI register set section to get closer infos about the SCPI register system in general.

        
>> STAT:QUES:PTR?
<< 65280

        
The default value after reboot or CLS is 65535 (all bits 1). So all condition changes from bit 0 to 1 update the event register.

      

    

    

    
Unfold all SYST Commands

    

      

        SYST:BEEPPlays a short beep
      

      

        
SYSTem:BEEPer[:IMMediate]

        
Use this command to play a short beep. The command starts playing the tone in background and returns immediately. 

        
>> SYST:BEEP


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:ADDRChanges IPv4 address of device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:ADDRess 
<address>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • addressstring IPv4 address string. Bytes separated by fullstop.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change IPv4 address of device. If DHCP is enabled the function simply updates the static IPv4 address without applying configuration to the network interface. If DHCP is disabled the command also applies configuration to the network interface.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:ADDR "10.10.3.123"


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:ADDR?Queries IPv4 address of device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:ADDRess?

        
Response
    
          
  • addressstring IPv4 address string. Bytes separated by fullstop.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query IPv4 address of device. If DHCP is enabled and no IP has been assigned yet the result might be "0.0.0.0". If DHCP is disabled the static IPv4 address will be returned. To test if 

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:ADDR?
<< "10.10.3


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:DFU:PORSets a new Ethernet port for the DFU server
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:DFU:PORt 
<port>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • portuint new port number. 0 to disable service. Default it 27007.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the Ethernet port number of the DFU( Device Firmware Update) server. The server allows updating the device firmwares via Ethernet. You can use port number 0 to disable the service. Once the port number is changed a reboot of the device is mandatory to apply new server settings.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:DFU:POR 20002

        
Requires reboot of device.


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:DFU:POR?Queries Ethernet port for the DFU server
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:DFU:PORt?

        
Response
    
          
  • portuint new port number. 0 to disable service. Default it 27007.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the Ethernet port number of the DFU( Device Firmware Update) server. The server allows updating the device firmwares via Ethernet. For closer details read SYST:COMM:LAN:DFU:POR.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:DFU:POR?
<< 2022


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:DHCPEnables or disables DHCP of device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:DHCP 
<state>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • statebool 1 to enable DHCP. 0 to apply static IP configuration.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable or disable DHCP client of the device. When enabled the IP address is assigned at runtime by any Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server in LAN. When DHCP is disabled the static IP configuration is used. Use  SYST:COMM:LAN:ADDR and SYST:COMM:LAN:SMAS to apply static IP configuration. Once a IP address has been assigned by DHCP server you can use SYST:COMM:LAN:ADDR? to query the address.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:DHCP 1

        
Disabling DHCP will automatically apply static IP configuration. It is best practice to configure static IP fist.

        
When enabling DHCP it may take awhile until IP address is assigned.

      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:DHCP?Tests if DHCP is enabled
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:DHCP?

        
Response
    
          
  • statebool 1 when DHCP is enabled. 0 for static IP configuration.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if DHCP is enabled or disabled. When enabled the IP address is assigned at runtime by any Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Server in LAN. When DHCP is disabled the static IP configuration is used. For closer details read SYST:COMM:LAN:DHCP.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:DHCP?
<< 1


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:HOSTSets a new hostname for the device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:HOSTname 
<name>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • namestring new device hostname. The maximum length of the hostname string is limited to 15.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the hostname for the device. The hostname can be used to customize the device name. It is displayed during boot to identify device. It may also be used in network as alias for IP address. This feature requires NetBIOS protocol to be enabled in LAN. Be aware not all characters are allowed in hostname string. DO NOT USE "space, slash, backslash, colon, semicolon, question mark, asterisk, smaller, bigger, pipe".

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:HOST "test"

        
Requires reboot of device.

        
Hostname resolution in LAN works only if NetBIOS protocol is enabled.

      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:HOST?Queries hostname of the device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:HOSTname?

        
Response
    
          
  • namestring new device hostname.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the hostname of the device. The hostname can be used to customize the device name. It is displayed during boot to identify device. It may also be used in network as alias for IP address. This feature requires NetBIOS protocol to be enabled in LAN.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:SCPI:HOST?
<< "Test_01"

        
Hostname resolution in LAN works only if NetBIOS protocol is enabled.

      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:MAC?Queries MAC address of device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:MAC?

        
Response
    
          
  • hexStrstring MAC address as hex string. Bytes separated by colon.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query MAC address of device as hex string.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:MAC?
<< "98:27:82:D0:00:0F"


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:PROPEnables/Disables LAN service propagation
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:PROPagation 
<enable>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • enablebool 1 to enable service propagation. False to disable
    • 
        


        
Use this command to enable/disable sending response on service propagation request  UDP broadcast on port 270378. If disabled the device can not longer be found by network search triggered by FindResources. If the IP address is known a connection might be established regardless if this switch is enabled or disabled. 

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:PROP 1


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:PROP?Tests if service propagation is active or not
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:PROPagation?

        
Response
    
          
  • enablebool 1 to enable service propagation. False to disable
    • 
        


        
Use this command to test if sending response for service propagation request  is enabled or disabled. For closer details read SYST:COMM:LAN:PROP.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:PROP?
<< 0


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:SCPI:PORSets a Ethernet new port for the SCPI server
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:SCPI:PORt 
<port>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • portuint new port number. 0 to disable service. Default it 2000.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the Ethernet port number of the SCPI server. The server allows sending SCPI commands via Ethernet. You can use port number 0 to disable the service. Once the port number is changed a reboot of the device is mandatory to apply new server settings.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:SCPI:POR 2001

        
Requires reboot of device.


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:SCPI:POR?Queries Ethernet port for the SCPI server
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:SCPI:PORt?

        
Response
    
          
  • portuint new port number. 0 to disable service. Default it 2000.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the Ethernet port number of the SCPI server. The server allows sending SCPI commands via Ethernet. For closer details read SYST:COMM:LAN:SCPI:POR.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:SCPI:POR?
<< 2001


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:SMASChanges IPv4 netmask of device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:SMASk 
<netmask>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • netmaskstring IPv4 netmask string. Bytes separated by fullstop.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change IPv4 netmask of device. If DHCP is enabled the function simply updates the static IPv4 netmask without applying configuration to the network interface. If DHCP is disabled the command also applies configuration to the network interface.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:SMAS "255.255.255.128"


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:SMAS?Queries IPv4 netmask of device
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:SMASk?

        
Response
    
          
  • netmaskstring IPv4 netmask string. Bytes separated by fullstop.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query IPv4 netmask of device. If DHCP is enabled and no IP has been assigned yet the result might be "0.0.0.0". If DHCP is disabled the static IPv4 netmask will be returned.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:SMAS?
<< "255.255.255.0"


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:WEB:PORSets a Ethernet new port for the Web server
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:WEB:PORt 
<port>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • portuint new port number. 0 to disable service. Default it 80.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the Ethernet port number of the  Web server. The server allows monitoring device state via web browser. You can use port number 0 to disable the service. Once the port number is changed a reboot of the device is mandatory to apply new server settings.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:SCPI:POR 8080

        
Requires reboot of device.


      

    

    

      

        SYST:COMM:LAN:WEB:POR?Queries Ethernet port for the Web server
      

      

        
SYSTem:COMMunicate:LAN:WEB:PORt?

        
Response
    
          
  • portuint new port number. 0 to disable service. Default it 80.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the Ethernet port number of the Web server. The server allows monitoring device state via web browser. For closer details read SYST:COMM:LAN:WEB:POR.

        
>> SYST:COMM:LAN:WEB:POR?
<< 80


      

    

    

      

        SYST:DATEChanges device date
      

      

        
SYSTem:DATE 
<year>
,
<month>
,
<day>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • yearuint year
    • 
              
  • monthuint month of year 1 to 12
    • 
              
  • dayuint day of month 2 to 31
    • 
        


        
>> SYST:DATE 2023,3,23


      

    

    

      

        SYST:DATE?Returns device date
      

      

        
SYSTem:DATE?

        
Response
    
          
  • yearuint year
    • 
          
  • monthuint month of year 1 to 12
    • 
          
  • dayuint day of month 2 to 31
    • 
        


        
>> SYST:DATE?
<< 2022,4,13


      

    

    

      

        SYST:ERR?Reads and removes oldest element of SCPI error queue
      

      

        
SYSTem:ERRor[:NEXT]?

        
Response
    
          
  • errorint SPCI error code. If no error occurred result will be 0.
    • 
          
  • errDescstring error code English description text.
    • 
        


        
Call to test if there where errors during command execution or asynchronous device errors. The device internally uses a error queue to store SCPI errors. This command returns and removes the oldest element of the queue. Call multiple times until queue is empty and function returns 0, "No error". The internal queue length is limited. So if you do not keep the queue empty you might loose errors when queue is full.

        
>> SYST:ERR?
<< -113,"Undefined header"


      

    

    

      

        SYST:ERR:COUN?Tests how many errors are stored in SCPI error queue
      

      

        
SYSTem:ERRor:COUNt?

        
Response
    
          
  • errDescuint Amount of errors stored in SCPI error queue. 0 when empty.
    • 
        


        
For closer details about SCPI error queue read SYST:ERR?.

        
>> SYST:ERR:COUN?
<< 1


      

    

    

      

        SYST:PARA:EXPO:JSON?Exports device parameter as JSON
      

      

        
SYSTem:PARAmeter:EXPOrt:JSON?

        
Response
    
          
  • jsonStrstring device parameters as single line JSON string
    • 
        


        
Use this command to export the persistently stored device parameters as single line JSON string. Some parameters like zeroing are not exported as the value is not valid for future imports. Use SYST:PARA:IMPO:JSON to import the parameter set again.

        
>> SYST:PARA:EXPO:JSON?
<< {"pm":{"name":"PM5020","adap0":1, ... longer JSON


      

    

    

      

        SYST:PARA:IMPO:JSONImports device parameters from JSON string
      

      

        
SYSTem:PARAmeter:IMPOrt:JSON 
<adapt>
, 
<jsonStr>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • adaptbool true to adapt parameters to ranges. False to generate error when out of range.
    • 
              
  • jsonStrstring device parameters as single line JSON format string. May be a substring of json line if larger 240 chars.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to import a previously stored parameter set again. The command will parse the JSON input and apply the parameter value. To export parameter set use SYST:PARA:EXPO:JSON?. It is possible to import parameters within a sensor family.  For example you might import parameters exported for a photodiode when another photodiode  is currenlty connected. Use the adapt parameter to allow the command to change the parameters  when out of range. When adaption is not allowed or input data is invalid for any other  reason a SCPI error is enqueued. Use SYST:ERR? to check if import was successful. 
 If JSON input string is longer than 240 chars the input data needs to be split into multiple calls of this command. The JSON fragment data is buffered and reassembled in the device memory. Once all data is transmited (detected by curly bracket counting) it gets parsed and executed. You can obmit any buffered input data by sending magic character #. 

        
>> SYST:PARA:IMPO:JSON  1,'{ '{"pm":{"name":"PM5020","ser":"P00000001"'

        
The maximal request length is limited to 240 characters! Call this command multiple times with sub strings.


      

    

    

      

        SYST:PASSOverwrites the system password used for authentication
      

      

        
SYSTem:PASSword 
<oldPas>
, 
<newPas>
, 
<cryptLAN>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • oldPasstring old ASCII passwort string. Max length is 25. Min length is 5
    • 
              
  • newPasstring new ASCII passwort string. Max length is 25. Min length is 5
    • 
              
  • cryptLANbool True if SCPI LAN interface should be crypted
    • 
        


        
>> SYSTem:PASSword "THORlabs", "K4!kes§", 1

        
Default password ist THORlabs


      

    

    

      

        SYST:PASS?Queries password used for authentication
      

      

        
SYSTem:PASSword?

        
Response
    
          
  • passstring passwort string.
    • 
          
  • cryptLANbool True if SCPI LAN interface is crypted. False for uncrypted.
    • 
        


        
>> SYSTem:PASSword?
<< THORlabs, 0

        
Default password ist THORlabs. Only supported by local serial or USB interface.


      

    

    

      

        SYST:SENS#:IDN?Sensor head identification query
      

      

        
SYSTem:SENSor
#
:IDN?

        
Suffixe
    
          
  • Sufix 1uint light sensor frontend channel 1 or 2. Default is 1.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • namestring name of sensor
    • 
          
  • serialstring serial number of sensor
    • 
          
  • calibrationDatestring calibration date of sensor. Format dd-MonthStr-YYYY.
    • 
          
  • typeuint type of sensor. See list in detail description.
    • 
          
  • subtypeuint subtype of sensor head. See list in detail description.
    • 
          
  • flagsuint bitmask with sensor capabilities. See lis tin detail description.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the light sensor head identification. Next to the name, serial and calibration date you get 3 numbers. The following listing defines the sensor types: 
     
  • 1: Single photodiode sensor
    •  
  • 2: Thermopile sensor
    •  
  • 3: Pyroelectric sensor
    •  
  • 4: Four Quadrant thermopile sensor
    •  
 These are the sensor subtypes: 
     
  • 1: Adapter sensor without head correction.
    •  
  • 2: Sensor without head temperature sensor
    •  
  • 3: Sensor filter slider. (Photodiode only)
    •  
  • 18: Sensor with temperature sensor
    •  
 The sensor capability flags are a bitmask with a bit set to 1 if the sensor supports the following function 
     
  • bit 0(1 dec): Sensor is a power sensor
    •  
  • bit 1(2 dec): Sensor is a energy sensor
    •  
  • bit 4(16 dec): Sensor supports setting responsivity parameter (Adapter only)
    •  
  • bit 5(32 dec): Sensor supports setting wavelength parameter (Non Adapter only)
    •  
  • bit 6(64 dec): Sensor supports setting of tau. (Thermopile adapter only)
    •  
  • bit 8(256 dec): Sensor head supports measurement of head temperature
    •  

        
>> SYST:SENS1:IDN?
<< "S120C","16060232","2-JUN-2021",1,18,33


      

    

    

      

        SYST:SER:TRAN:BAUDChanges baudrate of SCPI serial interface
      

      

        
SYSTem:SERial:TRANsmit:BAUD 
<baudrate>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • baudrateuint,MIN,DEF,MAX RS232 interface baudrate.
    • 
        


        
Use this command to change the currently configured baudrate of SCPI serial interface. The baudrate gets changed immediately and is stored persistently. The Powermeter supports the following baudrates: 
     
  • 9600
    •  
  • 14400
    •  
  • 19200
    •  
  • 28800
    •  
  • 38400
    •  
  • 57600
    •  
  • 115200 (default)
    •  
  • 230400
    •  
  • 460800
    •  
  • 921600
    •  

        
>> SYST:SER:TRAN:BAUD 9600


      

    

    

      

        SYST:SER:TRAN:BAUD?Queries baudrate of SCPI serial interface
      

      

        
SYSTem:SERial:TRANsmit:BAUD? 
<special>

        
Parameters
    
           
  • specialMIN,MAX,DEF Optional! Query minimal, default or maximal used baudrate.
    • 
        


        
Response
    
          
  • baudrateuint currently configured baudrate of serial SCPI interface
    • 
        


        
Use this command to query the currently configured baudrate of SCPI serial interface. For closer details about supported baudrates read SYST:SER:TRAN:BAUD.

        
>> SYST:SER:TRAN:BAUD?
<< 115200


      

    

    

      

        SYST:TIMEChanges device time
      

      

        
SYSTem:TIME 
<hour>
,
<minute>
,
<seconds>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • houruint hour of day from 0 to 23
    • 
              
  • minuteuint minutes of hour from 0 to 59
    • 
              
  • secondsuint seconds of minute from 0 to 59
    • 
        


        
Call this function to manually adjust the system time. You may also want to use SYST:TIME:NTP to set date and time by an external time server. If you want to adjust system time because of summer- or wintertime you should use SYST:TIME:MODE.

        
>> SYST:DATE 11,34,23


      

    

    

      

        SYST:TIME?Returns device time
      

      

        
SYSTem:TIME?

        
Response
    
          
  • houruint hour of day from 0 to 23
    • 
          
  • minuteuint minutes of hour from 0 to 59
    • 
          
  • secondsuint seconds of minute from 0 to 59
    • 
        


        
>> SYST:TIME?
<< 13,27,17


      

    

    

      

        SYST:TIME:MODEChanges clock for summer or winter time
      

      

        
SYSTem:TIME:MODE 
<timeMode>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • timeModeSPEC SUMMER or WINTER for summertime or wintertime.
    • 
        


        
Call to set summer or winter time without modifying the clock itself. This flag automatically adds an additional hour to the clock during summertime.

        
>> SYST:TIME:MODE SUMMER


      

    

    

      

        SYST:TIME:MODE?Tests if clock configured for summer or winter time
      

      

        
SYSTem:TIME:MODE?

        
Response
    
          
  • timeModeSPEC SUMMER or WINTER for summertime or wintertime.
    • 
        


        
>> SYST:TIME:MODE?
<< SUMMER


      

    

    

      

        SYST:TIME:NTPSynchronize device time with external NTP time server
      

      

        
SYSTem:TIME:NTP 
<timezone>
,
<isSummertime>
,
<ipForServer>

        
Parameters
    
              
  • timezoneuint Local time zone offset for GMT. Berlin is +1
    • 
              
  • isSummertimeuint 0 for wintertime. 1 for summertime
    • 
           
  • ipForServeruint Optional! ip address of used NTP server. By default PTB server is used.
    • 
        


        
Call this function to trigger a device time sync with an external NTP (Network time protocol) server. This requires an active Ethernet connection with the route to the requested server.

        
>> SYST:TIME:NTP 1,1

        
The device does not support DNS resolution. So you have to address a fixed IP.


      

    

    

      

        SYST:VERS?Returns SCPI version string
      

      

        
SYSTem:VERSion?

        
Response
    
          
  • versstring SCPI version string without quotes. See details for format.
    • 
        


        
Response format YYYY.V. YYYY is year of SCPI standard. V is the revision of standard.

        
>> SYST:VER?
<< 1999.0
